PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 78 citizens), Senator Calvert (from 83 citizens), Senator Knowles (from 20 citizens) and Senator Parer (from 261 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: That the Senate consider proposing amendments to the Child Care Act with regard to the current policy on Attendance Records

PARA.TAB: because:

PETITION.PARA: The Attendance Records are impractical for Family Day Care services.
Family Day Carers homes are not set up with separate office facilities, as Child Care Centres are.
Children who are transported to and from school may require the parent or responsible person to sign four times each day for each child.
Carers are responsible for making sure parents sign their children in and out each day.
The issue of accountability is not addressed by the Attendance Records.

PARA.TAB: We wish the Minister to look at proposed amendments. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate consider these amendments.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 68 citizens) and Senator Calvert (from 81 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy picks up and unemployment falls dramatically.
Further, that the Senate recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies and has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: UN Declaration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
the U.N. Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion and Belief

PARA.TAB: aDenies the Freedom of Religion guaranteed in the Australian Constitution
bIs designed to impede or oppose the Biblical life and ministry of the Christian Church
cIs being introduced as law to bring changes to our nation that were rejected by the people in the last Referendum on the Constitution

PETITION.PARA: We therefore ask the Senate to take all steps to have this Declaration disallowed from the HREOC Act 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag and condemns the attack on the Australian flag by the Prime Minister Mr Keating while he was overseas.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin the repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

PETITION.TITLE: Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to the fact that:

PARA.TAB: The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) contributes millions of dollars annually to the economy of Cooma.
If sold to private enterprise there is no guarantee that SMEC will remain in Cooma and no such guarantee can be given.
Such a sale would therefore decimate the economy of Cooma, reduce property values, and inevitably lead to social problems.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate that SMEC not be sold but remain in public ownership and therefore in Cooma.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bougainville
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the plight of the people of Bougainville. We call on the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: end military aid to the Government of Papua New Guinea.
demand the withdrawal of the Defence Forces of Papua New Guinea from Bougainville and an end to the blockade of Bougainville.
recognise the right to self-determination of the people of Bougainville.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Embargo: Bosnia-Herzegovina
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we are appalled at the atrocities which are currently taking place within Bosnia-Herzegovina. As citizens of a country that prides itself on freedom, democracy and human rights, we believe it is Australia's duty to oppose genocide in accordance with International Law.

Your petitioners therefore pray that our Australian Government supports the proposal to lift the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government so that it may defend its people, and to exclusively incapacitate military establishments in territories held by the Serbian Forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petitioning letter, from 40 citizens, which is not in conformity with the standing orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: It has come to our notice that two documents have been inserted into Australian law by a notice in the Gazette on 13th January 1993 and 24th February 1993. They relate to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) Act 1986 with the "United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child" and the "Declaration on the Elimination of all Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion and Belief".

We understand that a notice of motion to disallow them must be given in the Senate by 17th August or the House of Representatives soon after. We ask that you do all in your power to oppose the United Nations Religion Declaration to ensure the continuance of religious freedom in this country. We also ask that Parliament also please do all in its power to disallow the Child's Rights Treaty as it could have disastrous effects on the family and also on society generally.

Surely the responsibility and accountability for bringing up children should rest with parents' loving discipline, not with the government. Laws already exist to safeguard children's welfare. Why do we need laws to allow licence and rebellion to multiply? Apparently Article 15 gives the child the right to associate with whomever he/she pleases and parents' rights stated in Article 5 are worded in legally weak and qualified terms.

Of equal concern is the ability of a Government to change laws merely by publishing a notice in the Gazette without a full debate and vote in Parliament. I trust that you will be able to take steps to stop such an insidious abuse of power by disallowing these Gazetted notices from becoming law without full parliamentary debate and vote by members.
We would appreciate a reply to our letter indicating your support for our protest.

Dear Ros
I refer to the Importation of Arms, Ammunition and Explosives Ordinance 1992, Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands Ordinance No.6 of 1992, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 6 April 1993.

The ordinance regulates the importation of arms, ammunition and explosive in the Islands. The commencement clause provides for the ordinance to take effect on the gazettal of a notice by the Minister. This is a departure from the usual practice where, if there is no fixed date, there will be automatic commencement after a set period, normally six months. No reason has been given in the Explanatory Statement for this departure from current practice.

Sections 8, 11 and 12 respectively confer discretions on the Commissioner to grant or refuse a permit, to vary a permit and to revoke or suspend a permit. Sections 8 and 12 provide only for subjective criteria to control this power; section 11 provides no criteria at all. Sections 8 and 12 provide for an appeal to the Minister against an adverse decision, but there appears to be no such appeal from a s.11 decision. Perhaps you could advise the reasons for this.

Section 13 provides that the Minister's decision on appeals is final. There appears to be no provision for the Minister to delegate this power and we would be grateful for your confirmation that this is the case and that all s.13 appeals must be decided personally by the Minister.
In addition, there does not appear to be an appeal from a decision under s.14 to refuse to grant a temporary import permit or to grant such a permit subject to unacceptable conditions.

Section 27 confers wide powers of delegation on the Commissioner, who may delegate all of his or her powers to any person at all. Furthermore, any person to whom the Commissioner delegates power may, in turn, subdelegate all of such power to any person at all. These powers of delegation and subdelegation are unusual.
Section 24 provides that unless seized firearms are returned within 60 days, they must be taken to court to be dealt with according to law. This appears to be a long period.
There are several drafting oversights in the ordinance. The reference to `his' in s.8 should be `his or her' and the reference in s.14(8) to s.6(1)(a) should be to s.6(a).
The Committee would be grateful for your advice on the above matters.
Yours sincerely

Dear Stephen

I refer to your five letters of 7 April 1993 (reference numbers 302, 308, 317, 318 and 327) to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories in relation to the Local Government (Transition)(Amendment) Ordinance 1992, Land Legislation Ordinance 1992, . . .

PARA.TAB: Importation of Arms, Ammunition and Explosives Ordinance 1992 . . .

SPEECH.PARA: of the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Mrs Kelly has asked me to respond on her behalf. I regret the delay in replying.
Local Government (Transition)(Amendment) Ordinance 1992

The Committee was concerned that new sections 108, 111, 115, 122 and 133 of the applied Local Government Act 1960 (W.A.)(C.K.I.), which require a returning officer or other electoral official to be satisfied of various matters, do not contain an indication of what would happen if a person is not satisfied with the official's decision.

This Ordinance enabled the former system of voting on Cocos (which involved voters affixing a stamp on the ballot paper next to a photograph of their favoured candidate) to continue to be used for the first elections under the applied WA Act, held on 1 May 1993. This allows Territory residents to become familiar with the electoral provisions in the WA Act, under which subsequent elections will be conducted. The sections of the Act to which the Committee refers are amended only to the extent necessary to achieve this objective and the basic framework of the Act, including the provisions covering challenges to decisions made by electoral officers, is not changed. This is in line with the overall objective of applying WA laws to the Territory with a minimum of modifications.

The WA provisions do not give individual electors a statutory right to object to decisions by an electoral officer. Section 150 of the Act does, however, allow a candidate or a group of six or more electors to bring a complaint to a Court of Disputed Returns alleging that the result of an election is invalid. In view of the overall objective, I believe these provisions are adequate and should not be changed. . . .
Land Legislation Ordinance 1992

As requested, I can assure the Committee that this Ordinance will not be prejudicial to any private landowners in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. New section 176 of the Land Act 1933 (W.A.)(C.K.I.), which relates to easements, only applies to land where the Commonwealth already possesses the rights set out in the section. The Ordinance simply provides for these rights to be brought within the WA land tenure system, which was introduced to the Islands on 1 July 1992. In addition, the Commonwealth is the only landowner affected by new section 177 of the Land Act and section 286 of the Local Government Act 1960 (W.A.)(C.K.I.), relating to the property in land dedicated as a public street.
Importation of Arms, Ammunition and Explosives Ordinance 1992

Before addressing the Committee's queries about this Ordinance, I would like to explain that it was necessary to make the Ordinance at the earliest possible date to remedy a deficiency in the Territory's laws which arose because the former law restricting the importation of arms and ammunition was inadvertently repealed when WA laws were introduced. The import restrictions had proved to be the most effective means of controlling the poaching of protected seabirds in the Territory.

I accept that commencement of an Ordinance by Ministerial notice is unusual, however it was not practical for the Ordinance to commence on gazettal because the Regulations and forms necessary for it to operate effectively had not been finalised at that time. A specific date could have been set for the Ordinance's commencement, but this might have enabled persons to take advantage of the deficiency in the existing law to frustrate the Ordinance's purpose. The Ordinance was in fact commenced on 26 February 1993.

The criteria in sections 8 and 12 of the Ordinance are based on those contained in the Firearms Act 1973 of WA. This Act has been applied to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and sets out criteria for granting a firearms licence but does not regulate the importing of arms and ammunition. Adoption of these criteria reflects the general policy of following WA standards and also ensures that the criteria used for granting import permits and issuing firearms licences are consistent.

The principal intention of section 11 of the Ordinance is simply to allow the Commissioner of Police to make minor variations to a permit where, for example, the date on which importation is permitted needs to be altered due to a transport delay. It is obvious, however, that the wording of the section is far broader than this. Consequently, I am prepared to undertake to the Committee to amend this section by inserting criteria to be followed for varying a permit and providing for a right of appeal.

The Committee is correct that there is no provision for the Minister to delegate the power to decide appeals under section 13 of the Ordinance. As a Parliamentary Secretary I am, however, authorised to exercise this power on behalf of the Minister.

Section 6 of the Ordinance imposes penalties for intentionally or recklessly importing a firearm or ammunition except under a valid permit. Section 14 of the Ordinance is intended to cover situations where a person imports a firearm or ammunition due to ignorance of the requirements of the Ordinance. The Commissioner can issue a temporary entry permit to exempt such a person from liability under section 6. Consequently, a refusal by the Commissioner to issue a temporary entry permit involves a determination that the circumstances of importation justify a prosecution under section 6. I do not see it as desirable for a determination of this type to be Ministerially reviewable.

I acknowledge that the powers of delegation and subdelegation contained in section 27 of the Ordinance are unusually wide, but I believe that these powers are necessary in view of the remoteness of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Powers will be delegated principally to the sole police officer permanently stationed in the Territory, but this officer may require assistance at short notice, for example to carry out a search of a ship. A situation of this type occurred in January 1992 when it was necessary to appoint Administration employees and other Territory residents as special constables to seize a large quantity of illegally imported shotgun shells.

Section 24 of the Ordinance, allowing a 60 day period before seized firearms must be brought before a court, also takes into account the isolation of the Territory and the fact that court officers are based in WA. I intend, however, to monitor the operation of this section and am prepared to amend the Ordinance if 60 days proves to be excessive.
I thank the Committee for drawing my attention to the drafting errors contained in the Ordinance. These errors will be corrected when the Ordinance is amended. . . .
I trust this information explains to the Committee's satisfaction the approach adopted in the Ordinances.
Yours sincerely
WARREN SNOWDON

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Loosley

I refer to your letter of 7 April 1993 in which you request advice on why regulation 37G of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employees) Regulations (amendment) requires employers to retain for 30 years records of accidents and dangerous occurrences which are reported to Comcare Australia. The delay in responding is regretted.

In the course of the development of the regulations the need for better information about gradual onset disease was addressed. There was concern in particular about the uncertain health outcomes of the use, for example, of some chemicals and other hazardous substances in the workplace. Unions highlighted the need to record and maintain information about accidents and incidents which could lead to the development of gradual onset diseases. Consequently they requested that the regulations require employers to retain accident records for 30 years. Employer representatives agreed to this proposal on the condition that records could be stored electronically.

It is envisaged that the retention of this information will be valuable in monitoring and responding to the less obvious and emerging trends in occupational injury and disease in Australian Government employment. This in turn will lead to financial savings by reducing workers' compensation costs.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
LAURIE BRERETON

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That there be laid on the table of the Senate, within 5 sitting days after the passage of this resolution, a statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), and any relevant documentary evidence, setting out the full facts relating to the knowledge and involvement of ministers, particularly Senators Collins, Cook and Richardson, and their staff, with respect to the proposed scheme whereby the Labor Party was to sell access to ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a most important motion. The Australian Labor Party has obviously sought to prostitute the principles and practices of the parliament. We have seen recently many instances of the Labor Party, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and various ministers of the government showing disrespect for the institution of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has referred to the Senate as `unrepresentative swill'. He has taken actions and has made suggestions with regard to our national symbols and our flag. Now, when the Prime Minister's party is selling off seats in the parliament and access to members of his ministry for $3,000, we have indeed reached a new and total disrespect for the parliament. We need to ask a number of very important questions that arise from this action of the Labor Party.

It was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 13 August that 20 senior business figures were alleged to have paid a $3,000 fee for access to the parliament on budget night on special terms and conditions. The article by Mr Tom Burton referred to the fact that the ALP was seeking to raise funds by offering special access to ministers to be used at the official release of the government's budget and by selling off time with ministers, including the Prime Minister. After watching the budget from the privileged, specially selected, $3,000 seats in the House of Representatives, there were to be direct briefings on the budget by the finance minister, Mr Willis. The brochure went on to outline a whole array of ministers who were then obviously to give special rights and special privilege to the people who took up this offer.

The ministers named in that article who had agreed to participate where Ministers Crean, Cook, Brereton, Richardson and Collins. The Senate has a particular interest in the terms of the motion, because some of those ministers—Ministers Cook, Richardson and Collins—belong to this chamber. We need to ask very explicitly: what on earth could the taxpayers of Australia gain from the ministers' involvement in these special budget briefings? When did the ministers learn about the events that were to be planned, or even when they were subsequently cancelled? Senior Labor figures now seem to be terribly confused over the dates and the activities that were to take place. Why was it finally called off? Was it because it was discovered that it may have breached parliamentary privilege or was it because of lack of interest by business community groups in wanting to participate?

This attempt by the government is nothing short of an unethical and dishonourable way of raising money for the Labor Party's purely partisan purposes. It is concerning that three ministers from this chamber would participate in such a scam. It is terribly important to know what prior access to the budget papers through the ministers' offices had been given and was available in the preparation for the briefings that were to take place at this level. If one considers the particular ministers from this chamber that were to have participated and looks at their portfolios, one can see that the budget implications had special relevance.

Senator Richardson, as Minister for Health, obviously had a special interest in the areas of this budget that would have affected many wide ranging commercial interests in the community. Senator Cook, in particular, interests me because in this chamber he represents the primary industry portfolio. The implications that would have arisen for the whole rural sector of Australia and the special privilege that would have been granted to businessmen prepared to pay a $3,000 fee for these special privileges need to be answered.

We are well aware of many of Senator Collins's actions in relation to his portfolio interests in this chamber for the last year. We are well aware of the interest that he has taken in the waterfront and the shipping portfolio about the reforms that are proposed and what is in the budget. We remember that, not only with regard to the waterfront but also with regard to the Civil Aviation Authority, Senator Collins has had special and commercial interests that have been apparent in the air traffic control system and, much more recently, with the whole pay TV debacle there are implications that would have arisen through this particular budget.

There has to be a special answering by the government of what prior knowledge officers of the Labor Party had of access to these ministers' offices. We need to know the diary commitments that were made by each and every one of the ministers in advance with the Labor Party hierarchy, independent of their roles and their responsibilities to this particular parliament. The full facts and the knowledge and the involvement of the ministers need to be on the table and this Senate chamber ought to have a special report. I call on the Leader of the Government in the Senate to explain comprehensively, in full detail, this particularly ridiculous proposal by the Labor Party.

I hope, Mr President, that both you and Mr Speaker have called the leaders of the parliamentary wing of the Labor Party to account in this place. I hope that you have challenged the ministers who have been named by the Labor Party for a full report. I find that the particular proposals put forward have been ridiculous in the first instance, insulting to this chamber, generally insulting to the parliament and a complete breach of trust and faith in the proper principles of good government and responsibility to all taxpayers of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —May I explain to Senator Tambling that there was some confusion in the way this motion was to be handled. I indicated to him that I was happy to take it as formal and would make a brief statement as to why I would take that course. With inadvertence I did not know that the motion had been moved on Tuesday, not Wednesday, and that we would have to seek to do it now in the way that Senator Tambling has done it today.

PARA.TAB: Let me say why the government will not oppose this motion. That may seem surprising to some. It is not that we endorse any of the editorial content within it, but we believe the charge is totally baseless and we would like to respond and have the appropriate opportunity to respond. We will respond, even in the rather ridiculous terms that Senator Tambling has put down here today, and we will do it within the five days.

For those who just listened to Senator Tambling's speech, let us say for the record this is an event that did not occur, and in the better judgment of the Labor Party it did not occur. It was a fundraising idea from a particular individual, in which the Labor Party intervened and cancelled. But when we come to the discussion, within five days' time, some of the other documents we have relating to the Liberal Party and its various fundraising and involvement schemes will also be put on the record, as a matter of balance. These are ones that actually went ahead, without the Liberal Party intervening and cancelling. We are talking not only at a federal level but also at a state government level. I think I might promise Senator Tambling to do it at a Northern Territory level. On the whole, Senator Tambling has raised an issue and a charge that requires response. We welcome the opportunity to respond to it, and we will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the government has agreed to Senator Tambling's motion, but I am encouraged to add a few words of support to Senator Tambling's moving of the motion because of the word that Senator Ray used in calling the motion `ridiculous'.

PARA.TAB: I have a distinct recollection that in the euphoria of the Labor Party's dinner for the true deceivers, it was a dinner that was said to be to raise funds for the Fred Hollows Foundation. Yet it was just, dare I call it, a dinner for the swill and, in fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stood and said he was only going to govern for one-half of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Bishop has referred to those attending the dinner as swill. They involved a very large number of Labor parliamentarians, as she is well aware. I do not think that is an appropriate form of reference on this occasion in this place.
—If the remark was directed towards members of parliament, it should be withdrawn.

—Mr President, I would ask you to make a ruling on that. If it is fine for the Prime Minister to use the term `unrepresentative swill' to describe senators, is it not fair that that statement should be available for others to use?
—I have control only over what is said in this chamber; and if you were directing that comment at members of parliament, I think it should be withdrawn.

—I was using the term to describe the dinner as a whole. It was not directed at anyone in particular. It was the dinner for the true deceivers; and the Prime Minister stood up and said that he would be punishing lobby groups and representative industry groups that did not support him. He was going to rule for only one half of Australia: those who supported him and are now regretting it at their leisure. He indicated that he had no intention of looking after the interests of all Australians, and that he was going to be a Prime Minister only for certain people who supported the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, the function did not go ahead, in Senator Ray's terms, but the brochure was issued and people paid their money. It did not go ahead only because the news was broken first in the Financial Review and then in other newspapers. They outlined that this was not a party political conference at which, quite rightly, people would be able to give access to members of the party. This was the Parliament of Australia, and these people were being seen in their capacity as ministers of state: people who are charged under our constitution with governing for the peace, order and good government of all Australians.

The reason Senator Tambling has brought this matter to the attention of the Senate and asked for the information is not because anyone objects to seeing business people or ordinary Australians meeting with their representatives. Indeed, part of the reason is the failure of the Prime Minister to do that. He goes home in the afternoons and bunkers down in the Lodge and does not do his work properly. He does not turn up to the meetings he should properly attend, and he is not available to see Australians and the hurt that they are suffering.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless they pay for it.

—Unless they pay for it, that is the point. I want the Prime Minister to be available to the people. I want the ministers of state and other members and senators to be talking to the Australian people so that we make better laws for them. If we are out of touch, we make bad laws. But to say that access to a minister of state, in his capacity of minister of state, after bringing down the prospectus for Australia—that is, the budget, the most important single financial document that goes on the record—shall be given exclusively to those who contribute to the coffers of the Australian Labor Party is simply not acceptable.

PARA.TAB: That is why I rail at the term Senator Ray used in saying that the matter Senator Tambling is raising was a ridiculous one. The ridiculous proposition is that access to the ministers and members of this place should be given only to those who pay. That is what is outrageous. There should be access for the Australian people, for anyone who wants to have access. People will say that that is fine, and we all attend functions for which people charge. It might be $35, it might be $75. But $3,000? Should they charge $3,000 to give exclusive access to somebody who is supposed to be governing for all Australia and is appearing in their official capacity? That is the question we are debating here.

I can only say, strongly and sincerely, that if ordinary Australians could be given greater access to the people who are making the laws for Australia, then we would be doing our duty. It is simply not the Australian way to say, as the Prime Minister said, that he will give access only to those people who are friends of the Labor Party and who did not criticise the Labor Party—and him in particular—during the lead-up to the election, and that others can pay for that privilege. It is simply an unAustralian act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make certain that one matter is included in the response to Senator Tambling, and I thank Senator Ray for his willingness to come back within five days. One element of this matter which is of concern to me is a question relating to the announcement in the Financial Review which said that the proposal was that, after watching the budget from specially arranged seating in the House of Representatives chamber, all these other events would take place. I do not know how many of my colleagues here unsuccessfully sought seats in the House of Representatives chamber at budget time for their family, for friends, for associates, and were knocked back because there were no seats available. It happens all the time. I wonder how many of my colleagues in the House of Representatives sought seats for their families to watch the budget, particularly the new members.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a situation where specially arranged seating in the House of Representatives chamber was to be made available at a fee arranged by the Victorian division of the ALP, a matter of which the ministers appear to have been aware. What I want answered in this matter is: who provided the seats? Who demanded the seats? Whose seats really were they? To whom would these seats normally have been made available? Would they be available to members of parliament and their families, to the public, or were they specially reserved for sale to friends of the Labor Party? If this sort of procedure is allowed to exist then we not only have seats in parliament for sale, we have a Prime Minister for rent and we have various other ministers for rent.

I am intrigued to note in the Financial Review when Mr Gary Gray, the new federal secretary of the Labor Party, said he had cancelled the matter a week before it took place—none of the participants knew it had been cancelled, but that is by the way; it must have been a very effective cancelling—he said, and I quote from the Financial Review, `I became aware last week that this function was very sloppily organised'. There was no moral objection to selling seats in the House of Representatives, to selling the time of the Prime Minister and other ministers. His objection was that it was sloppily organised. That is a great, moral, firm stand. That is why I want these matters included in the answer. I hope that Senator Evans will ensure that the undertaking Senator Ray gave extends to this matter of whose seats they were. Why were our families and our friends denied access to the House of Representatives because these seats were specifically set aside for people who had bought them?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to a revised Murray-Darling Basin Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. The Agreement is set out in the Schedule to this Bill.

The Murray-Darling Basin Agreement provides the framework for intergovernmental cooperation to address natural resource management issues in the Basin of joint concern. As Australia's most important agricultural region, the Murray-Darling Basin is a major focus of the Government's approach to achieving sustainable resource use.

The Murray-Darling Basin comprises about one-seventh of Australia. It also produces about one-half of Australia's total output from natural resource-based industries. It supports 25 per cent of the nation's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and cropland, and almost 75 per cent of its irrigated land. Production derived is valued at some $10 billion annually. It is Australia's agricultural heartland.

Until well after the Second World War, the River Murray Commission, established under the first River Murray Waters Agreement of 1914, stood the test of time in successfully regulating the shared water resources of the River Murray to ensure reliable supplies for irrigation, urban and industrial use. This provided the foundation for the irrigation industry in the Murray Valley and ensured that South Australia received a supply of water essential to its survival and growth.

In the early 1980's, however, there was growing community and government concern about the economic and environmental costs of resource degradation in the Basin. The four governments party to the River Murray Waters Agreement recognised that a joint approach was necessary to address broader resource and environmental problems in the Basin.

The breakthrough in achieving a genuinely holistic approach to Basin natural resource management came in November 1985 when Ministers with responsibility for natural resources in the Labor Governments of the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, agreed to adopt a cooperative approach to the better management of all the resources of the Basin.

This new approach was given effect through an amended River Murray Waters Agreement which was signed by the Prime Minister and the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia in October 1987. Parallel legislation was passed in all Parliaments a short time later.

The paramount feature of the new Murray-Darling Basin Agreement was the establishment of a Ministerial Council to promote effective planning and management for the equitable, efficient and sustainable use of the water, land and environmental resources of the Basin. The Agreement also created the Murray-Darling Basin Commission to assume the River Murray Commission's regulatory responsibilities and take a broader advisory responsibility to the Ministerial Council.

Another important element in the Agreement was the provision for a direct line of communication between the Council and the Basin community through the establishment of the Community Advisory Committee. All participating Governments recognised the need for cooperation not only on an intergovernmental level but also with the community.
With this strong institutional framework, the Murray-Darling Basin Initiative represents a genuinely comprehensive approach to natural resource management.

Innovative public administration arrangements are linked with a strategic and comprehensive suite of policies and programs. These are firmly aimed in addressing real problems and realising genuine opportunities open to governments and communities to progress their mutual interests.

In addressing natural resource management issues, the Initiative depends fundamentally on mobilisation of the community. It is an outstanding demonstration of how policies and practices can be integrated to resolve the conflicts between competing demands for natural resources on the one hand and their sustainable use on the other.
The Initiative has an impressive list of achievements.

The Salinity and Drainage Strategy, a major component of the overall Natural Resources Management Strategy, has provided an effective means of dealing with land salinisation and waterlogging in the irrigation areas of the Basin. It is a dramatic reminder of the benefits of taking a coordinated approach across State borders to address natural resources management problems.

The Strategy aims to achieve a 20 per cent reduction in average salinity levels in the River Murray while providing the opportunity to protect, through drainage and disposal of wastewater, up to 500,000 hectares of land affected by water logging and salinisation. The Strategy complements other market-based measures such as more appropriate water pricing and transferable water entitlements. Since adoption of the Strategy in 1988, over $74 million has been jointly expended on government funded salt interception schemes and joint government and community based drainage and salinity management plans. Major salt interception works have been completed at Woolpunda and commenced at Mallee Cliffs and Waikerie. Drainage programs are being undertaken at Shepparton, Deniliquin and in the Murrumbidgee region.

The Natural Resources Management Strategy (NRMS), now in its fourth year, has become an effective framework for individuals and governments to jointly attack environmental degradation in the Basin. The Natural Resources Management Strategy promotes and sustains activities as widespread and diverse as river management, water quality management, land and vegetation management, and conservation of native flora and fauna and the Basin's cultural heritage.

It is a working example of an integrated regional approach to the sustainable use of natural resources. It has elicited a joint government funding commitment to date of $55 million. The increase in Commonwealth support in this period has been equally impressive, rising from $1.9 million in 1989-90 to $7.6 million for 1992-93, a total of $22 million over the period.

NRMS on-ground works undertaken through the community have been effective in fostering and harnessing community commitment and involvement in the Initiative. More than 200 community groups have received assistance. An ethos for sustainable resource management is taking root across the Basin. It will provide the enduring basis for sound stewardship of the Basin's irreplaceable resources.

The experience gained over the first five years of the Initiative confirms the view that an integrated and co-operative approach to Basin-wide resource and environment management can achieve significantly more than would be possible through independent action by the Commonwealth and States.
The current development of new strategies for irrigation management and water quality management indicates that the Initiative's momentum is continuing.

Sound and responsive water resources management policies are essential to support a viable irrigation industry in the Murray-Darling Basin. Similarly a comprehensive Basin-wide nutrient management strategy is needed to address pollution of the river system. Work on this strategy has been given new impetus following the widespread algal blooms of last summer.

The maturing of the Initiative has led to further refinements of its institutional framework. In 1989, the Ministerial Council commenced a review of the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement to provide for the evolving role of the Council in water, land and environmental management and to allow more efficient implementation of Council decisions.

The Bill before the Parliament contains a number of significant amendments which will further strengthen the Initiative. The inclusion of the Salinity and Drainage Strategy as part of the amended Agreement is foremost among these amendments. This major achievement, a cornerstone of inter-governmental cooperation, has developed to the stage where it can now appropriately be given the backing of legislation.

More efficient allocation of water, essential to the viability and sustainability of irrigated agriculture in the Basin, is also addressed. The amended Agreement provides for water allocation through a system of continuous water accounting. This will allow New South Wales and Victoria to draw on their annual water allocation according to need. Unused allocations will be carried forward as credits; above allocation drawings will be carried forward as a debit against future entitlements. This will facilitate the optimal use of a shared resource without disruption of fundamental access guarantees.

In line with effective program administration and efficiency goals, financial provisions will be revised to allow improved budget management by the Commission. Particular changes include the ability for the Commission, with the approval of Council, to carry-over limited funds from one year to the next. This will allow the Commission to apply its financial resources more flexibly in responding to changing circumstances and needs.

The development of new strategies to meet changing priorities and emphases, against a background of complex economic, environmental and social issues, requires a flexible legislative framework. Accordingly, the amended Agreement empowers the Ministerial Council to modify the Agreement through approving additional Schedules. This will enable, for example, the timely incorporation of new strategies into the Agreement.

With successful passage of this Bill through Parliament, the first Schedule to be brought forward for approval under this process will be one authorising the accession of Queensland to the Initiative. Approximately a quarter of the Basin lies in Queensland, including the headwaters of the Darling River, the major tributary to the River Murray. Queensland's accession will permit a truly Basin-wide perspective to be brought to resource management issues.

The Commission's day-to-day workload is increasing and issues being considered are becoming more complex. The provision for the appointment of an independent President in the Agreement will facilitate strong, ongoing Commission leadership in the development of sound advice to Council and in the implementation of Council decisions.

The Government is confident that the changes to the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement proposed by the Bill before the Senate will strengthen the legislative underpinning of the Initiative and facilitate its forward progress. In this way we can build on the significant achievements to date.

The manner in which the community of the Basin has embraced and adopted the objectives of the Initiative, together with the unprecedented cooperation of all levels of government, is clear evidence of a government and community partnership that can secure the future of the Basin's resources, to the benefit of both the local community and all Australians.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

(c)knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Senators' Interests;
shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly.

2.That statements of the registrable interests of a Senators's spouse or of any dependent children submitted in accordance with paragraph (1) shall be maintained in a separate part of the Register and shall remain confidential to the Committee of Senators' Interests except where the Committee considers that a conflict of interest arises, at which time the Committee may table the declaration.
Registrable interests

3.That the statement of a Senator's registrable interests to be provided by a Senator shall include the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware, of the Senator's spouse and of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and shall cover the following matters:
(a)shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;
(b)family and business trusts and nominee companies:
(i)in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and

(ii)in which the Senator, the Senator's spouse, or a child who is wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, is a trustee (but not including a trustee of an estate where no beneficial interest is held by the Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children), indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust;
(c)real estate, including the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned;
(d)registered directorships of companies;
(e)partnerships, indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership;
(f)liabilities, indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned;
(g)the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments;
(h)saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned;
(i)the nature of any other assets (excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5 000;
(j)the nature of any other substantial sources of income;

(k)gifts valued at more than $500 received from official sources (such sources being an Australian or foreign national, State, provincial or local Government or a person holding an office in such a Government) or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources, provided that a gift received by a Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children from family members or personal friends in a purely personal capacity need not be registered unless the Senator judges that an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist;
(l)any sponsored travel or hospitality received;
(m)being an officeholder of or financial contributor donating over $100 in any single calendar year to any organisation; and
(n)any other interests where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.
Register and Registrar of Senators' Interests
4.That:

(a)at the commencement of each Parliament, and at other times as necessary, the President shall appoint an officer of the Department of the Senate as the Registrar of Senators' Interests and that officer shall also be Secretary of the Committee of Senators' Interests;

(b)the Registrar of Senators' Interests shall, in accordance with procedures determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests, maintain a Register of Senators' Interests in a form to be determined by that Committee from time to time;

(c)as soon as possible after the commencement of each Parliament, the Chairman of the Committee of Senators' Interests shall table in the Senate a copy of the completed Register of Senators' Interests and shall also table every six months any notification by a Senator of alteration of those interests;
(d)the Register of Senators' Interests shall be available for inspection by any person under conditions to be laid down by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time; and
(e)that part of the Register of Senators' Interests relating to spouses and dependent children shall remain confidential to the Committee of Senators' Interests as provided for in paragraph 2.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1987 the government has tried on a number of occasions to bring the Senate up to date by introducing a system for the declaration of interests. The matter has had a very long history and it is now time to resolve it in this chamber, once and for all. Unhappily, in the past, the opposition has resisted the exercise at every opportunity. It has filibustered on the issue until the government has been forced, each time, to return to the business of legislation. We all got sick of the obfuscation and the delay. It will be remembered that in the last sittings we went ahead and tabled our declarations anyway. The Australian Democrats did the same and Senator Chamarette did the same. I think the clear disposition of the majority of honourable senators in this place is to do just that.

PARA.TAB: It is now up to the opposition to show its colours on this fundamental issue of political integrity and we hope that that will occur today. The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, declared his colours, when in a statement on 30 April last year, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have a strong personal disposition in favour of disclosure in government and I support the existing arrangements for the declaration of members interests that operate in the lower House. In short, I have strongly supported a disclosure and have established my bona fides.

One hopes that he will also be able to establish a little more credibly his leadership bona fides by having his will prevail on this issue and get honourable senators opposite to join in the debate on what is an issue of real integrity. It is about time the opposition showed its colours on this issue. Senator Hill has said in the past—this is about all he has said on the issue—that he wants more time to debate the matter. Well, time is available now. I hope he and others will debate it in a constructive and non-filibustering fashion so that we can see this matter resolved.

PARA.TAB: As I said, it is an issue that has a very long history. In 1974 the Whitlam government suggested that there should be public disclosure of the income and assets of parliamentarians. He set up a joint committee which included Mr Killen and Mr Nixon and which recommended unanimously to set up such a register. Mr Whitlam moved a motion to that effect on 6 November 1975 but unhappily that lapsed with the events that followed five days later. Even more unhappily, the Fraser government decided not to proceed with the exercise, notwithstanding its unanimous endorsement on a bipartisan basis before then.

When the Hawke government came into office in 1983, it immediately directed that all ministers, including Senate ministers, declare their interests and those of their immediate families. That practice has been in place ever since. In October 1984, the House of Representatives considered a motion requiring all honourable members to submit statements of pecuniary interests, once in a lifetime of each parliament, within 28 days of making an oath or affirmation as a member of the House.

A committee on members' interests was established to consider the processes involved and its report, among other things, urged the Senate to look also at the issue of the registration of interests. The House adopted its motion in September 1986 and honourable members in the other place have been tabling their returns ever since. On 17 March 1987, I proposed, by motion, a similar system of registration of interests for the Senate. That proposal, I am sad to say, met with objections from the other side and it lapsed with the calling of the July 1987 election.

Just to make the story complete, in November 1988 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Members' Interests rescinded the requirement to declare a relevant interest before speaking in a debate, as it was found to be impractical and unnecessary in the context of the register existing, with those needs being met by the register. I just mention that to honourable senators as perhaps an additional attraction of the register process. The current motion before the Senate does not include the declaration requirement, as it would require alterations to be tabled every six months, as opposed to from time to time as required, which is the form of words applied in the house.

In May last year the government—Senator Button initiating the debate—put the proposal to the Senate again. I am again sad to say that the opposition used the occasion for no more than an opportunity to attack Senator Richardson, and once again the government had to allow the matter to lapse because of pressing legislative business. In May this year, just before the break, through Senator Faulkner we gave notice of this motion that we are now debating today, in order to indicate what was proposed by the government. We adjourned that debate in a substantive way until today, again because of pressure of business.

In May last, we also circulated to all honourable senators a pro forma of a form for registration on a voluntary basis pending the establishment of the formal register. Again I am sad to say that no opposition member complied with that request. All government senators did, and the Australian Democrats and Senator Chamarette did as well. So it really is a matter now of considering whether pecuniary interest declarations are simply a right and proper thing for parliamentarians to do. Members of the house think so, Dr Hewson thinks so, and we on this side of the chamber certainly think so as well.

I will speak quickly about the substantive content of the current motion. The details are before the Senate. Honourable senators have seen what it looks like when translated into the form of a document, which is the one that has been circulated to them. The current motion has been developed bearing in mind some of the concerns that have been raised in previous debates and in all the endless discussion that has gone on in this place in the past. As a result, some modifications have been made to the practice that has been adopted elsewhere. The proposal before the Senate provides, for example, for details relating to spouses and dependent children to remain confidential. It also raises the threshold for declarable gifts to $500, that being the same as the limit which is applied to gifts received by ministers. It also defines, one hopes with some useful precision, the concept of official sources and membership of organisations.

I do not believe it is necessary for me to speak, at this stage of the debate anyway, in any more detail than that. As I have said from the outset, the issue has a long history. It is now time to resolve it. With the amendments to earlier proposals that are now embodied in this motion, I do not believe there is any reasoned basis for the opposition to continue either to oppose the issue or to obfuscate and delay it, which is essentially what it has been doing in the past. We hope that this debate will result finally, at last, after all these years, in a formal endorsement of a system which is fair, which is decent, which I think is regarded in the community as a whole as no less than what people expect of their elected representatives, and which is perfectly workable in practice. I believe, for all those reasons, it should command the support of this chamber.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Senator Evans, I believe you were going to move two motions together. I do not think you have done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I seek leave for government business notice of motion no. 2 to be taken together with this motion.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Can we debate them together?
—No.
—I see; we are having obfuscation, delay and filibuster all over again. Senator Hill will be judged accordingly by the electorate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, this matter has been around for a long time. There is no doubt about that, and the opposition agrees with Senator Evans to that extent. The fact is, however, that it has been around for a long time because the government has never shown any determination to bring it to a conclusion. From time to time it has been politically opportune for the government to raise this issue. It has received the appropriate publicity for doing so, and has then failed to pursue the matter.

PARA.TAB: To say that it has not been resolved in the last 10 years because of a filibuster of the opposition could be recorded as an incredible credit to the power of an opposition which does not have the numbers in this place. At any time in the last 10 years the government could have brought this matter to resolution if that was its purpose and it had any real determination to do so; but it did not do so on any occasion because it was not really interested in the issue.

Last year it started the run again, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sought to place some pressure on the Leader of the Opposition. That got Senator Button to come in here and move his motion again—a motion which, as I said, has been moved every few years for the last decade—but the government showed no interest in pursuing it. It had achieved its political objective of the day and it had no interest in then bringing this matter to a conclusion.

The government does not see that this exercise as genuinely beneficial. Why does it not see it as beneficial? Because the Prime Minister himself—no less than the Prime Minister, the highest elected officer holder in this land—has demonstrated by his own pecuniary interest statement that the process this government has adopted is ineffective. The Prime Minister's interest statement does not demonstrate to the Australian people that he is a half-owner of a massive piggery business or that, as I gather is the case, it is considerably indebted to the Commonwealth Bank. It gives no indication at all of the extent of his investment. It gives no indication as to the fact that apparently he has, through a nominee, the interest of a director in that body. It gives no indication as to the liabilities of that company and a series of subsidiary companies.

It therefore gives no indication to the Australian people whether he may gain as a result of legislation he is dealing with, whether it be banking legislation, legislation concerning AQIS—and the importation of semen was an issue last year for piggeries—or legislation on other rural matters. It is not possible for someone to go to his pecuniary interest statement and determine with any real certainty whether the Prime Minister has a conflict of interests. If it will not work in relation to the Prime Minister, why should this government seek to impose an unworkable system on the whole of the parliament? That has been our concern.

We thought that over the last few months this government would have gone away and redrawn this proposal and put it into a workable form, so that there could be some assurance that pecuniary interest statements are in fact transparent and do demonstrate real interest. But the government did not do it. Why did it not do it? Because it has no interest in the outcome in terms of ensuring that detail of pecuniary interests is on the record. It is simply pursuing a political objective.

Madam Deputy President, Senator Evans has got a nerve to come in here again today, after months in which this Senate has not been sitting, and with a history of lack of interest in the issue, and claim that it is as a result of our opposition that in 10 years this government has not put a pecuniary interests objective into effect in this place. Over the last few months coalition senators have again looked at this matter carefully and seriously, and they still find this proposal objectionable on a number of grounds. The main one is, as I have just said, that it demonstrably does not work. We do not dispute the worthiness of the motive behind establishing a register of interests, which presumably is to increase the confidence of the public in the integrity of its elected representatives.

The parliament cannot prescribe propriety and that is what Senator Evans does not seem to understand. This form of register, even if it were considerably strengthened, would not have the effect of avoiding dishonesty. However, an interesting aspect is that this parliament, generally speaking, can hold its head high in relation to propriety. In the main, the evidence is before us that parliamentarians in this and the other chamber have maintained high standards through the history of this parliament. It is interesting that the government has not come into this place alleging the contrary and therefore saying there is a need.

Firstly, it does not say that there is a need as a result of misbehaviour by parliamentarians and, secondly, it does not put to us a form that could in any way overcome dishonesty if that were to occur. Even if that was its objective, which it does not seem to be and it certainly has not been advanced in those terms by Senator Evans, it does not bring us a form that would be effective in any event. If we go back to the report known as the Riordan report of 1975 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament, we find that it advocated the establishment of a register but it also noted that a register would not be effective in exposing fraud by members of parliament.

In 1978, the Fraser government formed a committee of inquiry concerning public duty and private interests which was chaired by Sir Nigel Bowen. That committee reported the following year and the report expressed grave doubts about whether it would be possible to devise a register so as to eliminate lawful avoidance. The committee considered in detail the arguments for and against compulsory registration of interests and concluded that a register ought not to be introduced.

This decision was influenced by two major considerations. Firstly, however tightly the specifications for a register might be drawn, it would be impossible to list all private interests which would give rise to conflict situations. Secondly, the committee considered that the longer term consequences for office holders' privacy were undesirable. Public registration of interest denies each senator his or her right to privacy. To a great extent, parliamentarians' lives are already open to public scrutiny and, as was noted in the Bowen report, to require the registration of interests is to take the first step down a slippery slope that is likely to lead to a much wider system of disclosure and unjustified invasion of privacy than its first proponents contemplated.

Despite that report, despite the advice of that committee, in 1983 Mr Hawke saw it as politically opportune to urge that a system of public registration of members and senators be introduced. The House of Representatives passed a resolution requiring the registration of members' and ministers' interests. The coalition accepted that ministers' interests ought to be registered. They ought to be because ministers are making executive decisions day by day that concern taxpayers' funds, but the coalition opposed the application of the requirement to ordinary members of parliament.

Let me briefly look at the features of the present proposal that the government puts before us. Firstly, within 14 days of the passage of the resolution each senator must provide to the registrar of senators' interests a statement of their registrable interests and those of their spouses and dependent children. So we are not simply talking about the privacy of members of parliament, we are talking about the privacy of their families. Secondly, any senator who fails to comply or knowingly provides false or misleading information `shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate'.

The statements of spouses and children are to be held in separate parts of the register and are to remain confidential to the committee of senators' interests. The committee may table a declaration where it considers a conflict of interest arises. Of course, the committee will just be a microcosm of the Senate. Registrable interests will include shareholdings in public and private companies; family and business trusts; real estate; directorships; partnerships; liabilities, bonds and debentures; savings and investment accounts; and any other assets valued at over $5,000. The nature of other substantial sources of income, whatever that might mean, is to be listed, as are gifts from official sources valued at more than $500 and gifts valued at more than $100 from other sources. Also included within the statement will be sponsored travel or hospitality received—that presumably means lunch—and any other interests where a conflict of interest could foreseeably arise.

The President of the Senate is to appoint an officer of the Senate as a registrar of senators' interests. That person will also be the secretary of the committee of senators' interests. The chairman of the committee is to table in the Senate a copy of the completed register after the commencement of each parliament. Pursuant to a separate notice of motion, which will be a later debate this day, a committee of senators' interests is to be established at the commencement of each parliament. It will consist of three government senators, two opposition senators and an Australian Democrat or an Independent senator. The minority party in this place—the Australian Labor Party—still believes that it is entitled to have the largest membership of a committee such as this. It is to be set up as a parliamentary committee; it is not something within the province of government. The committee's duties will be to inquire into and report upon the arrangements for the register; to consider proposals about the form and the content of the register; and to consider submissions made in relation to the registering or declaring of interests.

Let me expand upon our reservations, some of which I mentioned a little while ago. First, although this issue has been around a long time, there has been a lack of debate within this place. It really is incredible that this is one of the few occasions, over 10 years, when the government has programmed this matter for serious and full debate in this chamber. Was there consultation with the major parties and the minority parties in this place in relation to the form of the motion? What we saw from Senator Evans in the last parliamentary sittings was really a gimmick. Even though the motions contained obligations upon the Senate to set up this structure, Senator Evans tabled a form that he, or the government, presumably, thought was desirable. He sought to make political capital out of calling upon all senators to comply with his requirements, not a requirement of the parliament.

He could have, if he had chosen to do so, had the matter debated during the last sittings of the parliament. Almost the whole of the first two weeks of that sitting was taken up with matters of procedure initiated by the government. This was not high on the governments order of priority. Yet Senator Evans comes in here today and says that it is a matter of high priority. That has not been demonstrated by the way the government has pursued this matter in the past. The government has not demonstrated good faith. It has been an exercise in political gimmickry, as Senator Evans demonstrated in the last sitting of this parliament. He is once again seeking to treat it as an opportunity for political point scoring.

After hearing Senator Evans talking yesterday about this Senate not giving sufficient time for consideration of the government's legislative program, I find it astonishing that today the government has decided that point scoring on this issue should take priority over that program. No doubt, at the end of this sitting, the government will come in to us and say the guillotine should be applied because there is insufficient time for this chamber to consider its program. This is another demonstration of the distorted priorities of Senator Evans and his government.

There are many other concerns that we have in relation to the form. We are amazed that, for some reason that is not explained by the minister—but subsequent speakers on the other side might fill the gap—the government has removed from this draft the provision for ad hoc declarations which it had included in previous proposals. Notwithstanding the lodgment by a senator of a statement of registrable interests, in previous drafts a senator was to be obliged to declare any relevant interest at the beginning of a speech in the Senate chamber and after a division is called, if they propose to vote in that division.

That has been a principle that we have adhered to on this side of the chamber. We have always accepted that if a senator, who has a conflict of interest, is going to participate in speaking or in voting, then the interest that could be in conflict should be made clear so that the public and the parliament can understand the position of that senator. Why has the government taken out that obligation, that it was going to put in previous proposals, in the draft that is before us today?

We are of a view that if this is to proceed, and the numbers in this chamber seem to indicate that it is, such an obligation should be reinserted, and we have an amendment to that effect. The British Select Committee on Members Interests 1992 report went so far as to observe that `there is a danger that the existence of a register may tempt members into being casual in their observance of the declaration rule'. Then let us put us back in. Let us try to find out from the government what it is seeking to hide. Why did it want that traditional obligation to be removed from its documentation?

If this is to be applied to members of this parliament, we wonder why it is not also to be applied to those who report upon the business of this parliament. One might say they actually have greater influence in many ways than those who participate within the process. The question of the application of disclosure provisions to classes of persons other than parliamentarians has, of course, been raised in the past. I remind honourable senators that the Riordan report in 1975 recommended that the parliament should require those accredited media organisations that enjoy the facilities of Parliament House to comply with the same registration requirements that are required of members of parliament. There are precedents for this and we will be moving amendments later in this debate to extend the application of these disclosure provisions to accredited members of the Canberra press gallery. They will no doubt applaud those amendments because of the high standards that they would like to see of us.

We have concern in relation to the definition of spouse. This is the first proposal in which the government has retreated from the position of requiring full public registration of the interests of spouses and wholly or mainly dependent children. The privacy of members' families is one of the areas of our greatest concern. There is a little more protection in relation to what is put before us, but it is, nevertheless, an invasion of the privacy of spouses and of children. However, if one is to talk of families why is it limited to spouses? Why does it not include de factos? Presumably, it was just a slip. Therefore, we propose to move an amendment to specifically include de facto spouses. I take it that the government will support that amendment when we get to it.

We are concerned about many aspects of the penalties for non-compliance. Paragraph 1, subparagraph (2) of the motion provides that a senator who knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests, or who fails to notify an alteration, or who knowingly provides false or misleading information shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly. Does that bring in the provisions of the Parliamentary Privileges Act or not?

Clearly, the parliament has the power to identify and punish contempts of the Senate, but it is section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act which identifies what is punishable by the courts. The essential element is conduct amounting to improper interference with the functioning of the Senate. It is arguable whether providing false information or failing to provide information would amount to contempt for the purposes of section 4. We believe that it needs to be clarified. We would have thought that even the Australian Democrats would be interested in the issue of penalties because they had previous amendments that specifically raised those issues.

We are concerned as to the confusion between the supervisory role of the new committee that is to be set up and the investigatory role. In fact, it is not clear who should conduct the investigations into alleged breaches—in other words, where senators knowingly misled. We think it is wrong if the ambiguity is to be interpreted in a way such that this new committee should have the responsibility. We think there should be separate bodies because there are separate responsibilities of supervising the structure and carrying out the investigations. If we are to go down this path, and we think there are strong arguments against it, we think it would be better if the Privileges Committee were to conduct the investigations. It is a committee held in high regard and it has longstanding experience. We therefore propose to move an amendment to clarify the situation so that such investigations as are needed to be carried out would be carried out by that committee.

I said some time ago that we have a serious concern that it will not work. It does not provide to the parliament the sort of information that is necessary and which the government would have required it to provide if it were serious. I will mention just a few examples again. A senator has to give information of his or her shareholdings but that does not tell people whether the senator is a major shareholder. It does not tell people whether those shareholdings are of great value or whether they are insignificant.
