The levy would be used to encourage the implementation of education and training in the development of low toxic, chemical-free agricultural production. That just came, by coincidence, from another source. I will be tabling such petitions and asking for legislative action.

This is a big issue. It is an issue that affects an incredible number of Australian people. The government will ignore it to its cost. Last year in this place we set up a new national registration authority. The draft of the legislation defining its operations was to be exposed to public scrutiny last November. We have been told to expect this legislation each month since then. The latest proposed timetable is that it will reach us at the end of August. The authority is to consist of a board of eight people, one of whom is to be a community representative.

One of the questions asked of me during the Newcastle workshop in June related to the function of the community representative. This is to be performed by Mr Don Burke of television fame. The government announced the appointment of Mr Burke with a great deal of fanfare, and probably rightly so. I can assure the government that the `community' of people interested in, and affected by, chemicals is not quite as excited as the minister with that appointment. To that end, I have placed a question on notice seeking information about Mr Burke's program of consultations and how he will go about ensuring that he is capable of acting as a community representative. The government will be well advised to handle that consultative process seriously. If the people who came to our workshop in Newcastle are at all representative of the community, and I believe they are, there is an expectation that meaningful consultation will be high on Mr Burke's agenda.

I close with a simple statement of intention: the use of chemicals is an issue that has a capacity to become a real Pandora's box. For too long it has been swept under the carpet and for too long too many people have been horrendously affected by them. We will continue to be vigilant in our efforts to expose the truth of this whole matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I wish to refer to this afternoon, and I shall deal with them both briefly. That is not, though, to be interpreted as indicating that I have only a brief interest in each matter. I just want to place them on the record.

PARA.TAB: The first matter relates to the outbreak of the disease in Western Samoa called taro blight, which has affected the taro crop in that country. It is a new disease that has not been found in Western Samoa before and it is absolutely devastating for the taro crop. It will have a major impact on the supply of domestic food. As honourable senators would know, the leaf and the corm are a significant part of the diet in Western Samoa.

Not long ago, when I wasin Western Samoa, a young woman I was speaking to about food and diet said to me, amongst other things, `A meal without taro is not a meal'. So the significance of this disease to that country is very great indeed. I understand that, as yet, it is not in the island of Savai'i. I hope that our government will assist in doing whatever it can to make sure that that does not occur. It will have an effect on their exports as well as on domestic consumption.

We have in Australia a man who is an expert on taro blight. Dr Grahame Jackson, who presently resides in the Australian Capital Territory, has worked for some 21 years with the Solomon Islands government as a plant pathologist and is a world-recognised expert in the area of taro blight. I understand that the Australian high commission in Apia has been very involved in talks with the Western Samoan government as to what Australia might do, and the Western Samoan government has sought assistance from us in dealing with the problem.

Clearly, eradication of the disease is something that must be sought, or at least bringing it under control in the short term. I have no doubt that AIDAB and ACIAR are actively involved. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), who is present in the chamber, to raise the matter with Senator Evans and ask those organisations to take every possible step as urgently as possible to assist Western Samoa to deal with this very significant problem that it has. If necessary, perhaps they could arrange for Dr Jackson to visit the country, but at least they could call upon him for all the expertise that he can bring to bear to fight the problem, because it is very grave indeed.

The other matter that I raise, and I am sure honourable senators have heard me mention it previously, is the treatment of Buddhists in Vietnam. The communist government there banned the church in 1981. I have on other occasions mentioned the treatment of some of the monks of the church in that country. I have raised the question of the property and pagodas of the Buddhist congregation having been confiscated by the Vietnamese government and not returned. There have been incidents again recently that I want to refer to briefly, such as the worsening restrictions on the patriarch Thich Huyen Quang. I think that the last or the second last occasion on which I spoke about this was when there were problems about the funeral of the previous patriarch. In June and July of this year 36 monks were arrested. There is also the matter of the continuing claim against the Unified Vietnamese Buddhist congregation.

It was 30 years ago in June of this year—and many of us will remember the photographs—that a 66-year-old monk drove to Saigon and set himself on fire in a crowded street to protest against the repression of Buddhism in that country. In a sense, it has been a bit like that ever since. I know that Senator Evans has previously taken up the matter of the execution and detention of monks. I know that the Australian embassy in Vietnam has been involved. With the latest escalation in this sort of activity against the Buddhist church I would ask Senator Evans again to ask the Australian embassy in Vietnam to prepare a report on what is happening and let us know whether there are any signs that freedom of religion will be allowed to operate in that country.
I want to refer briefly to part of an article in the Far Eastern Economic Review of 5 August of this year written by Murray Hiebert in Hanoi. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Just when Hanoi's communist rulers thought they had quelled a Buddhist rebellion in central Vietnam, a new row has erupted in the southern part of the country. The later clash culminated in the 9 July arrest of superior monk Thich Hanh Duc, head of the Son Linh pagoda near the southern port city of Vung Tau. He and a number of supporters were detained for `creating social disorder.'
It went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Many observers believe this incident marks an escalation of the conflict between the government and supporters of the fiercely independent Unified Buddhist Church, which Hanoi banned in 1981 . . . The dissidents are demanding the right to re-establish their old church, the release of detained monks and the return of pagodas confiscated by the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Evans again to ask the embassy in Hanoi to prepare a report on what is happening and to make representations to the government on the matter of freedom of religion, particularly in relation to those under detention at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about an urgent and desperate matter—the federal funding of a technical and further education college project in my own city of Adelaide. An impasse is potentially developing which will be to the great disadvantage of my state and the great disadvantage of vocational students, those current and those for many years to come, if certain proposals are now adopted. It is to safeguard against this disaster that I speak, partly on behalf of the chairman of the college council of the pre-eminent TAFE college in my state, now called an institute of vocational education. It is the Adelaide, or the college at Light Square.

PARA.TAB: I draw my remarks, particularly through the Senate and the parliamentary secretary who is on duty, to the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) and to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free). In these matters, the ministers can understand the problem I am about to address and I ask for their very careful consideration and for their not going ahead with the disaster that is proposed. I also alert the Department of Employment, Education and Training that I will seek to pursue this matter in the estimates process in the coming few weeks and will want very careful answers.

What had happened, until a few weeks ago, was a very responsible planning process for the institute of vocational education in Adelaide for the fifth stage of its capital development. The plan was an extension to its current modern and very practical campus by the demolition of some old buildings that had been bought for the purpose and the erection of a distinctly purpose-built structure with appropriate rooms and facilities that were to be totally integrated with the existing building in the centre of Adelaide. It was to include a child care centre which has been much wanted for many years by the thousands of students that come to this vocational education institute.

It was to include a hospitality training program instead of that program being in an old hotel which, for more than a century, had been on this site. It would be demolished and there would be an appropriate dual facility—teaching and serving facility—for hospitality students of this college. There would be an appropriate number of rooms for a wide range of courses immediately accessible to the existing campus. This proposal was well developed, with proper consultation, with the plans exhibited for all the public to see. It has been in process and has been approved by the Commonwealth government and $19.7 million has been set aside for it this financial year. Tenders have been called and tenders received.

At the 11th hour the state government of South Australia has put a spoke in the wheel. It has proposed that the whole process might be shut down and, instead, a redundant office building on the other side of Adelaide might be adapted for use for the purposes of this extension to the vocational institute. It is an existing 11-storey building that is distant from the campus. It was custom built as a commercial or city office building and is essentially a series of 11 floors with a few toilets per floor, a foyer and a lift, instead of the precisely designed building set out in the plans and approved by the Commonwealth.
I seek leave to incorporate a letter from the president of the institute, addressed to the State minister.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The document read as follows—
27th July 1993
Minister of Education, Employment and Training
Dear Minister
Stage 5 Development, Adelaide Institute of Vocational Education

I am most concerned to learn that the proposed Stage 5 development for the Adelaide Institute has been dropped in place of a proposal to purchase an office building in Chesser Street, Adelaide. At my request, I accompanied the Leasing Agents on a tour of the proposed site this morning and as a result, seriously doubt that the building could be adapted to an educational facility.
I regret that again the Minister has not consulted with the Institute Council on a very major decision concerning the Institute.

However, I am more concerned about the impact this proposal will have on the Adelaide Institute. I am sure that you appreciate that the Adelaide Institute is one of the most outstanding technical and vocational educational institutions in Australia. It has a reputation for innovative, leading edge technology and for enthusiastic, cooperative and very hardworking staff. The Institute has developed an excellent reputation which goes well beyond the State border. The number of international visitors who request a visit to the Adelaide Institute (and visit no other organisation in Australia) is extraordinarily high and is growing dramatically.

I was pleased to meet with you at the luncheon you hosted at Adelaide for the Malaysian Minister of Education. The Minister is a prime example of the foregoing. His visit was an outstanding success because he was able to hear about, and see on video, various aspects of the Institute. He then asked to visit a department and was able to quickly walk to that department to see in practice, the methodology discussed earlier.

As technology develops internationally, we envisage a growth in the international market for the export of courses and technology from the Adelaide Institute. The physical difficulties of coordinating staff split between two campuses in order to achieve this development will quickly mitigate against any future developments. I suggest that splitting the campus will cause many operational problems.

I am sure that your Government is only too aware of the export potential that the Adelaide Institute has realised through SAGRIC and the future that this represents. A hasty decision now could cost the State significant export revenue.

The proposal to relocate a large section of the Institute in a tower building which was designed for a completely different purpose has the potential to rip the heart out of the Adelaide Institute. It will destroy the opportunity for rapid and effective interaction between staff and will remove the opportunity for innovative, creative and productive interaction which has resulted in the sort of organisation of which your Government should be proud. I believe that the proposal, if it proceeds, will destroy the critical mass of the institution.

I also question whether the building could be adapted to conform to requirements of the Occupational Health and Safety Act because of the lack of facilities available to service the number of people occupying each floor.
From an economic viewpoint—
.we will have to provide an additional level of student services at the Chesser Street site
.we will have to duplicate the already stretched facilities of the Learning Resource Centre
.operating costs for a building constructed entirely of glass with a north facing aspect
.impact on existing cafeteria lease within the Adelaide campus (contract/lease is based on certain income expectations)
.relocation costs
.cost in conveying materials between the two campuses
and other difficulties too numerous to list at this point.

One of the major outcomes of the Stage 5 development as it was currently planned was to enable the Institute to provide weekend service for students and child care facilities. This will not now be possible if the proposed development goes ahead without significant increase in recurrent and capital expenditure costs.
On behalf of the Institute Council, I extend an invitation for you to meet with members of the Council to discuss the proposal before any decision is made.
Yours sincerely,
ALISON RAGGATT
President

TALK.START.PARA: —The two-page letter which has just been incorporated is from Alison Raggatt, who has been for many years the honorary president of the TAFE college which is now the Adelaide Institute of Vocational Education, and is a real plea from the heart. I fully support her concerns and I support the concerns of her council members. She has not been consulted, her council has not been consulted and the state government has intercepted a Commonwealth grant already approved for use for an exact purpose at that particular institution. Her letter speaks for itself but I will highlight a couple of points.

PARA.TAB: This institute has the highest standing amongst all the like institutes in Australia internationally. That reputation will be compromised if there is this splitting of the campus. There is an enormous growth momentum happening, to the great advantage of the citizens of South Australia and to the revenue of my state from international students coming in, because it is such a well-designed institute—I have seen its brochures that have set out for any comer the advantages of a well-designed campus—and it gives courses at the very best level. This will be compromised. How can anyone boast about a completely irrelevant design of an ordinary office building on the other side of town?

It is the judgment of the council that the office building cannot be adapted—it is impossible to adapt it—for the use of the thousands of students that this facility is otherwise intended for. For instance, there are glass windows on every floor, yet there are word processors with computer screens that are to be used and it is important to have the light right. There are only four toilets per floor for what would be 200 students per floor if it were used to the extent that has been designed.

It is, in any event, a split campus. There are extra costs to adapt it even for minimal use by this institute. Those costs are estimated at $10 million. Not only would there be the spending of the money on the wrong project up front; there would be the cost of having to adapt it and then there would be further, recurrent costs because of the split campus. Also, the weekend service for students—one of the aims of this project—and the child care facilities would have to be abandoned. Yet this is the deliberate concern not only of the council of that institute but of the students over many years now.
I seek leave to incorporate also a press release of 29 July 1993 by my colleague the leader of the state parliamentary party, Mr Dean Brown.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Media Release
Liberal Leader, Dean Brown
TAFE Deal to Add $10m to State Bank Bill
The Arnold Government has told the Adelaide College of TAFE to spend $19m to buy a Grenfell Street property currently owned by the Bad Bank.
The property will cost an additional $8m to $10m to use as a TAFE College.
This sleazy deal is outrageous. It is another example of SA Inc at its worst.

The Minister of Education, Employment and Training, Ms Lenehan, has directed the Adelaide College of TAFE to buy the property, despite the administrative and other problems which will result from splitting the campus like this.
In doing so, the Government is attempting to make the Bad Bank's books look as good as possible before the election.
At the same time, it wants to leave the next Liberal Government with the additional bill to re-furbish the Grenfell Street property.
The $19m to purchase the property is Federal funding originally approved for extensions and re-furbishment of facilities on the Light Square Campus of Adelaide TAFE.
This Stage 5 of Adelaide TAFE could have been completed for $19m.
However, the Government's decision that Adelaide TAFE should buy the Grenfell Street property will add up to $10m to the cost to taxpayers.
The Grenfell Street property is totally incompatible with plans that Adelaide TAFE had for its extensions.
It is a largely glass building when much of the work being undertaken at the College involves the use of computer screens and videos.
There are only four toilets on each floor of the building yet they will have to cater for well over 200 students per floor.

The Adelaide College of TAFE has a national and international reputation for the quality of its courses and it is deplorable that the Government should now make the College a pawn in its increasingly desperate attempts to hide the true cost of the State Bank's losses before the election.
This decision also will be a blow to the construction industry which is very short of major contracts at present.
However, the Government is locked into this deal because it has recently paid $7m to purchase the land on which the Grenfell Street properly is built.
The property, Chesser House, at 91 Grenfell Street, was built by the West Australian Pennant Group as a speculative development.
I understand the State Bank had an exposure of well over $40m to the Pennant Group—most of it on account of Chesser House.
Accordingly, not only are taxpayers going to foot the bill on the Bank's losses from this property speculation, they will also pay the bill to refurbish Chesser House.
At a time when many people cannot get into TAFE courses, it is absolutely unacceptable for the Government to be doing deals like this.
Other examples of the Government using more taxpayers' money to bail out bad State Bank property deals include—
.the E&WS moving into the empty Australis Centre in Grenfell Street (the E&WS also has one floor in Chesser House at present)
.the move of WorkCover into the Waymouth Building
.the move of the MFP Corporation and the Tourism Commission into the Remm Centre
.the Government's purchase of a part of the East End Market site
For further information contact Kevin Donnellan on 237 9391

TALK.START.PARA: —This press release also speaks for itself. I have not been in direct consultation with my good friend Dean Brown in this matter but I am aware of his and his party's concern that this is broader than what I know to be the case in what I have said up to this point. Dean Brown adds an extra dimension. He is looking to a successful win in this coming state election in my state.

PARA.TAB: That election might be held in November. I hope it is held as soon as possible, because we want to see a change of government in South Australia. One of the reasons why the present government deserves to be completely rejected and thrown out of office is the State Bank fiasco. The State Bank has left a debt of more than $3 billion on the heads of the citizens of the state. Among the assets that were left over from credit that was extended and that went bad in the hands of the State Bank, and that were therefore passed on to the state government, was this building called Chesser House, on the corner of Chesser Street and Grenfell Street. The building was an unwise investment by some Western Australian interests, but involved State Bank of South Australia money. It has never been used, and is a white elephant and which the state government has on its hands.

The state government wants to use the Commonwealth's $19.7 million to reduce the book debt it will have when it faces the public in the coming election, and then leave an incoming alternative government to pick up the pieces and try to serve the interests of technical and further education—and, indeed, the present and future interests of those who come to this institute of vocational education. Therefore I draw particular attention to the fourth, fifth and sixth paragraphs of Dean Brown's apt press release. Mr Brown says:

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, it wants to leave the next Liberal Government with the additional bill to re-furbish the Grenfell Street property.

He also talks about the practical problems: about the splitting of the campus and the inability to adapt the building. This is the accusation that is made by a responsible leader of the opposition in the state parliament. I believe that even if this were shown in some debate to be not fully founded, on the grounds of my earlier remarks about the completely inadequate aspects of the proposed building it is sufficient that no shift be made and that the campus not be split in the way that is proposed.

PARA.TAB: I finally wish to refer to the statement issued on the same day as the press release from my colleague Dean Brown by the minister responsible in the state government, the Labor minister Susan Lenehan. She made this press statement, still without any consultation with that institute of education. I note three things. First, she confirms that no decision has been made on this matter. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no decision made yet on exactly how the $19.7m allocated by the Commonwealth Government for construction of Stage 5 of the Adelaide Institute of Vocational Education will be spent.
She confirms that there is a proposal under consideration. I want her and the state government to announce that this proposal was ill-founded, that it is dismissed, and that stage 5 can go ahead.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, she confirms that there was no consultation with the college council, but she does make the promise that at some stage in the future it will be consulted. That is some consolation. Thirdly, she notes that were there to be this change, the Commonwealth would have to approve it. The state government cannot just intervene and get away with either the shonky rewriting of some State Bank debt or the inappropriateness of this facility. The Commonwealth would have to approve it.

That is why I appeal directly to ministers Beazley and Free and to their department to ensure that this decision is soundly made and that there is a rejection of any state government request from South Australia that would compromise the facility to the people of my state. It is clear that the minister has in fact caused a delay, because she has withdrawn the demolition order on the College Arms Hotel which was to clear the way for stage 5. So it is on hold, to the great tragedy of this college and of my state. I ask the ministers of the Commonwealth government to ensure that this whole fiasco is ended now and that the college can get on with the tenders that it has received to build stage 5 as planned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent days, and in the more distant past, we have heard in this chamber the words `mandate', `representation' and `accountability'. There has been a great deal of discussion and comparison between the Senate and the House of Representatives with respect to the way in which legislation is dealt with. As recently as yesterday we heard a great deal of discussion around the motion dealing with the timing of the introduction of bills into the Senate. Many people built arguments around this notion of mandate—what party had a mandate to what—and the idea of accountability back to the public.

PARA.TAB: This bears very much on the issue of the form of election which we have for the two Houses. I think most senators, looking dispassionately at the way the Senate operates, would agree that the Senate indeed operates as a house of review and that, since no party has held the numbers in this place to simply slam legislation through on numbers alone, this place has operated as a proper, representative and accountable chamber. With that in mind, I was particularly interested to see the report, in March 1993, by the Proportional Representation Society of Australia in relation to the 1993 elections. The society states:

SPEECH.PARA: The elections for Australia's House of Representatives resulted in the ALP and the Coalition each receiving less than 45% of the first preference vote.

Based on that, one can argue that neither the ALP nor the coalition alone have a mandate to do anything. They require an additional vote from somewhere to represent more than 50 per cent of Australians. Its report continues:
The ALP percentage exceeded that of the Coalition by only 0.66 percentage points, yet the ALP's share of the seats exceeded that of the Coalition by 10.20 percentage points.

In other words, the method of election in the House of Representatives resulted in an unfair, excessive proportion of seats in the House of Representatives compared with the number of votes which were actually first preference votes which were cast for the ALP. It is something on which the opposition should give some consideration. The society's report continues:
If the PRSA's recommended Hare-Clark system of multi-member divisions with PR had applied, the ALP would have had 74 seats and the Coalition 72—

a much closer result, which would have been far more reflective of the actual percentage of votes cast for the two groups. The society said that of those 72 seats for the coalition, the Liberals would have 61 seats and the Nationals, 11. They said that the remaining seat would have been taken by an Australian Democrat in South Australia. It further stated:

This would have allowed the ALP Government to continue in office with an absolute majority of seats, but would have ensured that its activities and proposals, and those of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition—
a term which we heard frequently yesterday—
could receive at least the minimum possible scrutiny and questioning by interests other than just the two standard alternators in power.

The society pointed out that, significantly, the one member of the House of Representatives that a proportional representation system would have elected would have been an Australian Democrat from South Australia, and that person would have been elected by virtue of a substantial quota of 66,842 votes of which 41,367 votes were first preference votes for the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: By contrast, the present system of election for the House of Representatives elected Mr Ted Mack by virtue of an absolute majority of only 37,542 votes, of which only 27,834 votes were first preference for him. Likewise, Mr Phil Cleary's absolute majority was only 35,218 votes, of which only 20,721 were first preferences for him. I make these few remarks at lunchtime today to point out that the method of election for the House of Representatives is unrepresentative, as shown by those figures and quite contrary to what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has disparagingly said of the Senate—that we are unrepresentative swill. I point out again that the Senate is a far more representative chamber, precisely because of the method of election, and that consequently we are the proper parliamentary and democratic house in this parliament.

I stress those figures to the opposition. If we had had a PR system for election to the House of Representatives, at the last election the opposition would have had 72 seats, compared with 74 seats for Labor. The result would have been a great deal closer and the pressure on this government, which I think everybody in here would agree would be highly desirable, would certainly have been increased. I think the opposition should give serious consideration to the proposal which the Democrats have before this parliament. We have had on our books for a long time the notion that we should go to a system of multi-member electorates with proportional representation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate some very great concerns relating to one of the growth industries in Victoria—the Victorian wine industry—and its concerns about the impact of the budget on its prospects and employment in the industry. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that there is very widespread concern in the community today about the broken promises of the Labor government. Everyone would be aware that Mr Keating went to the election promising time and time again that there would be no tax increases. He indicated that the income tax cuts which he had promised would be delivered in full and would not be funded by rises in other taxes.

PARA.TAB: It is true to say that on the Labor back bench there is very great concern about the tax increases which have come through in this budget. Senator Chris Evans from Western Australia, I am happy to see, is in the chamber today. He will be able to relate to the Senate, when he makes his maiden speech, the importance of the wine industry in that great state of Western Australia. I wonder whether Senator Christopher Evans can tell us whether, when he went around and campaigned during the election and undoubtedly met some of the wine producers, he gave any assurances to the wine producers that there would be no tax increases on their product. But Senator Chris Evans will have to speak for the industry in Western Australia and I hope that he will join his colleagues on the back bench who are in revolt over this budget.

I do not say that all members of the Labor Party have the same appallingly low standards as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I guess that people like Senator Chris Evans, when they made promises based on the Labor Party platform, believed that those promises would be kept. They now have a duty to ensure that the commitments that they made in the election are brought to the attention of the Prime Minister and that it is made clear to the Prime Minister in no uncertain manner that those promises are meant to be kept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Free themselves from the deceit.

—That is it exactly. The election has clearly been won by a massive deceit. I guess that, having made all these promises, they are feeling now that an election has been stolen and the Labor Party's name has been besmirched by the actions of the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: My purpose in rising today is to discuss the wine industry in Victoria. I have had the opportunity of speaking to the Victorian Wine Industry Association and have listened to its very great concerns about the impact that this massive rise in taxes will have on its industry. In my home state there are some 230 winemakers and many of those are planning major investments as the wine industry is one of those sectors of the Victorian economy which has really been targeted as a growth sector, certainly in terms of the export markets that we see opening up to wine production. Of course, as people know, the wine industry also has important effects on the tourism industry and particularly on employment in the rural sector.

So it is an important industry. It is an important industry in my home state and it is an industry which we see as one of the growth sectors. As a result of this promise broken by the Keating government, we are now seeing some of these prospects of the industry cast into doubt. I bring to the attention of the Senate, and particularly Labor Party backbenchers, the concerns of the Victorian wine industry. There are two Labor Party seats in Victoria which have a large wine sector and those are the seat of McEwen and the seat of Burke. The member for McEwen is Mr Cleeland and the member for Burke is Mr O'Keefe. I would like those two particular individuals but also people like Senator Chris Evans and others who come from wine growing states to be very aware of the impact that these tax changes on the wine industry will have on the growth of that important sector.

The Victorian Wine Industry Association will be making a press release later today in which it strongly condemns the federal government's budget, particularly the sales tax hike from 20 per cent to 31 per cent. This is what the Victorian Wine Industry Association says:

SPEECH.PARA: A 55 % increase in sales tax from 20 % to 31 % at this absolutely critical moment in the development of the Australian wine industry is more than simply ill-considered and regressive. It is in fact a savage counter attack on one of Australia's and Victoria's truly internationally competitive and successful export industries . . .
Victoria's 230 winemakers are angry and perplexed by the Treasury's vicious assault.
The wine industry has clocked up the following remarkable achievements in recent years;
1. Developed a unified national structure and strategy
2. Achieved 38 months of consecutive growth in export sales
3. Committed itself to seeking $1.2 billion of investment capital over the next five years in order to achieve its $1 billion export sales target
4. Developed `a leadership role' for Australian agriculture and manufacturing industry via its vertically integrated, value-adding, technologically-pre-eminent practices
and
5. Highlighted the relationship between wine exports and international tourism.
The press release continues:
And yet the federal government (despite exhorting Australian companies to do all these things) has chosen to penalize the wine industry for being successful.
That is a statement by its president, Mr Shelmerdine. Mr Shelmerdine says:

The Prime Minister has clearly been completely misinformed about the wine industry . . . The Treasurer is perversely taxing away our great natural advantages. Our international competitors—Chile, South Africa and Eastern Europe—are celebrating tonight . . .
That is because of the tax increase on wine which the Prime Minister imposed, quite contrary to the specific promises that he made during the last federal election. Mr Shelmerdine continues:
The mantle of government leadership and encouragement for Australian winemakers has now passed to the state governments of Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales.
Victorian winemakers are fortunate to have a state government committed to the full tourist, technical and economic development of the wine industry.
The federal government have cynically abdicated their responsibility to the thousands of independent grape growers and small and medium sized family wine companies in rural Victoria.
This tax grab must be rescinded at once.
He concludes:
Regrettably, it is yet another example of Canberra bureaucrats' complete insularity from an insensitivity to the real, hard world of winegrape growing, winemaking and international marketing.

I have brought to the attention of the Senate just one example of the adverse consequences that this budget will have on a particular sector of the economy. I dare say that we will see, as we go right through various sectors of the Australian economy, similar perverse results. They are the result of the Prime Minister breaking his election promises.

PARA.TAB: I know that the wine industry, and the Victoria wine industry, will be making their views very firmly known to the government, to the Labor members of parliament and to the Labor senators. It is certainly my intention to make sure that their particular concerns are properly and fully addressed by the government. This matter raises the wider issue that has been before this chamber now for a number of days since the budget: what value does one put on the price of a Labor promise these days? Is there anything so worthless in the community as the word of our Prime Minister? Let us face it, Mr Keating will say anything and do anything in order to win a short-term political advantage. As one journalist wrote in a newspaper today, the very currency of political debate in this country has been demeaned by the Prime Minister.

Senator Sherry, who is in the chamber, and Senator Chris Evans went around the electorate making promises and saying that there would be no tax rises. The test is now on them to see whether their word is worth more than the word of the Prime Minister. They had the chance to stand up in their party room and defend the promises that they made and which they were elected on. They had the chance to stand up and make it clear to the Prime Minister that, no matter how lowly and cynically he might hold the value of his own word to be, they held their promises dear. If those two senators do not do that, the community will take note that, in future, a Labor promise will not be worth the paper it is written on or the policy statement it appears in. The Labor Party will suffer very serious consequences as a result.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments about the latest development in the never-ending saga of satellite pay television licences. If we were to take our cue from the two ministers who have nominal responsibility in this area, we would not be any the wiser; indeed, we would probably be thinking that this matter was simply being negotiated administratively in some way. The reality is that we have now reached the point of absurdity where the fourth deadline has passed—with a deafening silence from both communications ministers! The process is still in free-fall and we have no early prospect of identifying any successful bidders.

PARA.TAB: If we go back to 1 May last, just after the first deadline had expired and applications had closed, we find that it took about five minutes flat for Mr Beddall to get up and say that not only had UCOM and Hi Vision won the bids but that $389 million was on the table. He said that this ushers in a new era in Australian television. If, by that, he meant that there would be a new era of unprecedented ministerial incompetence, he was absolutely right. He also said that he was not surprised at the size of the bids; that he had always thought the price could be much higher than other people thought. I do not know whom he has been talking to, but these days there is not anyone who would put up his or her hand to say that these prices were anywhere near reasonable. Indeed, most people would say that the market price is less than half the bid of either UCOM or Hi Vision.

He said that he was perfectly relaxed about that outcome and asked why he would not be if he could say to Ralph Willis, `Here is $389 million to help you with the budget deficit'. The fact is that, if honourable senators look at the budget papers, they will find no mention at all of proceeds from licence sales in respect of these licences. Are we meant to conclude from that that a few months ago the government was so confident and these ministers were so deluded that they were able to boast about having got $389 million for Treasury coffers and now they are so lacking in confidence and so totally out of touch that they are not even prepared to put $1 into the budget by way of revenue provision?

This matter has reached an extraordinary level of incompetence. One can only say that Senator Collins has been acting like a water buffalo frozen in the spotlight. If the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who fancies himself as being a man of great political courage, were prepared to summon up enough courage to sack Senator Collins, it would be the biggest dope bust of the decade. It is worth remembering the sort of bravado that Senator Collins constantly goes on with and how each and every time he falls flat on his face.

I want to refer to one of his more recent efforts, when he told the Northern Territory News on 2 August last—only a matter of a couple of weeks ago—that he was confident that the imposition of the five per cent deposit requirement would sort out the winning bids. The fact is that that was only a couple of weeks ago. Nothing has happened since that time, except that we have seen further bids fall over. There is absolutely no prospect of any end in sight to this circus. Quite clearly, both Senator Collins and Mr Beddall have chosen to say nothing on each occasion because they have absolutely nothing to say. They are acutely embarrassed.

They were under no obligation to nominate the successful bids and bidders several months ago but they chose to do so. They did so because they thought there was political mileage in it. They thought they were very clever in being able to identify new players paying top dollar. In fact, all we have discovered is that those bids were totally unrealistic. With hindsight we know that neither of those bidders had any serious intention, let alone prospect, of being able to become long-term players at that level. They are simply cascading down because the government has allowed that process to occur.

Given all the sound and fury that we had from Senator Collins, it seems extraordinary that he has not taken the very simple measure that has been advocated by many in the industry, and that is to require all remaining bidders to put five per cent on the table immediately. That would sort out the sheep from the goats, or the water buffalos from the rest. In one fell swoop, he would be able to bring this process to a halt. But instead he lets it drag agonisingly on so that we keep going through these never-ending cascades of bids, making Australia an international laughing-stock and ensuring that Senator Collins goes down in history as the most incompetent communications minister the country has ever had.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am provoked into speaking today by the continuing litany of deceit that is unveiling before us as we see the breaking of promise after promise of the newly elected `sweetest victory of all' Australian Labor Party government here in the federal capital. The budget has been a disgrace. It has also been a budget that has hurt many individuals. Most of us are reminded of that every day when we drive to this building in Commonwealth cars, whose drivers are yet a small example of people who have been deceived by the federal government, by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and by ministers in relation to the security of their employment.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth car drivers, along with many other public servants in Canberra and around Australia, were told, `Watch out. Don't vote for the Liberal Party at this election because there will be massive sackings. You will all lose your jobs and you will lose all your benefits and entitlements. So don't vote for those nasty, horrible Liberals. Stay with us. We'll look after you. She'll be right. You'll be comfortable'. But what happens only a few short months after the sweetest victory of all, the true believers' victory, is that we see the employment security of thousands upon thousands of federal public servants threatened. I think the saddest thing about that—the very, very sad thing—is that these people were lied to, they were deceived by this federal government and, worse still, they were just unable to plan their futures because of this deceit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is absolutely disgraceful.

—As Senator Kemp says, it is quite disgraceful. What is amazing is that this nation is now being governed by a government that had very little idea that it was likely to win the last election. It came in after winning that sweetest victory of all and had little idea of what it was going to do with the term that it never thought it was going to get. It is very sad to see what it is doing to innocent Australians, who very foolishly believed this Prime Minister, his ministers, the Labor Party and the candidates.

PARA.TAB: I was provoked into speaking today because I was reading through what I think is an exceptional document prepared by my close friend and colleague Senator Amanda Vanstone, from South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it got tanks all over it?

—No, it has not got tanks but I recommend it to Senator Sherry. I might even seek leave to table it but I probably would not get leave. This publication is entitled `Labor's Election Lulus'. I guess that is parliamentary language, Mr Acting Deputy President—it does not say `lies' or `dishonesty'; it says `election lulus'. Senator Vanstone has put this together after a process of broad consultation with coalition members and honourable senators throughout Australia. Senator Vanstone said, shortly after the federal election in those most depressing days for those of us on this side of the house, that she would like us to send to her examples of outrageous claims made by Labor Party people during the campaign. One was made by one of Senator Evans's former state secretary colleagues, Mr Wayne Swan, now MP. This excellent document should really become a document of the Senate but I might send it across to Senator Sherry so he can have a look at it. Page 26 of the document shows Mr Wayne Swan as having said during the campaign, in a direct mail letter to residents of the seat of Lilley—those poor people who again have been deceived by this man—`Under Dr Hewson women will have to wait five more years to qualify for the pension'. That may or may not have been true.
—It wasn't!

—Of course it was not true. There was an incremental increase, as Senator Panizza has said. But the fact of the matter is that Wayne Swan went around scaring the women in the electorate of Lilley by saying that to qualify for the pension they would have to wait another five years. Many of these women in the seat of Lilley, in Queensland, very good citizens of Australia I am sure, probably believed Mr Swan when he said that Dr Hewson was going to do that. They probably thought also that Mr Swan was implying that the Prime Minister and the Labor Party would not put up the qualifying age for pensions by five years if the women were to vote for Mr Swan.

PARA.TAB: The very saddest thing is that many of these women who voted for Mr Swan would have been absolutely shocked on Tuesday night, when they heard the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, to find that what Mr Swan stated the nasty Liberals would do in the budget has indeed been inflicted upon them by Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would Senator Sherry say was the length of the list of lies now? It must be growing.

—In response to Senator Kemp's interjection and in relation to the size of this list of, let us say, `lus'—I would not dare use such an unparliamentary word as `lies'—or election lulus, Senator Vanstone has made the point that it is almost a physical, practical impossibility to now create a document that lists all of those broken promises. As Senator Vanstone says, it would be probably a good thing that we could not put together a list of that size, because we would need a hydraulic trolley to move the document from one place to another. Indeed, it would be impossible to table it because, even though we have a very sturdy table here in this place, it would not stand the weight of a document of the size that was put together to document all of Labor's promises broken in such a short time.

PARA.TAB: But I will finish on a serious note. I recently read a very good article, which I commend to honourable senators, in the Economist magazine of two or three weeks ago, which analysed what was a very serious issue—that is, the use of the lie in politics. It is a document I may refer to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the author Paul Keating?

—No, it was not. But I will suggest, in a letter to the editor of the Economist, that he sends the correspondent—and those senators who read the Economist magazine will know that the correspondents to the Economist are anonymous—to Australia to do further research on this important issue: the use of the lie in politics down through the ages. In Australia in the last couple of months we have seen it perfected by this government, which was prepared to cheat and lie to the people of Australia in order to get re-elected. Again, on this serious note, I repeat to Senator Panizza, this very sad thing. We see every day when we come into work in our Commonwealth cars that good citizens of Australia—public servants in particular; and Senator Reid, who represents many of them here as a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, is entering the chamber—have been deceived. They have been cheated. They have had their lives and their security disrupted and disturbed by a government that, only a few months ago, was prepared to look them in the eye and say, `If you are a public servant, do not vote for nasty Dr Hewson because you will lose your job'.

PARA.TAB: A couple of months later, here we are debating the federal budget, and there are thousands of these federal public servants who will now have trouble sleeping at night. They will be worried about their future; their retirement; and the future and the financial security of their children. That is very sad. It is very sad for Australian politics that the art of saying one thing and doing the other is now a confirmed part of Australian political practice and has been raised to a disgraceful level by senators opposite and their colleagues in the other place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are just a couple of matters that I wish to respond to. Senator Teague requested that I bring to the attention of the federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) the matters he raised about a college in his state that has allegedly been adversely affected in respect to some funding, and that I will do.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter, in reflecting on debate that occurred earlier in this place about cut-off dates for legislation, made me think about some comments by one of his fellow colleagues in the Australian Democrats. I think it was Senator Spindler who suggested that one of the major problems for lengthy debate in this place is repetition. I certainly believe that if we could overcome some of the repetition problems and people truly debated, rather than coming into the Senate simply to give a speech and then leaving again, we might save some time.

Senator Kemp referred to the wine industry. I am sure we are going to be debating the effect of the budget on the wine industry on a number of occasions in this place. He did have the temerity to suggest that Senator Chris Evans, who was in the Senate at the time, should address this matter in his first speech. I would suggest to Senator Kemp, who is still in the Senate, that the first speech content is a matter for the senator to decide, not for him to suggest. I hope, but I am sure, given Senator Kemp's past record, that he will be here to listen to a very good speech from Senator Chris Evans when he gives his first speech.

Senator Alston referred to the ongoing concerns he has with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) and some concerns over licence bidding. Senator Collins is still the minister. He is here in the Senate and Senator Alston is still in opposition. He is still raising the same issue day after day, month after month, and Senator Collins is still handling the issue with great tact and diligence and still handling that issue very well.

Finally, Senator Campbell introduced us to a new terminology for a lie; lulus. It is an interesting new piece of terminology. I must confess I do not know whether it is unparliamentary or not; I will check to see. I was not sure, so I did not spring to my feet and demand that it be withdrawn. I think the accusation, that we would need a hydraulic lift to list documents containing alleged breaches of promise by this government, is a slight exaggeration, particularly given the honourable senator was waving this document around by hand. He must have some hydraulic muscles on his arms. Either that or he is doing some work in the gym that I have missed out on in the last year or two.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a distinguished member of the Victorian parliament, the Hon. Mark Birrell, the Minister for Conservation and Environment and the Minister for Major Projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that since February 1992 the government promised that it could match the coalition's tax cut pledge without any increase in tax, given that it perpetrated this lie throughout the 1993 election campaign, and given that the Prime Minister has admitted that he and the Treasurer agreed less than a week after the election that they could not honour their tax cut promise in full, how can anyone believe them when they now promise no new taxes for four years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill is obviously not the sort of person from whom one could buy a used prime ministerial statement. I say that because he has completely misquoted the line used by the Prime Minister in the Lateline interview of 19 November, when he did say, `What I am promising is not to put up tax'. What the Prime Minister said in the immediately preceding sentence was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: To maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment. In other words, what I'm promising is not to put up tax.

So the context in which that statement was made is exactly the context I described yesterday. It has always been the position of the government that we would not increase the proportion of revenue to GDP. It was also of course the position of the government that we would not introduce a broadly based consumption tax. Of course it was the position that we would not introduce a wholesale sales tax. It is in that particular context and with that particular trio of quite explicit promises that the government went to the last election. It is that particular set of promises that this government has squarely and unequivocally maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What is therefore meant by yesterday's statement that no new taxes for four years will be imposed?

—I think it has been perfectly straightforwardly explained by the Prime Minister and Treasurer in the context of the budget strategy as a whole, which is a four-year medium term strategy designed to produce, as those opposite should know by now, a fiscal deficit of around one per cent of GDP—no more than that—by 1996-97. The budget has adopted projections based on a series of plausible assumptions, which are spelt out in the budget documents. They bring forward a projection roughly halfway between the high and low growth scenarios which were presented in the national fiscal outlook report. As again Senator Hill is probably not aware, this was an unprecedented cooperative effort by Commonwealth and state governments to map out the medium term fiscal challenges in this country.

PARA.TAB: Against the background of that particular report and that particular scenario, it is clear—and I repeat the words of the Prime Minister—that there is no fiscal imperative for further revenue or expenditure measures in order to achieve those medium term fiscal targets. That is the basis on which that statement has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer the minister to the government's decision to more than double the allocation to the rural adjustment scheme over the next four years to $406 million. I ask the minister what benefits this and other government initiatives have provided to overcome the problems being faced by rural Australia?

—Let me answer this question in my capacity as minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I was sure that one of the government backbenchers would ask this question because this matter is of great importance to rural Australia. We have tried to provide a special emphasis on it in the budget.

PARA.TAB: I am advised by the minister, Mr Crean, that the significance of what the government has done is quite important. We have responded to the problems of the rural sector with a range of targeted programs—targeted at farmers, rural communities and rural families. The budget has provided $406.8 million over four years for the rural adjustment scheme, known as RAS. It has provided $105.2 million for the national Landcare program. I think most senators in this chamber agree that land care is the foremost environmental issue in Australia.

Four million dollars a year has been provided for rural families through the abolition of the assets test on the supplementary boarding allowance under the assistance for isolated children scheme. There has been further funding to almost treble the number of telecentres, that is, centres owned by local communities which teach techniques in computing and the use of other modern day electronic aids to business. Funding to telecentres in rural areas will allow them to treble; an additional 1.2 million has been provided. Funding for rural counselling has increased by $650,000 to reach the figure of $3.95 million for the budget year 1993-94. Funding of $22.6 million has been provided for the agribusiness development program.

The government has introduced a refocussed rural adjustment scheme targeted at providing a leg-up to farmers who are making an effort to improve the productivity and sustainable profitability of their businesses. The scheme offers interest subsidies on commercial finance for productivity improving measures and grants for training and professional advice. Australia-wide in 1992-93, over 11,800 applicants for RAS were approved, providing support totalling more than $112 million all up. Of this, 6,638 applications were approved for exceptional circumstances support, totalling, for that category, $75.9 million.

I will say a few words on the farm household support scheme. In March this year the government introduced the farm household support scheme which provided a further support mechanism for farmers in addition to the standard welfare programs already available to the general population, such as the Jobsearch allowance. This scheme provides a loan for up to two years at the level of the Jobsearch allowance to meet daily living expenses for those farmers who are unable to access further commercial finance. The scheme is aimed at two distinct groups within the farming community. The first group is those are who are unable to convince their financial institution of their prospects but who wish to work their way out of difficulties. The scheme provides a source of finance to meet their day-to-day expenses while the farmer works to return the business to a sound footing. The second group is that which has taken the difficult decision to leave farming. For this group the FHS provides for daily living expenses while the farm is on the market.

There are a range of things I could say in answer to Senator Jones's question. Let me say that these schemes and extra finance build on a plethora of existing mechanisms to help the rural community and should be seen as answering many of the needs expressed by farmers and rural organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the leader in the Senate of a government that led the Australian people to believe that it was not going to increase tax. How then does Senator Gareth Evans explain the fact that the government has put up tobacco tax, HECS, tax on long service leave, wine tax, petrol tax, wool tax, fringe benefits tax and sales tax? Why should the government be allowed to get away with this when it conned the Australian people? It conned them and it conned them and it conned them. Why should it be allowed to get away with it? Why does it think it has the right to mislead the people just like that?

—I am having difficulty extracting the question from the rhetoric. The short answer is that nobody was conned because no commitment was made, for exactly the reason that I spelt out in my previous answer. When the Prime Minister talked about no increase in taxes, he was talking about no increase in the proportion of revenue to GDP. That is absolutely totally clear from the context of what he said at the time, and it is totally dishonest for members of the opposition to come in here and to claim otherwise.

PARA.TAB: The reason there have been those revenue increases—and there are a number of them in the budget—is in order to achieve that fiscal strategy, the medium-term four-year strategy which I described and which manifestly is in the interests of all the people in this country. We cannot have growth resumed in this country's economy without a responsible fiscal environment in which that will occur, a responsible monetary policy, a responsible wages policy, a responsible micro-economic policy and a responsible policy towards employment and training. We cannot have anything without all of those factors coming together in a responsible way.

People on the other side, who want to pick and choose in a piecemeal fashion between the individual components of the budget, are absolutely failing in any residual responsibility they might think they have with the Australian electorate. The Australian electorate has made perfectly clear what it thinks of the other side. When it comes to fiscal responsibility, the Australian electorate gave a vote of confidence to this government. That confidence was deserved because this government is behaving absolutely responsibly on the fiscal management front.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We now know why the government did not put a tax on hot air because Senator Gareth Evans would have to pay more than anybody else. He says that the Australian electorate gave a vote of confidence to this government. Why should the Australian electorate now be allowed to be betrayed by this government in the way that it has been? What is so responsible about soaking the poor with the taxes of this government? I ask Senator Gareth Evans to explain to this Senate why we and the Australian people should allow the government to break so many promises and put through these tax bills which are so dishonest, so immoral and so harsh on the people who cannot pay.
—To get straight to the point, Senator O'Chee, I have nothing further to add to my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. In the budget on Tuesday night, the government announced that it would commit almost $100 million over three years to a range of measures to assist more small to medium sized enterprises become internationally competitive. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the expected impact of these initiatives? Will this enable more small to medium sized enterprises to join those 700 firms identified by the McKinsey report as `emerging exporters'?
—The budget delivered on Tuesday contains a range of initiatives, amounting to approximately $94 million over three years, to assist Australian firms to become internationally competitive—
—This is particularly so in the small to medium sized business area—an area that Senator Ian Macdonald knows nothing about.

PARA.TAB: This whole range of initiatives represents an impressive package of importance. It should be noted that it is a package which is targeted to meet the needs of the small and medium sized enterprises. The measures announced recognise the achievements of those enterprises to date and build on those achievements. They recognise the challenges faced by small to medium sized businesses and tackle them with various new means.

Central to these initiatives is an extra $12.5 million for the National Industry Extension Service, known as NIES, which provides services to firms to help them achieve international competitiveness through greater efficiency. As a matter of fact, many of our successful exporters have already used NIES. Obtaining information about NIES and other government services quickly and easily will be enhanced through the planned establishment of first stop shops. The budget also provides funding for the establishment of Businesslink—an electronic information network which will provide all relevant information to businesses from one point of contact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read that a bit slower.

—For Senator Campbell, who has a slow brain, I will read even slower. Significantly, we are recognising the success of the export access program by allocating an additional $8 million over the next three years. This program which was delivered by industry associations—mainly the small business industry associations—will be able to assist an extra 800 firms over the next three years.

PARA.TAB: The export market development grant international trade enhancement scheme has also been boosted. Additionally, the government announced a Market Australia campaign to build an image of Australia as a country producing innovative, sophisticated, high quality goods and services. In total, these programs significantly increase the range of opportunities available to small and medium-sized businesses in this country. I am sure that even honourable senators opposite will be willing to support the extension of our small businesses into the export area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer the minister to the Uruguay Round of GATT and the reported concerns of the Clinton administration that the GATT proposals will be used to depress health, safety, food and environmental standards in the United States. First, has the Australian government sought to incorporate in GATT standards on food labelling, product and work safety, health and environmental protection which safeguard Australia's standards and/or advance global standards? Secondly, has the minister made a detailed assessment of the extent to which the Dunkel proposals specify international standards which are below those maintained in Australia? Thirdly, will he undertake not to sign the Uruguay Round agreement until GATT standards have been lifted to at least the Australian levels?

—I am delighted to receive a question on the GATT because the Uruguay Round, which has now been running for seven years, is coming up to the endgame of the negotiations. The negotiations resume in Geneva on 1 September and they are to be completed by 15 December. Seven years of negotiating work is coming to fruition in those last three months. Since the value to Australia in extra income from a strong outcome to the round when fully implemented is about an extra $2.5 billion, we can expect that, in the last few months as we complete the negotiations for the round, there will be endless forays to deflect our attention and try to put obstacles in our course for successfully bringing this round to conclusion. I am not accusing Senator Spindler of putting an obstacle in our course, but I am saying that his question betrays a fundamentally flawed understanding of what the GATT itself is about.
—GATT is a raging success!

—No, please listen to this because it is now important more than ever for us to have a clear understanding of what the GATT does and does not do. For example, the GATT does not impose environmental standards; the GATT does not impose labour standards; and the GATT does not impose labelling standards or things of that nature such as Senator Spindler referred to in his question. What the GATT does is proclaim a set of rules to ensure that trade in the world among the contracting parties to the agreement is fair, free and transparent. So, if a country is using environmental standards as a non-tariff barrier, then the rules under the GATT would expose that and then deal with it.

PARA.TAB: This does not in any way prevent countries like Australia or the United States—or any country—imposing their own environmental standards for environmental reasons. But we would be naive in the extreme to think that, on labour standards, environmental standards, labelling standards and a whole range of other standards, some countries in the world do not exploit the idealism of some groups in the community and use false implementation of those things as non-tariff barriers to prevent free trade. That, I think, answers the first question.

Let me turn to questions two and three. The questions of detailed assessment and delaying of the signature to the Uruguay Round agreement do not arise. On what Senator Spindler has put, we certainly would not, should there be a successfully concluded outcome, delay our signature. This is because the GATT and the Uruguay Round text on technical barriers to trade, the revised standards codes and the sanitary and phytosanitary measures will not impose specific standards on Australia and the GATT will therefore not undermine Australia's ability to maintain its own high level of environmental and other standards.

What I suggest—because I know that Senator Coulter has a notice of motion which is similarly flawed in its understanding of the role of GATT—is that if the Democrats, the Greens or the independent members here would like a full briefing on the GATT, I would be delighted to give it. For Australia this is the most significant multilateral trade negotiation that we have undertaken. What is at risk here, if we miscue on this, is a loss of income of $2.5 billion a year and a commensurate reduction in Australian living standards. Before anyone does anything rash about this, he or she should understand the full implications of what is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think our concern is that if the government proceeds as it has in the past, the costs from this will be much greater than the benefits. May I draw the minister's attention to the fact that Australia has lodged an appeal against the energy tax that the United States wanted to impose to advance its performance under the Montreal protocol to reduce the greenhouse effect in the United States, and of course globally. That is an example of what the Uruguay Round can be used for. The burden of my question is that those opposite do not do that for Australia.

—Once again, I renew my invitation. I ask honourable senators to please get a full briefing on this. This is an issue which is too important for it to be misunderstood. Australia has not done what Senator Spindler has accused us of doing. Australia has not opposed any measure on energy taxes by the Clinton administration. We have expressed our view about a form of tax being suggested by some in Congress which would impose an energy tax on countries that export goods and services into the United States and tax those exports from, for example, Australia on the basis of their energy component. That in its own way is a non-tariff barrier to trade.

PARA.TAB: I just suggest that these issues cannot be dealt with in the thrust of debate across this chamber. They are significant, weighty and substantial matters affecting our future economic well-being. I do renew the invitation. I ask honourable senators to please come and talk about this, so that at least there is a clear understanding between us about where we differ and what the facts are.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In view of the Commonwealth's concession last week in its amended defence in the High Court test case, that the plaintiff Cambodian boat person who arrived in Australia on 30 March 1990 on board the Beagle was detained unlawfully by the Commonwealth from the time he was held against his will up until 6 May 1992, will the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs now exercise his powers under section 115(5) of the Migration Act 1958 to allow the Cambodians to remain in Australia on humanitarian grounds or, at the very least, facilitate their release from detention pending finalisation of court proceedings arising from their refugee claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to Senator Chamarette is no. I think the reason why the answer is no is pretty well known not only to people in this place but also to people who have been out parading in the streets trying to put pressure on the government in respect of this issue.

PARA.TAB: The background is that when the act was changed—and I think that change took place in May 1992; in fact, it was in the House of Representatives on 5 May 1992—it was understood and acknowledged at the time that there may have been problems with the detention regime. That was spelt out in the House of Representatives on 5 May by, amongst others, the opposition spokesperson Mr Ruddock. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: We are of the view that the current powers of arrest and the basis on which people are detained are sufficiently cumbersome, outdated and silent as to leave doubt in the minds of some as to whether or not people held in custody can continue to be so held.
So legislation was then introduced. It was understood at the time that there might have been some problem with its detention regime.

PARA.TAB: In essence, it was understood at the time that although there might have been some question of illegality or doubt over legality, the legislation that the government introduced would rectify that particular situation. The people have been held quite legally, without any doubt at all, in detention since the passing of that legislation. As I say, although there was some doubt beforehand, that doubt had not been acknowledged technically until court proceedings on a matter of compensation were continued last week.

In respect of those proceedings, the Government Solicitor filed particulars and an amended defence in the High Court during the week ending 13 August and in that defence was an acknowledgment that Mr Ly was detained unlawfully. That was very much done in order to proceed to the major question of that litigation, that being the question of compensation. The basic issue here is that we are talking with people who have been determined not to be refugees and, as a consequence, we are not going to proceed down the road that Senator Chamarette suggests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The government has conceded that a person has been detained unlawfully for two years, regardless of the fact that the previous 18 months have been lawful detention. Does that not constitute grounds for release of a humanitarian kind and will it not be far less expensive to release those people into the community even pending their processing being completed rather than paying compensation and maintaining detention?

—I think I have gone to the substance of the question. What Senator Chamarette and others in the community who might get worked up about this particular issue should understand is that people who come here illegally by boat have, for a long time, had a very clear message from the Australian parliament, not just the government, and that is: if they are bona fide refugees they will be processed and out in the community. One quarter of them who have arrived in Australia by boat have been so processed and are in the community. If they are not bona fide refugees, then for so long as it takes them to pursue the courses of action available to them through our system they have to stay in detention. The people in question in a number of cases have been determined some four times not to be refugees. It is not within the will of this government to allow the process of delaying legal proceedings as embarked upon by some practitioners in this field to force us into a situation which subverts the policy of this parliament.
—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery on my left of a former minister, the Honourable Bill Wentworth.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. During the last election the Labor Party promised that all age pensioners would be free of tax by 1995. In fact, it was Senator Richardson who trumpeted this initiative and said in one of his flamboyant moments—and I will remind him—that this was `one of the greatest reforms this nation has ever had'. What possible explanation does the government have for ripping this assurance off pensioners less than one week after the last federal election, other than that it was a Labor L-I-E—lie?

—The Treasurer dealt with this issue some four or five months ago and we have had a rather large number of sittings of the parliament since. I would have thought that if this was actually a source of great passion and concern it might have been raised then.
—You didn't give us a question time on Tuesday.
—It might have escaped Senator Teague's notice but we were actually here in May.
—But we didn't have the budget in May.

—But honourable senators opposite did not have any doubt about the policy because the Treasurer had made it clear, and the Treasurer also made it clear at that time that the government was pursuing the objectives set down in that 1995 commitment other than through that way because we have been approached by a number of groups, principally pensioner groups, saying it was not the most equitable measure to pursue that goal.
