—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was the Minister approached by those pensioner groups up to the week before the election, because a minister was publishing material a week before the election promising pensioners just that?
—I'd shut my eyes if I were answering this question, too.
—Only if I was looking in your direction. The answer is yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. In the Distinctly Australian policy statement the government asserted that one of the fundamental aims of its cultural policy is to extend access for all Australians to a diverse range of cultural activities. In what way is the government fulfilling this commitment?

—That is a very appropriate question to ask because it is a policy commitment from which Tasmania has been a very significant beneficiary. Providing opportunities for wider access and participation has been and remains a fundamental aim of our cultural policy. We should all have the opportunity to share the national story being told by the arts and the cultural industries of Australia. It is important that we make it available broadly.

PARA.TAB: One of the most significant initiatives in this area in recent years has been the Playing Australia performing arts touring program. Since January this year, Playing Australia has made it possible for more than 50 performing arts companies to take their productions across state boundaries to towns and regional centres around Australia. The big winners have been Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the regional cities and centres of Australia.

In this budget we have extended that program. We have also added to it a visual arts touring program which will enable more Australians to enjoy the visual arts, crafts and collections of heritage and scientific materials of our national collecting institutions and of state and regional institutions. One of the important things about both the performing arts and the visuals arts touring program has been and will be that not only are collections in the major capital cities and the arts groups performing in the major capital cities being taken to regional cities where it was not otherwise possible, but also performers and artists in those areas are getting access to the wider audience of people in the major capital cities. So people from Broome are performing their work in Melbourne and people from Tasmania have the opportunity to get access to the audiences of the mainland.

We will be providing $1 million this financial year and a further $5 million over the next three years to enable both major collecting institutions and smaller organisations to tour exhibitions of the visual arts more widely. They will move across state and territory boundaries to cities and regional centres around the country, making the best art available to Australians available to all Australians wherever they live.

The cultural policy Distinctly Australian, which was delivered in the budget, has a variety of components. It covers a diverse range of cultural activities. A credible and coherent policy requires more than just turning up to glitzy opening nights and getting one's photograph taken with international artists as they visit the country. I know that the Leader of the Opposition has taken on the role of arts spokesperson; I suppose he hopes some charisma might rub off. But can I advise him that an arts policy requires more than five visits to 42nd Street.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the minister representing the Treasurer. Would the government which promised no new taxes care to explain why millions of ordinary workers who have carefully planned their retirements and their long service leave entitlements should suddenly and retrospectively have the rug pulled from under them? What possible fairness can there be in treating older Australians on the verge of retirement as pawns in Labor's desperate and dishonest deficit repair game, by hitting them for thousands of dollars in extra taxes? Is this just another flagrant example of Labor's social justice strategy in action, and why should the Senate be an accomplice to any initiative that imposes these new taxes?

—I note the fervent attempt by people to create a climate in which they can justify voting against these measures, but the attempt to portray that question as concern for lower income workers is an absolute phoney. Most people except Senator Alston would understand that for this simple reason: no worker, no citizen in Australia, on less than $20,700 a year will lose 1c as a result of this policy—everybody should know that—because the tax rate on which this applies at the moment is 30c. So no-one whose marginal rate is less than 30c will lose a cent. Nobody on less than $38,000 would lose significantly because most of that person's income would be taxed at much less than 30c and only a very small amount up to 34c.

PARA.TAB: So it is not a measure that will adversely affect lower income workers at all. What will happen—and Senator Kernot correctly outlined the principle this morning on radio—is that lump sum payments will now be taxed in the same manner as leave taken during employment. That is, income, whatever its form, will be taxed in the same manner. That is the proper taxing principle. There is no question about that.

Most low income earners do not get the benefit of the existing concessions. They are concessions that have been overwhelmingly available to high income earners only. So let us not try to shed crocodile tears and concoct some concern about lower income workers. The legitimate concerns of taxpayers who are close to retirement or who lose their jobs at short notice have been acknowledged in the way the changes have been structured.

Retaining concessions on long service leave accrued before 1978 for those taxpayers aged 55 or over will cover the largest part of the current concessions for this group. All the concessions for those who leave employment because of redundancy, invalidity or approved early retirement will be retained. The principal concerns of those who are close to retirement or who lose their jobs at short notice have been addressed. Those who are concerned about this measure should not try to dress up their concern as protecting the interests of low income workers because those workers have never had the benefit of this concession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister seriously suggesting that 60 per cent of taxpayers who earn more than $20,700 and who happen to be under 55 years of age should simply stand by while the government imposes a retrospective tax simply for its own selfish budget purposes? The minister has the cheek to say to them, `Our social justice policy extends only to people who are on $20,000 or less'. In other words, `We couldn't give a damn about the bulk of the Australian population and we're going to tax you retrospectively because it suits us'. Is that the government's policy?

—That does not bear the vaguest relation to what I have said, but I never expected Senator Alston to listen, so I am not very worried about it. I actually spoke about the situation for people on incomes up to $38,000 a year, but Senator Alston was not listening. The fact of the matter is that for people earning up to $38,000 it is a very marginal issue. The opposition continually tries to find ways in which income can be raised but somehow or other nobody has to pay it. It wants to make omelettes without breaking eggs. I can tell those opposite that it does not work.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the minister to the budget change abolishing Austudy for 16-year-old secondary students, who will now remain under the family payments system. Is the minister concerned that the transfer of these students from Austudy will result in a drop in assistance of around $8 per fortnight? What will the minister do now that the assets tests that apply to the family payments system are far more restrictive than the Austudy test and that rural students in particular are now likely to be ineligible for assistance due to the nominal value of their parents' farms? Will the government show real commitment to rural families, who are now doing it tougher than ever before, and exempt the family farm from the assets test in the family payments system? How many students will be disadvantaged by the change?

—I have been advised that the government's decision to streamline payment arrangements for 16-year-old secondary students does not apply to students living away from home; accordingly, it will have no effect on isolated rural families. In the last election the government promised that it would abolish the assets test for families in the assistance to isolated children scheme. The government has honoured that commitment.

PARA.TAB: This measure recognises the hardship being experienced by families affected by the rural recession and is aimed at ensuring that the recession does not impede rural children's access to education. Payment arrangements for 16-year-old school students living at home have been streamlined. The need for families to transfer between family payments and Austudy while their young children continue on interrupted secondary schooling has been reduced as a result.

Some students will stay with the family payment system and will receive a slightly reduced weekly entitlement. The 1994 Austudy assets limit for families is $369,350, but rural families receive concessional treatment because the value of farm business assets is discounted by 50 per cent. The normal assets test on additional family payments is $363,500, but special hardship provisions that apply would cover many farming families.
In relation to the last part of Senator Woodley's question as to how many will be affected, I have not been able to get that amount of information. I will pass it to him when it becomes available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Health. Can the minister advise what the government's assessments are about the numbers of children and self-funded retirees who will not get eye tests as a result of Tuesday's budget? How many cases of eye disease are likely to go undetected? Why should any Australian accept Senator Richardson's word as minister on anything at all, given that on 2 July he promised the Australian Optometrical Association that nothing would happen to optometry services in this year's budget. He also gave an assurance that he would consult with the association before doing anything which might adversely impact on optometrical benefits. Why is it that all ministers in this government lie?

—Order! I really think that is a reflection and that it should be withdrawn. I am writing to the leaders of the parties today. I have allowed people to say `the government has lied'. I am not going to allow it to be said—and this has been the practice that has applied in this place for a long time—that individual ministers lie. I think the remark ought to be withdrawn.

—Mr President, may I pursue the matter a little further. I take it that you have just accepted then that it is legitimate in this place to accuse the government of lying, and we certainly do that in relation to the last election—it lied, lied and lied again. I also remind you, Mr President, that last year when you allowed Senator Cook to refer to the Victorian government as lying, he clearly was putting it in the context of Mr Kennett and then Mr Gude. So you allowed him to list ministers and then say that the Victorian government lied, and you said that that was legitimate. I ask you: how do you distinguish that ruling from what was just said by Senator Newman?

—I intend, Senator Hill, as I said, to write to you and to the other leaders of the major parties about this whole question of accusing a government of lying. I have let it go this week. I am saying that what Senator Newman has said this afternoon is directly in contrast to rulings that have been made by presidents before me and I am asking her to withdraw. I ask people to withdraw and the majority do, even when I do not regard it as unparliamentary. I am just asking her to withdraw.

—With respect to you, Mr President, I do withdraw, pending your ruling. However, perhaps I may rephrase my question—and I wonder whether it makes that much difference because we all know what I am saying: why do ministers in this government have so much terrible trouble in telling the truth?

—Ministers in this government, at least the ones that I know, have absolutely no problem with the truth at all. In fact, every day I come in here and hear nothing but the truth from all those on my right and my left, and one person in front of me.

PARA.TAB: I was asked a specific question about undertakings that I gave at a meeting with the president and secretary, I think, of the Optometrical Association. That meeting took place about six weeks ago, just after I had a meeting with the College of Ophthalmologists, which had some nasty things to say about the optometrists; it does not like them very much.

TALK.START.PARA: —They always do. That's nothing new.

—Yes, that is right; they always do. It is nothing new; it has been going on for years. The College of Ophthalmologists said that it was about to give me a submission which would lay the ground for heinous things to be done to optometrists who were in some way cheating upon the system. I told the optometrists about the ophthalmologists wanting to give me that document. I told them that I would take no action on that document without talking to them. I have not read that document because subsequent to the meeting that I had with the optometrists there were budget discussions. Savings papers came up in those budget discussions and, as a minister with no problem with the truth and with an absolute commitment to the responsibility ministers have, I did not discuss that matter with the optometrists or anyone else. To have done so would have been a clear breach of responsibility on my part and not something which I would do. So I did not speak to the optometrists and, given that the undertaking was given in the context of a paper to have been received from the ophthalmologists, I have no qualms of conscience about anything I did in relation to that.
—You never had a qualm of conscience in your life.

—I think I know far more about it than Senator Herron. One of the questions asked by Senator Newman concerned eye disease and the number of children in whom it would not be detected. I do not know the answer to that; I am not sure that anyone does, although we will seek some information on that point.
—Now you say it. You should have done this before.
—Senator Herron should remain calm. I said this to him yesterday; he has a problem with this.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senator—You have a problem with the truth too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no problem whatsoever. Yesterday I said—I repeated it this morning—that in so far as the examinations for squinting in children are concerned, I will go back to the government on that question, in the same way I did a few years ago when I was the Minister for Social Security. We made that co-payment decision on pharmaceutical benefits and I went back to the chronically ill. I see no difficulty in seeking an exemption for those who are in need and for any unintended consequences.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister some pretty specific questions. Obviously, he does not know the answers so I will put them more clearly for him if it helps him. Firstly, is he trying to give us the impression that the government has done no work at all on assessing how many children or self-funded retirees will not get eye tests? Secondly, would he dispute, for example, that something like 11,000 cases of undetected diabetes are detected in routine eye tests around the country? Thirdly, is the Minister specifically denying that he told the optometrists that nothing would happen to optometry services in this year's budget?
—I thought I answered the last part of that question more than adequately in the first attempt, but I will give it one more try.
—You could say yes or no.

—If the answer is to be yes or no, no, they were not the exact words that I used. But I am sure Senator Newman wants more than that and so, in the reasonableness that I always show, I am trying to give her the full answer. I told the optometrists that I had no plans to do anything to optometry in the budget and that if, after reading the submission from the ophthalmologists, that changed I would let them know and discuss any alterations I wanted to make with them first. I have already explained the context of that. I see no reason to repeat it. One could not glean from any syllable that I uttered in the first answer that we have done no work on the points that Senator Newman made.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the claims about the numbers of cases of diabetes detected by examinations in optometrists' offices, I think they will be very hard to verify. No doubt there are some. I am not sure that I would be prepared to put a figure on it as yet, and I certainly would not simply accept the figures produced by them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Health, concerns the seniors card. Who will qualify for the new seniors card? Will it make any real difference to the lives of those who qualify for it? What extra access to health services will it give to people?
—Mr President—
—Why would anyone believe you?
—Well, they will be getting their seniors cards and these services, Senator. As usual, we will be delivering. That is why they will be believing. The proof is in the pudding, as they say.
—They get 15 per cent in respect of sewerage charges.

—Let us not talk about sewerage; let us talk about the seniors card. I have been asked by Senator Carr about the application of the new seniors card. All senators will recall that during those glorious halcyon days when I was Minister for Social Security, I suggested that there ought to be an extension of benefits beyond the limits that applied in those days. As of April this year, the government extended the health card for all those who are on a part pension, which is a very important extension.

PARA.TAB: We are now seeing a further extension to bring some real justice to those who have paid taxes all their lives but who are not on super incomes in their retirement. All those who are of qualifying age and whose taxable incomes are below the pension cut-off point will be eligible for the new seniors card from 1 July 1994.

In these days pension levels have crept up and up. The pension is now more than $18,000 for a single person and over $31,000 for a couple. They are quite reasonable incomes. It is a very important step for the people concerned. It means that they will not be disadvantaged by the extra medical costs which are often associated with getting older and which no doubt one day we will all face. They will now be able to obtain concessional pharmaceuticals, which is very important for them.

Pensioners will be able to participate in the new dental scheme, which will be up and running in every state in Australia by 1 July next year. That is another promise that has been kept by the government in this budget. They will be able to obtain optometry services, because they have been exempted from that charging decision as well, and they will get free hearing aids from Australian Hearing Services.

It is clear from all those examples that there is a recognition of a group of Australians who have made an enormous contribution over a lifetime. These people deserve some rewards for all that effort and participation. As usual, this government is delivering it to them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to his earlier answer to Senator Hill in which he said that the Prime Minister, on 19 November, had said:

QUESTION.PARA: To maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment

I stress the phrases `tax to GDP ratios' and `at the moment'. Is it correct that the tax to GDP ratio to which the Prime Minister must have been referring was 22.2 per cent for 1992-93. As a result of the tax changes announced in the budget, the ratio will rise to 23.5 per cent by 1996?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are comparing apples to oranges.
—No, tax to GDP ratios. This represents about a $6 billion tax rise. Will the Minister now admit that Mr Keating has broken the promise that he made on Lateline last year not to put up tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The information available to me is that the tax to GDP ratio for last year, 1992-93, was 23.6 per cent and that the one for this year is 23.5 per cent—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is talking in the context of the total relationship between what the taxpayer pays and what the total product of this country is. The context of that particular exchange is worth reading out in full in order to appreciate the context in which the Prime Minister was talking. Mr O'Brien, the interviewer, said:

ANSWER.PARA: But you have acknowledged for example the need for infrastructure spending. There are some who would say the need for infrastructure spending is even much greater than you're anticipating. There is a limited purse within which to do that, but you are promising with a very uncertain economy, very uncertain recovery, very uncertain international economy, you are promising a massive tax cut, two years from now, three years from now, four years from now.
The question is about what revenue is available to finance infrastructure spending. The Prime Minister responds:
To maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment. In order words, what I'm promising is not put up tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I seek your guidance because I think I can cut this short by pointing out that the Prime Minister said, `the tax to GDP ratio'. That is what the Prime Minister said in response to that question. The revenue to GDP ratio is quite different, Senator Evans.
—Order! That is a spurious point of order.

—I know that Senator Kemp moves in sophisticated circles and that, in particular, he is accompanied constantly by Senator Bishop, who I noted gave her budget address-in-reply speech today, to which performance at the Canberra Club all the media were invited to attend. That is another fascinating demonstration of what is going on in the Liberal Party. I guess that in those sophisticated circles Senator Kemp moves, and with that kind of advice available to him, it is possible to draw a distinction between tax and revenue.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, it is not a distinction that people employ in the context of ordinary discourse, ordinary rough and tumble media exchanges of the kind that was in issue there. That was obviously what was in the Prime Minister's mind. This is a squalid and rather pathetic little effort to justify a course of action on which those opposite are all embarked—making claims about misleading statements on tax which simply have no justification whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I suppose I can say, `What a tangled web we weave when first we set out to deceive'. How is it a `squalid act' to quote the precise words the Prime Minister said in relation to a tax promise? I will put the question to Senator Evans again. He has dumped the Prime Minister right in it today. The Prime Minister said, `the tax to GDP ratio at the moment'. He did not say `revenue to GDP ratio'. Can the minister now stand up and admit that the Prime Minister has lied to the Australian public once again?
—I suppose I could respond to that undergraduate diatribe with a sort of elegant postgraduate response, but I think it would be wasting everybody's time if I did so; the answer is perfectly clear.

—I actually have two questions for the Minister for Transport and Communications, but I can ask only one of them. Can the minister provide details of the work involved and the funding required for the proposed completion of the survey in regard to Alice Springs to Darwin railway proposal?

—I am glad to be able to finish question time today on a positive note. The proposed Alice Springs to Darwin railway stretches across a distance of about 1,400 kilometres. Of that distance, about 1,100 kilometres has so far been surveyed. I acknowledge that this is a matter that has been raised in this chamber by Senator Chapman and in which the people of South Australia have a keen interest. Three hundred and seventy-five kilometres of this route remain to be surveyed. This part of the line is in four sections: between Murranji and Buchanan, from Western Creek to Katherine, from Burrundie to Adelaide River and between Livingston and Darwin.

PARA.TAB: The funding allocation in the budget will complete the survey of the rail link and it fulfils an important election commitment that was made by the Prime Minister, particularly to the constituents of the Northern Territory and South Australia. An amount of $3 million will be provided over the next two years for this work in line with this commitment, and the survey work will go to tender. The completed survey will help future proposals on the commercial viability of the rail link to be more accurately appraised. The federal government is prepared to consider providing further assistance with the future development of the project if a substantial private investor or developer expresses some real interest in it. I note in passing that this is precisely the same position that was adopted during the election campaign on this issue by the shadow cabinet.

Honourable senators would be aware that a number of taxation incentives have been provided by the government for the private sector construction of large infrastructure projects such as the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link and those were introduced in the One Nation package. I am pleased to see that the budget decision to fund the survey has been welcomed by the Northern Territory government, by business and union leaders. Those close to the debate would recall that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, claimed in the last week of the campaign that the re-election of the Federal Labor government would have meant all chances of developing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you fix him up, Bob?

—Fortunately, Marshall Perron happens to be still in office. He has not actually strangled any journalists lately, so he is still there. The budget announcement, unfortunately, has been met with silence from those opposite. This is perhaps not surprising given that the opposition shadow minister, John Sharp, said on ABC radio in Darwin only a couple of weeks ago that the opposition had `proof' that the Labor government would renege on its promise to fund the survey. He has maintained his unbroken record in that sense of getting it wrong.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Mr President, I was standing.
—Order! Question time had gone over by more than a minute.
—Just a couple of minutes ago, Senator Kemp asked me a question to the effect that tax—
—An undergraduate tutorial.

—Here is the postgraduate bit and Senator Patterson had better wait because she is not going to like it. Tax last year, said Senator Kemp, was 22.2 per cent. Tax this year, said Senator Kemp, was 23.5 per cent.
—No, I did not say that.

—Can I just tell Senator Kemp what the tax this year is going to be? I would be delighted to, because the figure for tax this year is 21.9 per cent. In other words, the proportion of tax to GDP—not revenue to GDP—will in fact reduce from 22.2 per cent last year to 21.9 per cent. So comparing apples with apples, not apples with oranges or anything else, the tax to GDP ratio has, I am verily advised and believe, gone down. So you, Senator Kemp, are a goose.
—Order!
—I ask the Minister to withdraw that.
—I withdraw it—a gander.
—I wish to move to take note of the minister's answer and to respond to the unfounded accusations he made.
—If there are ministers with answers, they have priority.
—Senator Short was going to ask me a question; I would rather deal with that now. Senator Kemp could then proceed.

—In accordance with the procedural orders and resolutions of the Senate, I ask the following ministers for an explanation of why they have left unanswered for more than 30 days the following questions I have on the Notice Paper: Senator McMullan, question No. 64; Senator Bolkus, questions Nos 75, 89 and 218; and Senator Ray, question No. 212.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, question Nos 215 and 212 are on the same subject. The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet indicated that the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services would provide one comprehensive answer to this question. The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet instructed departments that no further action was necessary on behalf of it. Senator McMullan can round out why there is a delay to those questions in general.
—Before I call Senator McMullan, if opposition senators have questions to ask of ministers, it would help if they tell the chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the issue, but Senator Short referred to question No. 212; I am talking about question No. 223, which is about consultants under the Member of Parliaments (Staff) Act. I know Senator Short is waiting on another answer from me, but that was the one he was talking about with Senator Robert Ray. I have a different number, but we are talking about the same question.

PARA.TAB: The answer has been prepared, but to assist the Table Office it has been converted to disk for its more easy utilisation. That has taken a little time but should be available today. It would otherwise have been available before the start of this week. We have undertaken to give the answer to the Table Office on disk rather than on hard copy. I repeat that it should be available today.

Senator Short has asked my office about a couple of other answers and they have been supplied. The one that is outstanding, which is the one that Senator Short is referring to, is No. 64. The response is in preparation. I understood that it would be here; it is not. So I will pursue it for tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Short) agreed to:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanations given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) and the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray).

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 18 August on the motion of Senator Short, I now table a statement of the government's forward estimates projections of revenue for each of the fiscal years 1994-95 to 1996-97. This will be of particular interest to Senator Kemp, because it starkly outlines the particular point I was making before. Whereas revenue has gone last year to this year from 23.6 to 23.5 per cent, tax revenue—and there is a distinction—goes from 22.2 down to 21.9 per cent, as I just said. It will make very interesting reading, and I think Senator Kemp should be grateful to his friend Jim Short for giving me the opportunity to put this firmly on the public record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Kemp this day in relation to the ratio of taxation to gross domestic product.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to respond to the astonishing comments that Senator Gareth Evans made after a bit of quick advice from Senator McMullan, who popped over on the run. The trouble with taking advice on the run is that one is liable to get it wrong, and that is precisely what Senator Gareth Evans did. I was using the formulation used by Senator Gareth Evans and by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in previous question times and that is, what happens when these tax changes that the government has announced wash through the system. The government's budget papers show that, at the end of the day, the ratio of tax to GDP will rise to 23.5 per cent. Of course, some of these tax changes do not apply until part of the way through the year. Everyone now concedes that the Prime Minister has given a somewhat inflated estimate overriding Treasury of what the GDP will be in year one. That was the figure which Senator Gareth Evans mentioned but which was not relevant to the question I put.

PARA.TAB: What is interesting to the taxpayer—and what the government has tried to justify since the budget—is that taxes will not rise above what Senator Gareth Evans has described as current levels, which he then goes on to define—

TALK.START.PARA: —Roughly current levels. Quote him accurately.

—Senator Gareth Evans has had his go; I am going to have my go. He has defined them over the past eight years. The government's own budget papers show that after all these tax changes which are imposed this year wash through the system, on the government's own forecasts, the ratio will rise to 23.5 per cent. That is precisely what I said in my question to Senator Gareth Evans.

PARA.TAB: The problem today was that Senator Gareth Evans was caught out seriously. He defined the promise in terms of the tax to GDP ratio and we accepted the terms in which he defined that promise. Then we looked at the government's budget papers and found that the tax to GDP ratio rises over the term of this government as a result of these tax changes. Because of the poor advice that Senator Gareth Evans has taken or because of the lack of work that he applies to his job, he has put the Prime Minister straight in the soup.

Therefore, I think that after all this is over, Senator Evans should go and make it clear to Mr Keating that he and his colleagues and the community are not going to accept these broken promises. These innumerable taxes, which Senator O'Chee so well explained to the Senate today, are quite contrary to the promises that the government made during the election campaign. After these have washed through the system, as Senator McMullan will now tell us, the tax to GDP ratio will rise from the level that Mr Keating was talking about to 23.5 per cent on the government's figures.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to have the opportunity to participate in this debate.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senator—Did you seek leave?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need to do that because I am speaking to a motion which he has moved.
—We would give leave to Gareth to do it and have another good laugh.
—I also thank Senator Macdonald for his assistance. In terms of humour around here he is doing well enough just by opening his mouth.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that we have people here who are seeking to be profound when unfortunately they are not really on top of the facts that they are dealing with. We have those things which determine the tax to GDP ratio as well as the revenue to GDP ratio, which is clearly the more important factor. If it is not self-evident, I will come to the reason why it is more important in a moment; it would be self-evident to most people but apparently not to everybody here.

The ratios are determined by more than merely the changes in the tax laws. With absolutely no change in the tax laws, it is possible for the tax to GDP ratio to change depending on the rate of inflation, the rate of growth, what is happening on to wages, what is happening to company profits and on the composition of the GDP between wages and profits, because taxes on profits are different from taxes on wages. In a projection four years out, there is a complex array of factors that determine tax to GDP ratio.

In the table that Senator Evans has just tabled, which is an extract from the budget papers and shows figures going back to 1953, we find a number of occasions in which there have been major changes in tax to GDP ratio without changes of any significance—and sometimes none at all—to the tax laws of a revenue raising nature. It is possible to have a year in which there are tax cuts, and yet the tax to GDP ratio changes because of other underlying economic factors. Senator Kemp knows that, just as he knows that the tax cuts cost more than the tax measures will raise.

I am not saying that Senator Kemp sought to mislead, but it is misleadingly simplistic to go four years out and assume that the tax to GDP ratio is solely driven by changes in the tax laws. The data over the years quite clearly proves that that is not the case. Senator Short and other people with any knowledge of, for example, the impact of the change in composition of the GDP, the impact of growth, the impact of inflation on tax to GDP ratio would know that inflation is the most obvious but not the only one. Even at the very low inflation rate that we have there is inevitably some impact on tax to GP ratio. But revenue as a percentage of GDP is a much more important issue than tax as a percentage of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Paul said.

—I have dealt with Senator Kemp's wonderful issue; I am trying to make another point. Revenue as a percentage of GDP is what determines the percentage of resources being produced in the economy and used by the government to fund its measures or to determine the extent of its deficit. That is the case if, as with all previous Liberal governments, it is running at a deficit—unlike the position under this Labor government which is the only one in history to have had some experience in running a surplus.

PARA.TAB: The more important criterion is the revenue to GDP. As I tried to explain to Senator Hill on television the other night, that will, over four years, go up by less than one per cent—even with all those other influencing factors that I outlined. I failed, obviously, to explain it adequately to Senator Hill; I am sorry about that. It may be in the teacher's shortcomings, but I think it is more likely the student.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Evans and he is the student. He didn't learn too well.

—I was not referring to the leader of my party when I spoke about failure to learn. However, the most important point is that the factors determining tax to GDP ratio are much more complex over four years than the simplistic nonsense that Senator Kemp spoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard such a lot of nonsense in my life as that which has just come from Senator McMullan and, before he spoke, Senator Evans. Those people opposite have got themselves into an absolute shambles. The simple fact is that on Lateline on, I think, 22 November last year—
—November 19; get it right.
—On 19 November last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: To maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Roughly, yes, roughly.
—That is his objective, yes:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, what I'm promising is not to put up tax.
At that time, the tax to GDP ratio for the year just completed—1992-93—was 22.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And this year will be?

—This year it will be 21.9 per cent. And does Senator Evans know what it will be next year, according to the figures he has just tabled? It will be 22.8 per cent; then it will be 23.3 per cent; and then it will be 23.5 per cent.
—It is going up.
—So it is going up every year. It will go up every year between now and 1996-97. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) acknowledged that very point yesterday at the National Press Club. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that in doing that—
that is, the budget's tax measure—
we will be restoring the overall share of taxation revenue by 1996-97 to 23.5 per cent of GDP.

In other words, he is saying exactly the opposite of what the Prime Minister said on Lateline in November last year in what was unequivocally an election promise. On the basis of the figures that the government has produced in the last couple of days in the budget, the Prime Minister lied. The Prime Minister lied, and there is no way—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is unparliamentary and out of order to describe a member of the other place as lying. Senator Short knows that, and I ask him to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Withdraw, Senator Short.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, our leaders are going to be written to on this. So, pending clarification of that—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If you are going to make a ruling in accordance with Senator Evans's request that that is unparliamentary, I think, Mr Acting Deputy President, you should take into account the previous rulings of the President in this regard. What I will do is ask of you the same as I asked of the President to—
—Including the ruling half an hour ago.
—No, he did not make a ruling half an hour ago; he said he was going to write a letter and he asked for a withdrawal. He did not make a ruling.
—He asked that Senator Newman withdraw.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am going to ask you to distinguish between the situation of stating that the Prime Minister is a liar and what Senator Cook was allowed by the President to do on an a number of occasions in November of last year, and that was to refer to the Victorian Premier and certain of his ministers and then immediately thereafter say the government lied. The only possible interpretation of that is that he was dressing up an allegation that those Victorian ministers were lying with the final wrap-up statement that the government lied. Nobody reading what Senator Cook said on several occasions on 10 and 12 November last year could do other than interpret that he was alleging that the Premier of Victoria in the lead-up to the Victorian election lied; and yet he was permitted by the President to do so in this place.

PARA.TAB: What I am asking is: how can he—a Labor minister in this place—be permitted by the President to do that as within the standing orders and practices of this place if you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are going to rule in favour of Senator Gareth Evans and say that Senator Short should not be permitted to say, in these blatant circumstances, that the Prime Minister lied in the lead-up to this federal election?

TALK.START.PARA: —I request to speak further on the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. What Senator Short said was—and I quote him as best I can recollect—that the Prime Minister has lied. He did not say, `The government has lied'. His reference was not made in any collective way, which is the particular context that Senator Hill is describing and in respect of which Senator Sibraa earlier today said that something of an anomaly perhaps had opened up, because precedents had been established where people had referred to a collectivity as lying. But whatever may be the case, whatever may be the justification for drawing that distinction, which is perhaps a rather dubious one—I say this with all due regard to my colleague and the President—there is no suggestion and never has been any suggestion in this place—and nor should there be any such suggestion—that a statement as blatant as that made by Senator Short is other than absolutely, unequivocally unparliamentary, and I ask you to order him to withdraw on that basis. A specific reference to a specific named member of the other place in those terms, Mr Acting Deputy President, is just out of order.

—On the basis that it has been held on so many occasions that to say that the Prime Minister or another parliamentarian has lied is not in order and under the circumstances of a recent statement by the President on this matter—under all those circumstances—I ask Senator Short to withdraw.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, pending, as I say, the President writing to the party leaders, I will defer and withdraw. I have consulted a thesaurus on this. Would you take as an alternative a `right proper whopper'? What the Treasurer did yesterday at the press club by telling the truth—and for once he could not do anything else because he had actually put it in his budget papers the day before—by saying that tax measures will restore the overall share of tax revenue by 1996-97 to 23.5 per cent of GDP was to put the Prime Minister's statement on Lateline last year in proper perspective—that is, that that statement was blatantly wrong; it was not an accurate or a true statement. Yet it was a statement that was relied on very heavily by the electorate during the election campaign.

PARA.TAB: Let me come back very briefly to the figures because they are extremely significant. The figures that Senator Gareth Evans has tabled today—and I thank him for doing that—show, as he rightly says, that the ratio of tax to GDP will fall marginally from 22.2 per cent last year to 21.9 per cent this year. But then it will increase every year until 1996-97, till it reaches the figure of 23.5 per cent, and that figure means that the tax hike involved is more than $6 billion.

If that is not a tax hike, I would like Senator Gareth Evans to tell me and the Australian people what is, because there is no way that the government can get that figure without there being a massive increase in taxes. If one looks at the government's figures published in the budget, even in absolute terms—set aside altogether the percentages—tax is going to rise from an estimated $89.2 billion last financial year, and $92.4 billion this financial year, to $121.4 billion in 1996-97.

By anyone's standards, by anyone's measure, that is not only a tax rise; it is a big tax rise. It is absolutely contrary to the deceit the government has been trying to spread across the Australian electorate for months and months now and which it spread—shamefully—in particular, before the election. The government's whole economic policy is a shambles, a fraud. It is an absolute deceit. The government has been caught out monumentally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to reiterate the points made by Senator Kemp and Senator Short: the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was simple, straightforward and comprehensible. He was making a promise to the Australian people that he would not increase the taxation burden. Senator Kemp and Senator Short and Senator Gareth Evans have been kind enough to table figures which demonstrate that the Prime Minister was the truest deceiver of them all on that occasion. In fact, the tax burden has gone up.

PARA.TAB: We are equally indebted to Mr Laurie Oakes, who wrote an article which appeared in the Bulletin today entitled `Pea-and-fumble secrets revealed'. He quotes from an article written by Dr John Edwards, Paul Keating's economic adviser, who told how these people try to turn the English language in such a way as to bamboozle and confuse. Referring to the article by Dr Edwards, Mr Oakes says:

Before the election, the budget was self-repairing. It was going to `whirr back into balance'. Now the revenue base has to be repaired through tax increases before the whirring can begin. Pre-election, Keating was promising not to put up tax. Now that has been redefined to mean the overall tax take will not be increased beyond the level it reached in the boomtime `80s. Pre-election, nary a word was said about the decline of national savings. Now it is one of the major problems facing the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is what we have seen today from Senator Evans and his chief adviser, Senator McMullan. Referring to Dr Edwards, Mr Oakes continues:

He goes further, referring to the process as `manipulation', often on many different levels, `with one rationale for action giving way to another more sophisticated one as each was successively undermined by fact and experience'.

PARA.TAB: He continues: `Very often the personal success of politicians or the continued electoral success of the government depends on the ability of the cabinet members and their officials to persuade us to see the world as they wish us to see it and then, when reality intrudes, to persuade us to see it in a somewhat different way without noticing the change or being annoyed by the contradiction.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what we have seen today. The Prime Minister said on 19 November that he was going to `maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment'—that is, at that point in time. The Prime Minister was referring to a 22.2 per cent figure. The figures that Senator Evans has tabled in the Senate today show us that by 1996-97 that will have risen to 23.5 per cent. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I think it is important to have a graduate from the government side speaking on this matter. So much for undergraduates over here. I was looking up at the school children in the gallery above and the older people in the gallery below and thinking that it would be very interesting for them—
—They are not old.

—I did not say that. Please let me be quick because the graduate wants to talk on this. I would like to go down the streets in the marginal seats that I doorknocked for nine weeks at the beginning of this year and look through the flyscreen doors of those people who were deceived during the election. I would like to see them look at the transcript of this speech. I would like the people in the gallery to think about the sorts of figures that we are arguing about, whether it is revenue to GDP or tax to GDP, and I would like to hear their interpretation of `the tax burden will not go up'.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that everyone who read a newspaper or saw television on Tuesday night or Wednesday morning knows that the tax on wine went up—they know that the tax on cars went up; they know that the tax on cigarettes went up; they know that the tax on petrol, flavoured milk and toothpaste went up. The tax on all of these things went up, up, up. To the people living in the streets of suburban Australia it makes almost no difference whatsoever whether we pay 22 per cent of revenue to GDP or 23 per cent. The tax increase is what counts to the people of Australia. The reality is how it affects their lifestyles. We can sit in this place, so many thousands of miles away from real Australians, and argue as much as we want to about percentages.

We as a Senate are indebted to the graduate on the other side of the chamber for today tabling the figures in relation to revenue as a percentage of GDP, because even his own figures prove that this government is not the government of the true believers; it is the government of the true deceivers.

This government, Mr Keating and the graduate on the other side of the table, having promised that tax would not rise, will have achieved a tremendous thing in Australian politics: they will have exceeded what Gough Whitlam was able to achieve at the end of his regime in 1975. And it was a tremendous achievement. At the end of the famous Whitlam era, that government had achieved a revenue to GDP of 22 per cent. On the figures tabled by the graduate recently, by 1995-96 this government will have exceeded that by some 1.3 per cent. We will have an even higher percentage of revenue to GDP in the next year or so than that which was able to be achieved by those economic gurus Mr Whitlam, Dr Cairns and Mr Hayden, and by those other brilliant economic thinkers during those heady days of 1972 to 1975.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the subject of the heady days, I remind Senator Campbell that in the last two years of the Fraser administration the figure was 24 per cent—a higher proportion of tax to GDP than will be the case in 1996-97, even on these projections; that is, 23.5 per cent. He might just contemplate that figure before he gets too cavalier with some of these other figures he has been throwing around. It was 24 per cent—a higher tax take than there is now and a higher tax take than there will be, even after the full effect of all these measures works itself through in the way that Senator Kemp, Senator Short and everybody else have been getting excited about. Those opposite should contemplate that before they start throwing these figures around again, because they are going to come back and bite them.

PARA.TAB: I think Kerry O'Brien would be absolutely delighted to hear that behind every flyscreen door and window in Perth there were people watching his Lateline program on that fabled night of 19 November. It seems to be the assumption the opposition is making that the whole electorate was so moved by this particular statement, made in a particular context by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that they were led to—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the reason? Oh!

—Senator Kemp has not brought up any other examples. This is the quote used all the time. If he has some better ones, he should let us see them. The particular quote the opposition has been using was the one made on the Lateline program. On the face of it, taken out of context, it does seem to be the most stark and the most interesting for the opposition's particular purposes, but the point about that particular statement, which is the only one the opposition felt able or comfortable to quote and to repeat, is that it was made in a very specific context. For a start, it was made in response to a question about infrastructure spending and what kind of capacity there would be on the part of the government to do that. The context was not a question about what kind of revenue measures we have in mind, what we are going to do with direct taxes, or what we are going to do with indirect taxes.
—He says it.

—I am just making the point, little bit by little bit, in little dollops that those opposite will be able to understand, that the response was to a question about that. It was not in response to being asked, `What is your tax policy?', and it was not in response to a question about what we are going to do with particular individual taxes or tax rates.

PARA.TAB: The second point to make about it is that the words used by the Prime Minister were not words of precision, as has been acknowledged by Senator Short. He was saying, `What we want to do is maintain the tax to GDP ratio we roughly have at the moment'. He is talking in generalised language in a particular context where it is self-evidently the case that we are talking about the same orders of magnitude. de.

Moreover, we are talking in a context where the average tax take for the whole previous 10 years of this government had been over 24 per cent—24.2 per cent. If you look at those figures and add them up, I think that is the way the arithmetic falls out—24.2 per cent over the previous 10 years, starting with the 24 per cents, two in a row, from the Fraser administration, which we inherited. Let me read the figures into the record so that those opposite know: 24 per cent and 24 per cent for the last two years of the Fraser government; for the first year of our government, 1983-84, it dropped to 23.1 per cent; going down the list, it was then 24.6, 24.7, 25.3, 25.3, 24.7, 24.7, 24.5, 22.6 and 22.2 last year.

That is the particular context the Prime Minister was talking in—that average tax to GDP ratio coming out at around that 24 per cent. He was talking about roughly the environment he was confronting. So before we fiddle and fuss any longer and paw apart even further this poor benighted throwaway line of the Prime Minister's, any proper reading of it should acknowledge that particular context.

The further point, the obvious point, to make, moreover, is that not only is the tax take not going up this year, it is going down. How often do I have to repeat the point that it may have been 22.2 per cent last year; it may be, on the out-year projections, getting up to something less than it has been for the last 10 years and less than it was in the last couple of years of the Fraser government; but this year, when the immediate impact of all these petrol taxes and the wholesale tax and all the things the opposition is troubled about makes itself first apparent, the tax ratio to GDP actually goes down from 22.2 per cent to 21.9 per cent.

It is a pretty exotic little debating point that those opposite have been able to put together, with all the research resources available to them. I do not think it has persuaded anybody. It certainly has not persuaded me, and it is not going to persuade anyone listening to this debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the management and operation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I seek leave to have that document incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: For the information of honourable members, I present a statement containing the Government's response to the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Management and Operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
When this report was released last December, I welcomed it as a comprehensive vindication of the Department's management and, in particular, of its continuing management improvement program.

The report's examination of the issues and its recommendations constitute strong support for the direction and implementation of management changes in DFAT since the merger of the former Department of Foreign Affairs, the former Department of Trade and Promotion Australia (PA) in 1987. It provides strong support for the Department's program of modernisation and reform. I support the report's conclusion that the Department "must be given credit for the progress it has made" in managing changes which the Committee describes as "large and rapid".

A basic feature of the Department's reform program has been an openness to constructive ideas and to practical suggestions about how performance can be further improved. This is the spirit in which the Government has considered the report's recommendations.

By its own account the Committee's recommendations cover mainly "housekeeping" issues. For the most part the Government endorses these recommendations, and indeed has already implemented several of them. In the very few cases where the Government is not in a position to accept certain recommendations—for reasons of practicality or cost—we have sought to examine alternative ways in which the Committee's objectives could be met. The details are set out in the formal response which I have tabled.
Management Reform

The management of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is, by any measure, a complex endeavour. Its global reach is unique in the Australian public sector, as is its mix of policy advising, service delivery and public advocacy functions.

Such an operation is not managed by static systems. It requires flexibility and a practical, evolutionary approach. The management improvement program introduced in 1988—which has been endorsed by the Committee—was one part of this evolutionary process. It addressed the needs of a then newly amalgamated Department confronted additionally with declining resources and expanding demands.
Since then, many other changes have been introduced in areas such as staff development, program evaluation, information technology, and financial and accounting systems.

The Department is now a more open one with greater diversity in staff background and experience. Its personnel management systems have improved in terms of client service and collegiate decision making consistent with Industrial Democracy and EEO principles.

Most recently, the new Secretary has, with the full support of the all three Portfolio Ministers, moved quickly, in consultation with all staff, to initiate a comprehensive review of the Department's Corporate Plan, its capacity to pursue the Government's core economic and strategic interests, the match between resources and priorities, the role of its Senior Executive officers, and a range of other management issues including competency training, career satisfaction and work and family, or personal, responsibilities.
In all of this the Department's continuing objective is to ensure it has effective management systems operated by staff who are motivated, expert and flexible.
Staff Morale

Much of the Committee's report is devoted to the complex range of issues that affect staff morale at a time of rapid change and with multiple pressures upon Departmental management and staff. The major changes involved in merging two Departments and Promotion Australia, each with its own strong sense of history and organisational culture, inevitably brought with them challenges for all concerned.

Changes of this magnitude require a sustained sensitivity on the part of Departmental management to any consequences in terms of staff morale due to uncertainty about the new directions for the new organisation and each individual's place within it.

The creation of the new Department added a further layer to the range of complex issues surrounding management/staff relations in recent times, arising not only from implementation of the extensive public service reforms of the 1980's, but also from the simultaneous actions to enhance flexibility by abolishing the narrow career streams which had been a feature of the old Department of Foreign Affairs.

And now we have under way further major changes flowing from the Government's adoption of workplace bargaining and from the Department's pursuit of modernisation through the introduction of Information Technology.

Throughout this process I have encouraged the Department in its renewed focus on corporate identity, greater flexibility and stronger definition of standards of ethics, individual accountability and courtesy, consistent with the tenets of "New Professionalism" embraced by the APS as a whole.
Allegations of Corruption
As the Committee Chairman noted in his tabling statement, the Committee in its Inquiry devoted some considerable time in investigating many of the claims made by the so-called "DFAT Reform Group".
Allegations, by a former officer of the Department, of corruption within the Department played a major role in the establishment of the Senate Inquiry.
Previous investigations into these allegations by the Auditor General and by the Australian Federal Police had concluded that they had no basis.

The Committee arrived at the same conclusion, describing the allegations as "improper, reckless and likely to have damaged the reputations of individuals and to have been contrary to the public interest".
I welcome this exoneration of Departmental officers, and its associated acknowledgment of the integrity of Departmental systems.

I strongly agree with the Committee's recommendation that any further allegations about the Department by the so-called "DFAT Reform Group" should not be subject to further inquiry until "they provide substantive evidence to support the allegations".

Our public service disciplinary provisions, are underpinned by principles and values such as natural justice, fairness and equity. The Public Service Commission has stated that in keeping with these principles and values, "vexatious or unsupported allegations against the management and operations of a department should not be inquired into".

I welcome the Committee's balanced comments on the phenomenon of "whistle blowing". My Department's recent experience underlines the need to ensure that in protecting the rights of individuals to speak out, we also afford protection to the victims of false or malicious allegations, as well as to those involved in investigating the allegations.

The issue of safeguards for investigators is a particularly serious one. Investigators have been vilified while performing their tasks by leaks to the press and public figures, anonymous pamphlets, abusive phone calls, including to their families, and abuse in the work place.
Minority Report
Finally, let me say that the minority report attached to the Committee's report, while not unexpected, is nevertheless disappointing.
It reflects, at best, only grudging acceptance of the very significant improvements that have been introduced into the Department over the last few years, and documented in the main report.
It would appear that some critics are simply not prepared to allow the facts to speak for themselves.

The report's thirty-three recommendations are grouped under six headings: Departmental Reorganisation; Allegations by the DFAT Reform Group; Personnel Management Issues; General Management Issues; Conditions of Service Issues; Disciplinary Systems and Standards of Conduct. I have followed this format in responding to the recommendations.
RECOMMENDATIONS
Departmental Reorganisation
Recommendation 1
If the Government decides to retain a specialist public relations capacity within DFAT, it should do so in such a way as to maintain a viable core of specialisation within a single branch;
Recommendation 2
That branch be given clear and unambiguous objectives related to the undertaking of specific public relations campaigns and activities (Paragraph 3.66).
Response

The Government concurs with the merits of concentrating core public affairs specific functions within a single branch in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade . The Overseas Information Branch is in the process of developing a set of objectives which relate directly to the aims, goals and priority tasks of the Department as a whole. Its performance against those objectives will be monitored closely.
Allegations by the DFAT Reform Group
Recommendation 3

No Commonwealth investigative or administrative review agency inquire into any further allegations about DFAT made by Mr Carroll or the DFAT Reform Group unless and until they provide substantive evidence to support the allegations (Paragraph 5.35).
Response
The Government supports this recommendation. It should be noted, however, that there may be some investigative or review bodies which have no discretion to refuse to investigate a complaint.
Personnel Management Issues
Recommendation 4
DFAT bring together its various staff welfare initiatives into a specific sub-program directly answerable to the appropriate Deputy Secretary position (Paragraph 7.18).
Response
The Government supports the substance of the Committee's recommendation.

A small Welfare and Occupational Health and Safety (OH&S) unit has already been created, and a new position of Staff Counsellor will shortly be filled. The occupant will be a suitably qualified professional who will provide a confidential counselling service on personal and workplace problems for all Departmental staff and their families both in Canberra and at overseas posts. These positions, together with those of the Family Liaison Officer (FLO), Medical Adviser and Careers Adviser form a network of staff welfare positions which consult closely and meet periodically with the First Assistant Secretary, Corporate Services Division (FAS/CSD) and PA/CSD to review staff welfare policy and issues.
Recommendation 5

DFAT adapt its Statement of Service publication into a skills register by seeking basic information on postings, educational qualifications and other skills in standard format from all members of its staff and by maintaining that information in a sortable format (Paragraph 7.29).
Response

The Statement of Service publication has a different function from that of a skills register. It is a quick reference for obtaining personal and career information on officers. Much of the information currently contained in the publication is not relevant to a skills register and in its current format it would not be possible to interrogate it as one would a data base.
The resources which would have to be devoted to developing and maintaining a new and dedicated skills register which would meet staff and management expectations would be significant.

Much of the information likely to be included on a skills register is readily available in various forms in the Department. In particular, the PERSPECT personnel information system that is used in the Department captures much of this information (e.g. relevant personnel information, placements in the Department, language skills, educational qualifications, training undertaken).
The Department has decided to conduct a skills audit of all staff in order to identify current and medium term training needs.
Recommendation 6

In its response to this report, the Government report on the effectiveness of the development diary system with particular regard to whether there is scope for making the essential components of the system mandatory and whether there is scope for extending the system to SES officers (Paragraph 7.34);
Response

The Department accepts the case for making the essential components of the system mandatory. The appraisal section of the diary is being re-designed for universal and mandatory use, consistent with the performance appraisal mechanisms established under the agreement between the Government and the PSU of December 1992.
The Department always intended that the development diary appraisal process should apply to SES officers.

In the case of heads of mission, appraisal input will be drawn from a wide range of sources, including post clients inside and outside DFAT. The comprehensive annual Post Evaluation Report process will be used as an initial basis for judgements to be made on a HOM's performance against agreed post objectives. Final judgements will be made by the Department's Executive in a moderation process to ensure fair and consistent standards are applied to all HOM's. The post objectives will constitute a performance agreement between each HOM and the Department.
Recommendation 7

Completion of the appraiser's self-assessment in DFAT's development diary to be made mandatory with a requirement that it be countersigned by the person being appraised, with provision for that person to comment if he or she wishes, and a requirement for review by the appraiser's supervisor (Paragraph 7.35).
Response

The Department supports the concept of mandatory upward assessment, but would wish to consult formally with staff before introducing such a system. Existing Public Service wide arrangements do not make formal provision for self appraisal, nor for any form of upward appraisal.
Recommendation 8

DFAT, OPG and the Department of Finance jointly review the feasibility of allowing at least some officers to receive an allowance and rent their own accommodation instead of residing in government-supplied residential accommodation at posts where it could reasonably be expected that officers do so (paragraph 8.17).
Response

A number of DFAT officers already receive an allowance and rent their own accommodation overseas instead of residing in Government-supplied residential accommodation. This occurs mainly in London and in North American posts.

OPG has expressed the view that, for most countries, Government owned or leased accommodation will remain the most cost-effective means of providing staff accommodation. A copy of a paper prepared by OPG on this issue is attached.

The Department of Finance has pointed out that a potential difficulty it has with the extension of private leasing arrangements is that it may be cheaper for the Commonwealth, over the long term, to own houses rather than lease them.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade nevertheless has explored the feasibility of extending private leasing arrangements. In looking at this issue the Department concluded that it should be confined to countries where:

PARA.TAB: the local leasing arrangements are similar to those in Australia and officers could be reasonably expected to negotiate leases without any special background knowledge of local conditions;
the leases are written in English and the negotiations carried out in English;
the conclusion of personal leases for foreigners is normal practice among the diplomatic community in the relevant city;
the laws governing the personal liability of officers in leasing accommodation are comparable to those in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Other overseas operating agencies concur with DFAT's approach.
General Management Issues
Recommendation 9
DFAT account for passport fee revenue in a way that separates the components of the fee which apply to passport production costs, consular services, and the remainder of the fee (Paragraph 8.26).
Response
The costing details provided in the attached Passports Australia Business Plan annually details the cost components of passport production and issue.

The problems of precisely stating the costs of consular services are considerable. Consular workload is unpredictable, the majority of our posts have no officers dedicated to consular functions, consular functions are also undertaken by officers of DFAT, DIEA and AUSTRADE overseas and costs can also be incurred by other Commonwealth Agencies (eg Defence in the provision of evacuation aircraft.)

The Committee's recommendation that full transparency of costs be provided is partially met now by the detail contained in the annual Passport's Australia Business Plan. As revised program structures for the Department are introduced and as accrual accounting systems are developed the Committee's interest in a substantial, but not total, identification of Consular costs should be satisfied.
Recommendation 10
Australia have a standard passport with a system of endorsements to certify the position held by or status of the person to whom the passport is issued (Paragraph 8.31).
Recommendation 11

There should also be the option of some distinctive endorsement to be embossed on the covers of passports issued to Australian officers posted overseas, especially where such an endorsement might offer operational advantage or increased safety (Paragraph 8.31).
Response

Special passports are recognised by all international states and are used by the majority of international states and this convention affords universal recognition for Australian officials travelling overseas on behalf of the Government. The circumstances whereby security and operational efficiency of officers would be enhanced by the abolition of special passports and introduction of another special "one off" restricted passport category for staff posted overseas, have not been established. The current categories of special passports provide operational flexibility for all overseas travel and posting needs, including areas of specific security concerns, cost effectively. The status of documents proved to be particularly important during the Iraq conflict.
Recommendation 12

DFAT comment in detail in its 1992-93 Annual Report on the measures it has taken to improve its records and information-retrieval systems and provide evidence of the success of those measures (Paragraph 8.38).
Response
The Department accepts this recommendation and details of measures taken to improve records keeping will be included in the 1992-93 Annual Report.
Recommendation 13

The Government response to this report outlines the measures taken by DFAT to ensure that its methods of payment of locally engaged staff do not breach or facilitate breaches of taxation law in Australia or overseas (paragraph 8.44).
Response

The Government understands the Committee's concerns about the Department's responsibilities under Australian Taxation Law in relation to payments to locally employed staff employed at Missions overseas. The Committee is aware that efforts to rectify the problem were "clearly hampered" by contemporaneous change to Australian taxation legislation. Since the report was tabled in late 1992 efforts to improve the situation have continued.

On 22 March 1993 the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), in consultation with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), issued an Administrative Circular (No. 24/93) on the Australian taxation of Australian resident Locally Engaged Staff (LES). A copy of Administrative Circular 24/93 is attached.

Administrative Circular 24/93 set out the procedures which DFAT-managed posts must implement to ensure that DFAT meets ATO requirements in relation to the Australian taxation of Australian resident LES notably :
LES employed at DFAT managed posts will be required to complete a `Questionnaire' to establish Australian residency and Australian income tax liability; and
Australian resident LES who are assessed to be liable to pay Australian income tax will be required to complete a `Declaration of Income' form which DFAT will pass to the ATO on an annual basis.
These new arrangements are to be applied on a retrospective basis to take in all salaries and wages paid to LES in the 1992-93 financial year.

Procedures established by Administrative Circular 24/93 cover all LES engaged at DFAT managed posts including LES who may be performing all, or some of their duties, on behalf of other Government departments or agencies. The ATO intends to establish similar reporting mechanisms with other overseas operating agencies of Government which manage offices overseas independent of DFAT and employ LES.

In terms of LES who are not considered to be Australian residents (and who are normally citizens of the host country) DFAT will continue to observe local laws which vary widely from country to country. From time to time posts may be requested by host governments to provide details of salaries and conditions payed to LES.
Recommendation 14

DFAT, in reporting on the activities of its Evaluation and Audit Section in its 1992-93 Annual Report, comment on the extent to which its internal audit program has been aligned with the audit priorities of the Australian National Audit Office (paragraph 8.58).
Response
The Government accepts this recommendation and will include relevant material in its 1992-93 Annual Report.
Recommendation 15

All cases of apparently unauthorised release of information within DFAT's area of responsibility be recorded in the Department's list of leak investigations, including the release of information on individual current or former members of the Department's staff and the release of information other than by DFAT officers.
Response

All cases of apparently unauthorised release of information are recorded and investigated, and that record is kept up to date. In some cases the matter is forwarded to the Minister responsible for approval to enlist the services of the AFP to conduct further investigations.

The Government will ensure that all cases under investigation involving apparently unauthorised releases of information within DFAT's area of responsibility are recorded in the schedule, including releases of information other than by DFAT officers which become known to the Department.
