It is time to stem the flow; it is time to get right behind Australian ideas and Australian industry. It is time for a genuinely activist export strategy.

More than that, one of the continuing major disappointments from this government has been the absolute lack of interest in import replacement. Merchandise imports have risen another 17 per cent over the last year, during a recession or a very slow recovery. What will happen if or when we ever take off? This budget does nothing to address this side of the equation at all. As soon as anybody mentions import replacement, the standard response is, `Oh, so you want to return to sheltering behind the walls of tariffs'. That sort of response is, once again, like the level playing field, intellectually bankrupt and economically incompetent.

Let me be quite clear about those who might be tempted to misrepresent our position. The Democrats have never suggested a return to the across-the-board high protection era of the 1960s and 1970s. We say that it is not good enough for the government, with the complete support of the Liberal and National parties, to merrily go about dismantling protective barriers without having a strategic industry policy in place. By doing this we have done nothing but set ourselves up to lose.

The Democrats have fought a lone hand against economic rationalism in this parliament. We remember what it was like sitting there for eight years while the two major parties voted together. But the evidence is in—they were both wrong and the country is now recognising it. The work of my colleague Senator Spindler in the area of tariffs, trade and industry development—work which this government and this opposition has ridiculed and tried to stymie—has been comprehensive in exposing the failure of this government on industry policy. Let me quote an article written by Trevor Sykes in this week's Bulletin magazine. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: For the past decade Australia has been running probably the world's most stupid foreign trade policy. In the sacred cause of free trade we have slashed tariffs unilaterally while other countries have largely maintained their import barriers. The policy we have been following is the economic equivalent of trying to be the only virgin in a very big brothel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—Mr Trevor Sykes, in this week's Bulletin.
—I would not know anything about that.

—Thank you, Senator Harradine. The bottom line is that it is about time this government and the coalition woke up on industry policy and joined the real world. There are a range of measures available to us—measures in complete compliance with GATT—which curb imports and create Australian jobs. But this government has not even seriously explored them. Those measures do include the selective provision of tariffs on a sector by sector basis. Government purchasing policy should give preference to Australian products. Anti-dumping measures, labelling laws and import quality controls should be stiffened. These are measures used all over the world.

PARA.TAB: A good starting point may simply be a register of national imports. How can we tell what it may be possible to even produce in this country if we cannot even identify quickly and easily what is coming into this country? In short, I recommend Senator Spindler's report on tariffs and industry development to everybody in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the name of that report?
—It is a parliamentary inquiry. Senator Spindler's work shows that by adopting a strategically interventionist industry policy in this country we can create jobs, and it is high time we did so.

PARA.TAB: It is hard to make real progress without the solid foundation of a decent accessible education system. Nothing demonstrates the government's poverty of ideas more clearly than its illogical and short-sighted education policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you support them all the time?

—Senator Macdonald supports the government on education; this is where we feel differently. This government persists in seeing education as a mere money making commodity. Who voted for the higher education contribution scheme? Senator Macdonald and the Labor Party. HECS will hit students with crippling debt levels and education penalties and exacerbate the situation where students in higher education are being rushed through the system at breakneck speed in much the same way as products come off a conveyer belt.

PARA.TAB: After this budget students will be expected to repay their HECS debt faster and sooner and they will face further financial penalties if they fail to complete courses within a minimum time. There are increases in the rate of the HECS repayment and a lowering of the threshold at which students begin to repay their HECS debt, all at a time when graduate starting salaries are at a 16-year low. Students who want to undertake second degrees will have to think long and hard about whether or not it is worth being slugged with a double HECS debt. Students who fail to complete their courses within a minimum time face a 50 per cent increase in their HECS payment for each additional unit.

These measures will have a significant effect on the ability of women to enter and complete tertiary education. Women are already five times less likely than men to repay their HECS debt by the age of 30. Yet here we have the government introducing measures which discriminate against women, particularly those of mature age, who are likely to have interrupted periods of study because of domestic and employment commitments.

A key to ensuring equity of access in post-compulsory education is student financial assistance. The extension of the loans scheme in this budget signals the phasing out of Austudy grants. In addition, the abolition of secondary Austudy for 16-year-olds will affect over 130,000 students. Students who are eligible for assistance under the family payments scheme will lose at least $4 a week as a result of this measure and students from rural areas risk losing their benefits altogether with the application of a different assets test limit.

The Democrats do not support the continued erosion of student financial assistance. Education is an investment in the future of this country. In addition, further deregulation of postgraduate courses and inadequate research funding really do expose the lie in the government's commitment to the so-called clever country.

Funding cuts to adult literacy programs are astonishingly short-sighted when 10 to 20 per cent of our population is functionally illiterate. Increases in charges for English as a second language courses make absolutely no sense if we want to ensure that people migrating to this country can contribute as active citizens. These moves are not sensible. Ultimately, they will not even be cost effective. They represent cost cutting desperation from members of a cash strapped government, most of whom, I might add, like most of us here in this chamber, got their education for free. I take great pride in saying that this budget confirms the Democrats as the only political party that is committed to a fair and accessible education system for all Australians.

In terms of the health portfolio, we have the charming thought of the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) playing footsy every month with the AMA. I really worry about whose interests will be served in this respect; it certainly does not seem to be the patients' or the taxpayers' interests, if the two major health measures in the budget are anything to go by.

Firstly, the government has announced that it is ending the $42 Medicare rebate for basic eye tests other than for pensioners and health care card holders. The estimated saving is meant to be $48 million this financial year and $90 million next financial year. Quite clearly, this is a cynical, desperate cost-cutting exercise. Senator Richardson does not seem too concerned; he knows this.

The plan is also, if you will excuse the pun, extraordinarily short-sighted because it will result in a decline in the eye health of Australians. Eye diseases will go undetected as people defer their eye care because of the cost. It will place a substantial additional financial burden on families where eye conditions are hereditary or where children suffer from ongoing eye problems.

One optometrist has written to me that he knows of many children whose vision problems have actually caused learning delays of several years. What does that ultimately cost the community? This leads me to seriously question whether savings can genuinely be made here. Aside from those extra costs brought about when children and adults neglect their eye care, it could easily be the case that, instead of going to an optometrist, people will end up seeing an ophthalmologist via a referral from their GP at three or four times the cost of Medicare. That is some great saving.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will get expert advice.

—So optometrists cannot give expert advice. That is interesting. Optometrists have been very good Medicare providers, agreeing some years back to charge no more than the Medicare fee for their services and managing to keep the out-of-pocket expenses of their patients well below that of other health service providers. They have done the right thing by this government and health consumers, and they have every reason to be angry about being singled out ahead of other providers. We also see this plan as being the thin edge of the wedge in setting up a two-tiered health care system. We will not wear it for reasons that we have outlined time and again in this place.

PARA.TAB: The second budget health measure which concerns us greatly is the government's proposal to establish peer review measures to deal with Medicare rorts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on, tell us. Don't tease, Cheryl.

—Senator Bishop knows all about that. As my colleague Meg Lees said yesterday, the new measures announced by Senator Richardson to combat fraud and overservicing in Medicare represent a significant backdown by the government. It appears that the minister has managed to ignore the Auditor-General, the Health Insurance Commission and his own department in one fell swoop and opt for the soft line.

PARA.TAB: I can only say that I agree with Meredith Carter from the Health Issues Centre and Jenny Blakey from the Welfare Rights Unit in Victoria, who today pointed out the very different approaches the government takes in dealing with social security fraud and medifraud. Ms Carter and Ms Blakey quite rightly accuse the government of hypocrisy for its continuing refusal to legislate to treat medical fraud in the same way that it treats any other fraud of the public purse.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?
—This is one area that we will look very closely at in the coming weeks. We will be able to show—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. As a matter of clarification, did Senator Kernot tell us that she was going to vote against the measure? Can she clarify that for us?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Senator Bishop, that is not a point of order, and you know quite well that it is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to show the government where it can make money.
—Are you going to vote against it?
—Of course we will vote against the optometry proposal.
—And against the fuel tax?
—I am coming to that. I am using my 30-minute time limit, thank you very much.

PARA.TAB: Finally, in terms of tax, we have had confirmed in this budget that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) went through the election campaign misleading the public about the affordability of his income tax cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

—The opposition voted for them. He pretended that he could deliver income tax cuts to match the coalition without needing a GST and spending cuts, but he left out those who earn less than $20,700. It is true that the Treasurer was a trifle more circumspect about the probable need for tax hikes in other areas, but circumspect is something that the Prime Minister certainly was not. We now have the unedifying spectacle of regressive income tax cuts being paid for by even more regressive indirect tax hikes. Mr Keating has the temerity to ask, `What is not Labor about that? What is not Labor about this budget?'. Indeed, looking at Mr Keating's record, he is probably right. This is just another unfair Labor budget.

PARA.TAB: The real effect of Labor's reform of income tax rates since 1983 has been a redistribution of income away from lower and middle income groups. One reason—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I understood that the Senate determined by a majority—that is, the Labor Party voting with the Australian Democrats—that we could each only speak for 20 minutes. Senator Kernot seems to have gone longer than 20 minutes. She was most definite at the time about restricting us to 20 minutes, indicating that anyone who wanted to get across a message could easily do it in 20 minutes. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask for your ruling. Is Senator Kernot allowed to proceed longer than 20 minutes?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—The 20-minute time limit is for second reading speeches only.

TALK.START.PARA: —The real effect of Labor's reform of the income tax rates since 1983 has been a redistribution of income away from lower and middle income groups. One reason for this is that the real value of the tax free threshold has been reduced.

PARA.TAB: It is estimated that about 320,000 taxpayers have been brought into the tax net during the last 10 years. When this government first won office, the tax free threshold was 25.3 per cent of average weekly earnings. In 1992-93, tax was paid from 17 per cent of average weekly earnings. Those on extremely high incomes of $240,000 are now paying about $24,000 less tax per year than before Labor came to office. Perhaps this budget is the icing on the cake, but this time the cake has not risen.
In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, Geoff Kitney wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: John Dawkins has delivered a Budget that makes those hardest hit by the recession worse off and offers no hope to the unemployed.
In the same newspaper, Alan Ramsey wrote:

. . . those really shafted are Labor's own people, the supposed True Believers, the blue-collar families and individuals lower down the income scale who wouldn't trust John Hewson and voted in their tens of thousands for Paul Keating . . .

One could observe that in Fightback at least Dr Hewson paid considerable attention—not enough, but considerable attention—to the issue of compensation for those hit hardest by his indirect tax, the GST. But what have we seen from this government: a wonderful, miserable, $100 tax rebate to compensate for massive hikes in sales and petrol taxes. It is universally and quite rightly condemned as being not good enough, and the Australian Democrats will not wear it.

PARA.TAB: I give notice that I will be seeking to at least double that $100 tax rebate for low income earners. To pay for this increase the Democrats will seek to vary the thresholds at which the new, lower income tax rates for upper income earners will start; that is, we will try to take away a part of the tax cut for those who do not need it, around $30,000, and deliver the benefit to lower income earners so they can keep their heads above water. The government has wrapped its petrol price hikes in a cloak of green rhetoric. What a joke!

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry Senator Watson, $50,000 down to $30,000. We all accept that we must lower lead levels. The health of our children depends on it. This is a matter which the Democrats have been hammering away at for years; we are not Johnny-come-latelys on this environmental health debate. The Democrats believe that we must be green without being mean.

PARA.TAB: How are we going to lower lead levels if we make it impossible for those who drive cars which run on leaded petrol to change over to unleaded vehicles? The combination of the halving of leaded petrol car values, which has happened overnight, and 10c per litre increase in super fuel in 18 months without any adequate compensatory measures is just counterproductive. We will be discussing this issue widely with consumer, health, environment and welfare groups. We are also looking for ways to quarantine or lessen the impact of the petrol price hikes on rural Australians.

In closing I will briefly mention two more contentious tax measures which the government has put forward in this budget. We are concerned about the immediate, unannounced introduction and the retrospective impact of the changes to the tax treatment of unused long service leave and holiday entitlements.

We are also concerned about the impact of the massive increase in sales tax on wine. We have previously opposed the increases in sales tax on wine, and I guess the bottom line would be to try to legislate a phased increase in the sales tax level. However, on that matter—and please check the record—every time the wine excise has gone up in the past the opposition has voted for it.

There has been a lot of speculation about how the Senate will treat the budget legislation. We have heard the announcement from the Liberal Leader Dr Hewson this evening about the taxes that the Liberals are going to block. I think it is quite silly to lock oneself into a position without sufficient evidence, but what I will say is that because of the opposition's announcement tonight we will be visited by that ancient Chinese curse: may you live in interesting times. In this place in the next few months we certainly will.
Debate (on motion by Senator Schacht) adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—The President has received letters from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate concerning an appointment to a vacancy on the Committee of Privileges.
Motion (by Senator Schacht)—by leave—agreed to:
That, pursuant to standing order 18, Senator Archer be appointed a member of the Committee of Privileges.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was outlining to the Senate a range of positive initiatives in the budget, which apparently members of the opposition have not read, directed at assisting the rural sector. These initiatives clearly demonstrate the government's consideration and understanding of the rural sector in this country.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I do not want to comment on the broad expanse of the budget in this debate, I would say, in regard to the three contributions that have been made earlier tonight, that whilst I do not agree with a considerable amount of Senator Kernot's contribution or indeed Senator Boswell's contribution, at least they do play to the main game. All I can say about the contribution of Senator Hill—and I am sure it was reflected in Dr Hewson's speech—is that we could best summarise their attitude as one of venting their spleen. If that is the way the opposition is going to approach the government of this country over the next three years, well I rather pity it. If it continues to adopt that attitude, then it will lose the next election.

Senator Boswell's major contribution did make reference to a couple of points that are pertinent to this issue of assistance to the rural sector. I want to make reference to a couple of those matters before I conclude my remarks. Firstly, he made reference to opposition to the so-called retrospective application of the tax on untaken long service leave and annual leave. That is a bit rich coming from the opposition, given that we consistently get complaints from the opposition that it does not believe in long service leave. Whilst the opposition does accept a certain amount of annual leave, it is fairly nebulous in its approach to annual leave.

Senator Boswell made a big song and dance about a one per cent administration fee on the diesel fuel rebate. But the fact is that the diesel fuel rebate will cost over $100 million more as a result of this budget. There is a relatively minor affect of the administrative charge; it is less than one per cent of the total payout of the diesel fuel rebate to the farming community. Despite that administrative charge, it will still cost another $100 million. That is a recognition of the unique position that the rural community has in the Australian economy.

There are a number of programs that I referred to before dinner that I want to comment upon now. I referred to the Tasmanian wheat freight subsidy scheme. I referred to the rural adjustment scheme. I do not know how Senator Boswell reads the budget, but he actually claims that in the budget there is actually a cut in funding; there is actually an increase in funding. Much of the additional moneys will go to state governments and, as Senator Boswell acknowledged, it is being kept in hollow logs. We have paying money over to the states since 1982 and they have not been reimbursing that money to the farming sector in the proper way. The government is now insisting that they do that. In addition to that, we are putting aside an extra allocation for the rural adjustment scheme; yet the opposition is complains.

Senator Boswell made absolutely no reference to the reforms of the Australian Quarantine Service, AQIS. As I mentioned earlier, there will be a massive change to the approach of the Quarantine Service which will lead to a freeze on charges over the next four years and a reduction in charges in many areas.

I was at the rural press club breakfast this morning and many in the audience were quite praiseworthy of our approach to the AQIS reforms; yet there is no word of acknowledgment of those reforms from Senator Boswell or Senator Brownhill. As those on the other side know, AQIS charges is the issue about which we get the most representations and most correspondence; yet there was not one mention about it by the opposition tonight. They like to conveniently forget these sorts of important structural reforms that are taking place.

There are a couple of other programs that I would like to mention. These were actually contained in our election manifesto. Again we are accused of not implementing our election promises. These matters were included in our election policy platform and they are three of 10 election promises that I referred to and read out earlier tonight.

I refer to the three new programs to enhance our export industries in the agribusiness sector. Firstly, there is the world best practice incentive scheme. This is a central component of this government's agribusiness development initiatives. It will accelerate the introduction in Australia of a culture based on world best practice by encouraging groups at all levels of the production chain to benchmark their current practices against equivalent practices overseas. Secondly, we have the rural development incentive scheme which is focused on encouraging community and regional business groups to identify local development opportunities. Thirdly, we have the rural enterprise network program. Those are three new programs being funded to the sum of $22.6 million over the next four years.

I have taken quite a considerable personal interest in the clean food export program. One of the central thrusts for this country over the next decade is to improve our export program in the food industries, and central to that is the clean food export program. As part of that program this government has announced funding of $5 million for a special pilot promotion to be launched in Taiwan. Taiwan has been targeted as a market for this program. I am not going to speak in detail on this matter tonight, but it is a very interesting program and it will certainly be useful to see the sorts of results that come from this approach. There is an ongoing commitment in this budget to a range of horticultural programs, including the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the Horticultural Policy Council and the task force of which I am chair which is currently examining a range of horticultural industries.

Before I go back to the 31 initiatives, I make a comment on the alleged increase in the wool tax. When we put the wool package through earlier this year, 15 or 16 opposition senators commented on the wool tax package and certainly demonstrated a fairly significant knowledge of that package. I can recall a number of opposition members referring to the fact that the package contained a reduction of the prescribed wool tax—which is 12 per cent—to a rate of 8.5 per cent for one year only. Yet we had media releases from the opposition touting the proposition that this budget contained an increase in the wool tax. That is not correct. There has been no increase in the wool tax.

The current prescribed tax level in the legislation is 12 per cent. It will revert from 8.5 per cent to 12 per cent at the end of this financial year. There is nothing new in that. I have here the minister's press statement which was released in April. When we debated that issue earlier in the year, those opposite demonstrated an understanding of that. But they conveniently forget that in the budget context and for the purposes of this debate.

Indeed, those opposite conveniently forget the range of positive programs that is contained in this budget. As I warned them earlier tonight—and I do it quite sincerely—they continue to generalise, they continue to assume that all is wrong. The motion reflects `a total lack of consideration and understanding'. One cannot come to that conclusion from reading this budget.

I have read out the programs for which this budget has provided funding and I will do so again because it is apparent that those opposite have not read the initiatives contained in the budget for the rural sector. The enhanced rural adjustment scheme—RAS as it is commonly known—has received an increase in funding from approximately $200 million to $400 million. Other measures include programs to enhance agribusiness—an election commitment; boosting the clean food export program—another election commitment; assistance to isolated children; the rural counselling program—another election commitment; upgrading rural telecommunications—another election commitment; telecentres—another election commitment. In the area of rural development there will be an evaluation of community based approaches—another election commitment. There will be an overhaul of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and an overhaul of the Australian Geological Survey Organisation.

Efficiency gains in the department is a matter which those opposite have not mentioned tonight. The administrative costs of the department are being reduced by 20 per cent. For an opposition that is continually crying out for efficiencies in government administration, that is a very significant reduction in the administrative costs of the department. The budget further includes: savings in the Bureau of Resource Sciences; cost recovery for managing Commonwealth fisheries; reductions in the Australian Fisheries Management Authority staffing—again, the opposition failed to even acknowledge that; fisheries research and development improvements; a national residue survey—very critical in terms of our export performance; energy and greenhouse initiatives—another election commitment; and the national Landcare program. Senator Boswell seemed to scoff at that program earlier this evening.

One of the things that impressed me in my position as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy when visiting rural and regional Australia over the past four months is the clear cultural shift in the rural community towards landcare over the past decade. It has been very widely embraced and almost universally praised. We continue to expand that program in this budget. A further budget measure relates to the Murray-Darling Basin natural resources management strategy—another critical initiative to overcome many of the problems faced in the Murray-Darling Basin area because of the overlapping political jurisdictions.

There is the New South Wales flood mitigation; there has been no mention of that from the opposition. That is another election commitment. There is the national registration scheme for chemicals which is very important in the context of a clean food strategy and ensuring the acceptance of our exports overseas. There is the new horticultural funding—an election commitment—and the Tasmanian wheat freight subsidy scheme. Senator Calvert has just walked into the chamber. What about the scaremongering that went on about this program from the Tasmanian senators? They thought that the Tasmanian wheat freight subsidy was going to be abolished.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say a word about it.
—Senator Calvert did not but some of his colleagues did. Here it is in the budget; $2.7 million is provided.
—What about Alcorso's wine industry? What did you do to him? You put a 10 per cent increase on his bill.
—We will get to the wine industry in this debate.
—Senator Calvert, we were having a nice time until a few minutes ago.

—I pay credit to the new member for Lyons, Mr Dick Adams, who fought long and hard to make sure this scheme was kept for Tasmania. The challenge was taken up by those opposite: what were we doing about preserving the wheat freight subsidy scheme? Here it is in the budget. The budget contains measures relating to primary industry research and development corporations and councils and forestry postgraduate research awards. There are 31 initiatives in this budget, 10 of which are election promises. I have outlined the approach on the alleged increase in the wool tax; there simply is not an increase in the wool tax and those opposite know it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza participated in that debate earlier this year and he well knows the context in which the prescribed 12 per cent wool tax was reduced to 8. 5 per cent. He well knows the circumstances and he should not try to claim that it has been increased in this budget, because it has not.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the wording of the motion before us this evening that there has been `a total lack of consideration and understanding of the rural sector demonstrated in the 1993-94 budget' cannot be sustained. There is significant assistance to rural and regional Australia in this budget. Later on in this debate my colleagues Senator West and Senator Carr will be highlighting other positive initiatives and exposing the deceptions and the misleading comments of those opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Brownhill's motion, but I do have some concerns about the absolute language which he uses in the motion. I understand Senator Sherry's frustration with such words as `a total lack of consideration and understanding'. The Australian Democrats support some measures in this budget, such as counselling services and the abolition of the assets test for isolated students.

PARA.TAB: I have learned over the years to be very suspicious of over the top and absolute statements. However, given this qualification, I am still prepared to support the direction of the motion because it is correct in stating:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the increases in taxes and charges will have devastating effects on the people in rural and regional Australia . . .

Regardless of whether the government tinkers at the edges of the problem, as this budget does, the situation in the bush remains that the people, the industry, the families and the communities are desperate. There are families who, going back generations, have never asked for help in their lives, but who are asking for that kind of help now.

PARA.TAB: When in St George a week ago I talked to a number of cotton growers who are some of the best farm managers in Australia. One of them, a friend of mine for many years and someone who would never ask for help, said to me, `We will cope with this drought as long as you can prevent any increase in taxes and charges. We just cannot cop any further increase in our overhead costs'.

Over the past few weeks, government ministers, such as Simon Crean and Graham Richardson, have visited centres in western Queensland. To their credit they have listened to the people and expressed concern. They promised to make sure that bureaucratic blocks to assistance and social security would be removed. But I need to remind this house that rural families have special needs and so often that assistance and those social security allowances do not reach them.

I give another example of a family in Bollon. At the moment the three sons are living in Toowoomba, which is 500 kilometres away. They receive Jobsearch allowance and they cannot find a job. The family is desperate for them to go home because they certainly need help. Yet, if they go home, they will lose the Jobsearch allowance. If they go home, the family will not even have enough income to feed them. I know the father, and he is so close to the edge. If this were an isolated example, then one could dismiss it. But the same story is repeated over and over again across Australia.

Although we recognise some minor assistance in this budget, in terms of the situation which we face in Australia, in terms of the desperation of thousands of families and hundreds of rural communities, the budget simply does not even come close. I know that it is difficult to design a social safety net to cover every circumstance, but I believe that for the sake of rural families it is worth trying.

This morning I asked a question of the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Although I give him credit for trying, he did not seem to fully understand the point I was making. So I want to put it on the record. Under this budget 16-year-old students at secondary schools will no longer receive Austudy; rather they will be paid through the family payments system. There are two problems with this. Firstly, the level of benefit payable to those students under Austudy used to be $64.90 per week. This will be cut to $60.80 per week, made up of about $10 in basic family payment and $50 in additional family payment, and it is available only if parental income is below $21,000.

Secondly—and this is the serious issue—the assets limit on Austudy is around $700,000, whereas the new assets limit to apply for the basic family payment has just been slashed to $550,000 in this budget. Worse still, the assets limit on the additional family payment is just $363,500. The majority of farms are nominally worth far more than those asset levels but are still producing very low levels of income. I am concerned that much of the saving, which the government estimates at $5 million for this year and $20 million, $24 million and $27 million respectively for the next three years, will come from the pockets of rural students at a time when they can least afford it.

What the minister did say was that the government has removed the assets test from the supplementary boarding allowance paid under the assistance for isolated children scheme. We applaud this, but the government is simply not consistent. The minister's press release announcing this initiative stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is to ensure that people living in isolated areas were not excluded from receiving additional financial assistance for schooling because of assets that yielded little or no income.

We agree with the minister. That is a very good principle, and the Australian Democrats have been saying that for a long time. Now I want him to apply the same principle to our 16-year-old rural students. Indeed, the principle should be extended to a whole range of allowances and social security payments. I trust that this time, if we bring that initiative into this chamber, the coalition will support us. Finally, I am glad that Senator Brownhill has proposed this motion in the Senate, but I want to be assured that his words and those of other members of the opposition will be backed by action. The Democrats will look for the opposition's support to this end in the coming weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion proposed by Senator Brownhill is fundamentally flawed. To suggest that there is a total lack of consideration and understanding of the rural sector by the government is patently untrue. This is a simplistic motion which recognises neither the positive benefits for rural Australians contained in the budget nor the breadth of services provided by the Labor government to rural Australians.

PARA.TAB: What we have heard from the opposition tonight is that the cuts did not go deep enough. Its view of economic policy is to slash and burn. Its view of economic policy is to deprive Australians of government services. Its concern is to deprive the people of this country of the benefits that can only be provided by the state. The opposition's view is that the government should stay out of the affairs of the economy, particularly in rural Australia. This is a tough budget for tough times. But this budget, despite these tough times, has good news for rural Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about it.
—I will. It will position our agriculture and resources industry to become more productive, more profitable, more export oriented and environmentally sustainable.
—It will put up prices.

—The major initiatives have already been outlined tonight, but I will go over them again because it is quite clear that some people have not understood. These initiatives include: $406 million to be provided over four years for the rural adjustment scheme, an increase of $200 million; $22 million for the agribusiness development program; $105 million for the national landcare program; and $1.3 million for the clean food export program. A host of other initiatives are included in better service delivery to rural industries, such as a more efficient Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Further, the government's regional development strategy will benefit from a $2.8 million boost.

PARA.TAB: The recently announced Commonwealth task force on regional development has been allocated $900,000. It will provide a major focus to develop industry in rural Australia. It needs to be said that, in spite of the opposition's rhetoric, the government has retained the diesel fuel rebate to primary producers, reducing fuel costs to that sector by $900 million.

The Liberal and National parties are shackled in any debate on rural communities by the narrowness of their vision as to who the rural communities are. The interests of the rural sector are much broader than the farm gate. We have heard nothing tonight from Senator Brownhill about workers in rural Australia. We have heard nothing about the sorts of conditions which many people in this country are facing. Their view of the rural sector consists mainly of farmers and excludes the citizens of rural cities and towns.

Let us just look at a few of the 100 election promises and commitments delivered in the current budget which will give direct benefits to rural Australians. In terms of employment, education and training the Commonwealth Employment Service will be upgraded, including enhanced offsite facilities, to service clients in remote areas and telephone based client services. Some 300 open access learning centres will be established throughout the country to help open learning students gain access to a variety of technological aids and support services at a cost of $52 million provided through the 1992-93 budget and into the 1993-95 period. A figure of $3.7 million over the next three years will be available for hostel accommodation for rural school students. The assets test for supplementary boarding allowance under assistance for isolated children will be abolished. This will help students living in remote areas and cost the government $14 million over the next four years.

In terms of transport and communications, a national transport planning task force will be established to assess Australia's national transport infrastructure, to meet future demands and to develop priorities for infrastructure in the long-term at a cost of $1.5 million. One such project, for instance, is the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link proposal which is receiving $3 million to complete the survey work. A figure of $1 million has been provided to establish an expert advisory group to develop a blueprint for extending optic fibre networks to the majority of houses, schools and businesses in Australia. This has enormous implications for assessing optic fibre technology for rural Australians. Also, $19.2 million over the four years will be available to extend the ABC radio station JJJ to 44 areas with populations greater than 20,000. This will enable 3.7 million additional people, mainly in rural areas, to access this excellent service.

In tourism, the government is committed to promoting regional areas and has given significant stimulus to regional tourism, which in turn means more jobs in these regions. In the current budget, $42 million over four years has been allocated to develop tourism in rural and regional Australia. In addition $23 million is available to implement a regional tourism development program, to improve the capacity of regional areas in order to attract both international and domestic tourists. Assistance for the development of farm based tourism will be part of the new special interest tourists program.

In health, over $16,000 million—that is, a nine per cent increase—will be spent on health for Australians this financial year. Many people in rural Australia will benefit directly from this. Of particular note is the senior health card, the benefits of which Senator Richardson outlined to the Senate today. This will benefit over 200,000 non-pensioner retirees.

In terms of women, of great benefit to rural women will be the new home child care allowance of up to $60 a fortnight which recognises the workload and enormous contribution of women as home makers who care full-time for children. There will be a new pilot program and referral service for women seeking to escape domestic violence in rural and remote areas. This service will provide support as well as advice on housing, finance and legal issues. In employment and industry, there will be the creation of jobs and help to unemployed people as a major thrust of the 1993-94 budget.

Unlike the opposition, which seems obsessed with the price of petrol as the one and only concern of those who live outside our major urban cities, the Labor government recognises that unemployment severely affects the lives of all Australians, city and country people alike. The federal Labor government will not accept a situation where people are condemned to long-term unemployment. The key to more jobs is to get industry moving and to facilitate economic growth. The injection of almost $30 million to assist companies become more export oriented and innovative will greatly assist many regional and rural industries.

Those on the other side of this chamber deliberately forget that much of the $600 million this government spends annually on industry programs and bounties goes to helping rural communities. In addition, this government will bring in new and improved programs and more efficient service delivery to unemployed people, including increases in the Newstart allowance and the mature age allowance. There will also be a $200 education entry payment to help unemployed people cover the cost of upgrading their skills and qualifications.

Let me contrast the federal government's approach to that of the Kennett government in Victoria. We have Liberal senators in this chamber, and one would have expected more to have been said about the attacks on the rural community in my home state. The Victorian government's approach has been to slash and burn. It has been to close schools, close railway lines and close hospitals. What have we heard from Liberal senators on the services that are available to rural communities, which are much less now as a result of the vicious attacks that have been undertaken in Victoria?

For instance, the headline in today's Melbourne papers tells us that a further 2,600 teachers are to go. That is a 6 per cent staff cut on top of the 8 to 10 per cent that has already been inflicted. This will mean that schools with fewer than 12 people in them will close. There will be closure of schools in rural Victoria, but we have heard nothing on that score from those opposite? In fact, what we see in Victoria from the National Party is that the price of coalition is silence. I would have thought that the National Party would have some obligation to their own constituents to speak up for them and to defend their rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not the Country Party any more.

—That is precisely the point, is it not? Their view is that they will do anything to get into a coalition no matter what they will have to do to stay there. It means that they will not be able to defend the interests of rural Australians.

PARA.TAB: For instance, in the case of the rail lines in Victoria, the national government is providing money to the national rail authorities for trunk routes, but what do we see on the branch lines? In Victoria we see the closure of lines. Under the Labor government $50 million was allocated to upgrade and standardise those lines, but what have we seen under the present government in Victoria? A cut of $20 million. Five lines were going to be funded under Labor and now we hear some talk of maybe two. We are waiting to see the contracts actually let for those two.

In terms of the wheat industry in Victoria, the direct assistance provided by the Liberals has been cut. The situation is one of total hypocrisy on the part of the National Party. It surprises me that National Party senators can come in here and argue a case in trying to defend rural Victorians and rural Australians, but that their leaders talk about budget cuts and further cuts to services. They expect us to cop that sweet. That is not on. Their hypocrisy has to be exposed for what it is. This ill conceived motion should be returned to the barren wasteland of rhetoric from which it sprang.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of Senator Brownhill's motion because I believe that this federal ALP budget shows a total lack of consideration for rural communities. We heard first of all tonight from Senator Sherry as the main apologist for this budget, and we have just heard from Senator Carr in similar vein. These people are very game to defend any aspects of this budget. The microphone was on the other night when Martin Ferguson did not realise it was on and he said, `How do you defend the indefensible?'. That really sums up this budget.

PARA.TAB: We heard 31 initiatives from Senator Sherry. Let me give the Senate a few other initiatives that are in this budget: a tobacco tax rise, a HECS tax rise, a petrol tax rise, a fringe benefits tax rise, a wholesale sales tax rise, a credit union tax—that will not be a great problem in the rural sector because they have not got any money to save after what this government has done for them—and a wine and cider sales tax. That is the tax I want to concentrate on tonight because of its devastating impact on the wine industry, particularly on my own region, the Hunter.

Eric Fitzgibbon, who is the honourable member for the Hunter, actually increased his vote at the last election. I do not think he would be game to show his face in his electorate after what this government has done to the major industry of the Hunter. Where was he when the government was framing the budget and increasing sales tax on wine by 55 per cent which next year goes up to 60 per cent?

Of course, it is not just the Hunter that is affected. The wine industry is one of our most successful domestic and export industries and it has a base in most states. These measures brought down by this government attack rural communities across a very wide range of Australian country areas. The Australian wine industry is made up of 5,000 wine grape growers, approximately 600 winemakers, and it has an annual turnover of $1 1/2 billion per annum. Wine is a very high value added product and its sales are booming in world markets. It also now has the potential to establish markets in the areas to our north. As Mr Perry Gunner, Chief Executive of the Orlando Wyndham Group, said last February in Canberra at the National Agricultural and Resource Outlook Conference:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . apart from unforeseen natural disasters or major economic upsets and trade wars, the single factor which stands between the Australian wine industry and the achievement of its $1 billion export target by the year 2000 is the availability of financial resources.

That was, of course, until the Keating government brought down its budget on Tuesday and slugged the wine industry with an increase in sales tax from 20 per cent to 31 per cent in one hit—and rising the following year. The increase in the sales tax on wine from 20 per cent to 31 per cent is a devastating attack on this industry. To quote Mr Brian Croser, President of the Winemakers Federation of Australia:
A 55% increase in sales tax at this absolutely critical moment of the development of the modern Australian wine industry is stupid in the extreme.

Unfortunately, the Winemakers Federation of Australia is expected to announce that it is revising its expected overseas sales target for the year 2000 from $1 billion down to $500 million—a halving of the expectation—due to this government's measures announced this week.

PARA.TAB: A large number of Australian wine companies have recently undertaken to raise a record $1.2 billion in investment for this industry. This was needed to meet the original $1 billion export sales target. According to Mr Croser, the investment and the export targets are at risk because of this unexpected and savagely discriminatory sales tax increase. An example is the statement delivered today by the manager of Penfolds wines that its planned vine planting program worth $100 million will now have to be reviewed.

This is tragic because this industry is a model for all other value added industries in this country. It is internationally competitive and based on sustainable natural and technological advantages. But most important, according to the Winemakers Federation, is that the very competitive and price sensitive domestic market is the springboard for any export success. According to Mr Croser:

SPEECH.PARA: The domestic market—
which makes up three-quarters of Australian wine sales—
provides the scale and opportunity for product development and is the anchor of investor confidence.

The actions of this Labor government are criticised by Mr Gunner of Orlando Wyndham. He said that, with this tax increase, `the industry had been chopped off at the knees'. When I questioned Senator Gareth Evans in this place yesterday, he completely missed the point in his answer. He said:

. . . the increase in the wholesale sales tax will not, in our judgment, make a major dent, in any significant way, in an industry that is booming, that is doing brilliantly well in terms of export markets, and that we fully expect not only to survive but also to flourish locally.

It is clear that the government cannot see how important the domestic market is as a launching pad for international sales and how the domestic market will be savaged by this tax increase. Senator Gareth Evans certainly is not listening to the winemakers.

PARA.TAB: The actions of this Labor government are nothing short of a betrayal of the wine industry. Having survived Labor's tax imposts in the 1980s, the Australian wine industry has been tripped up on this hurdle during this budget. The ill-conceived actions by this government will destroy confidence in the wine industry and its production and in the marketing plans of those investors who were beginning to be supportive of the wine industry.

As a result of Labor's budget, the Australian economy will suffer because the $300 million in export sales that we now have will not grow to $1 billion by the end of the century, as previously projected. The already reeling regional economies of Australia will take another body blow from the Keating government's careless disregard for the struggles of the small business and rural enterprise battlers, including the 600 small winemakers.

According to the Winemakers Federation, there are over 5,000 independent grape growers. These are dispersed among the regional economies and they will be affected greatly by this government's actions. This is at a time when many of them, having suffered from the rural recession and the inappropriate policies of these Labor governments, are on a knife edge. This will result in many of them being sent under and going bankrupt.

It is very important to remember that many of the winegrowers in Australia are not export oriented. The export side of the wine industry is dominated by six very large producers. The other 600 or so small, mainly family run wineries are currently having a very tough time in the domestic market, just like any other small businesses in Keating's engineered recession. According to Australia's biggest wine producer, Penfolds, as a result of these measures, Australia's domestic wine consumption will drop by five or six per cent. This is a far cry from Senator Evans's misleading and falsely optimistic comments of yesterday.

Domestic wine consumption has been declining for some time—from 23.5 litres per head in 1984-85 to 18.5 litres per head in 1992-93. With the market only just starting to pick up, the government in one hit has applied a tax impost of 55 per cent. What a way to kill an industry—and that is exactly what will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called murder.

—Industrial murder. Let us hear what some of the local people are saying. We are not just talking about the Hunter Valley, the Barossa Valley, the Margaret River and the other areas; we are also talking about areas such as Murrumbateman. There are taxes already on items such as giving away wine and tastings at wine shows, and they will be increased again. Mr Ken Helm of Helm's Wines, which is a small family run winery at Murrumbateman just 40 minutes away from Canberra, told me this morning that his business paid sales tax on free wine tastings of $1,350. With increases in sales tax of 55 and then 60 per cent, many of these small wineries will be unable to afford to offer free wine tastings or to enter wine shows. They will therefore lose a lot of publicity and a lot of sales.

PARA.TAB: On 5 August this year, only two weeks ago, the Australian newspaper reported on the tough times currently being experienced by winemakers. In the article, Mr Will Taylor of Finlaysons, a legal firm in Adelaide, said that many small wineries are unable to move forward because of very heavy debt burdens. The imposition of this cruel tax increase by the federal government will make the survival of these wineries only more difficult. According to Penfolds wines, the action of the federal government means that the Australian wine industry is now the most highly taxed industry in the world.

This is simply not the appropriate action of a government supposedly committed to expanding our exports and creating jobs. The last thing regional areas need at this time is increased taxation on their industries, such as the wine industry. The only possible result of this action by the Labor government is reduced investment, less employment and the collapse of many struggling wineries. The Labor government stands condemned by these actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was rather saddened by Senator Brownhill's attack on me when he suggested that, as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I should be ashamed to support this budget. As a member of that committee, I have always found Senator Brownhill to be very reasonable and fairly objective—in contrast to his irrational and hypocritical attack on myself and the government this afternoon. It just shows that he feels he has to attack the government regardless of the merit of the budget it brought down. I would not normally refer to a maiden speech but—
—This is your annual speech, is it?
—No, it is not. This is an important one. Senator Troeth made some comments about the way in which society should be organised and governed. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no case whatever for taxpayer support of poorly managed rural businesses, including where wrong investment or production decisions lead to commercial failure. Government should not be in the business of subsidising primary producers every time they meet adverse conditions. History suggests that government intervention in the rural economy does more harm than good. Indeed, in this area, the 19th century philosopher Thoreau was correct in his view when he said that government never furthered any enterprise but by the alacrity and speed with which it got out of its way.
So it appears that the good senator believes that government should not assist rural industry in almost any circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about taxing them out of existence?

—Everyone knows that taxation is not popular. It does not matter what sort of tax a government levies, a person who is affected by it does not want to pay that tax at all. —We don't want social programs.

—Some sections of the community do. I would like now to turn to a national drought policy document. The majority of the people on that particular committee were from the Labor Party. However, there were three people from the opposition and one Australian Democrat. When one looks at some of the recommendations of that committee, they show how well we worked together and how objective we all were, including Senator Brownhill. Let us have a look at some of the recommendations that were made in terms of how Labor Party people in a particular committee feel. Incidentally, there was no minority report; it was unanimous. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy introduce an effective Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme. The Committee further recommends that the Minister consider the following possible provisions for a revised IED scheme:—

The Committee supports the recommendations of the Task Force on land management. It considers that the management of the land—

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop rabbiting on and say what was in the budget.

—The recommendation continues:

SPEECH.PARA: on a sustainable basis is vital for the continued viability of the agricultural sector. The Committee supports the views expressed during the inquiry concerning the need for increased incentives for landholders to implement soil conservation measures.

The Committee notes that at the Australian Agricultural Council meeting in February 1992 the Commonwealth Government agreed to consider the introduction of tax measures to encourage landcare activity.
Senator Troeth would not want government money to do that. So let us go a bit further.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have read the report.
—But you have not understood it, and that is your problem. I am trying to help you to do that. The report also states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Queensland Department of Primary Industries gave the Committee detailed information on advisory and extension services provided during the drought that began in June 1991—
This is a Labor government—
Amongst other services, the State Government undertook the following:

PARA.TAB: .a fodder and agistment register that was subsequently published in Country Life and made available on the CALM computer system;
.a 008 drought hot line, including crisis counselling and referrals to other instrumentalities regarding crown rents, electricity and water charges; and

SPEECH.PARA: If the farmers were so self-reliant and did not need government help, they would have done all these things for themselves. But the government helped, and the government did these things. The conclusions in the report stated:
The Committee agrees with the view that the introduction of new arrangements based on a self-reliant approach to drought management—
And I guess that goes a bit of the way towards what Senator Troeth said about standing on one's own two feet—

must be accompanied by information programs and relevant advisory services. The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian and New Zealand Agricultural Council, provide special funding for information and advisory services and training programs as part of the implementation of a national drought policy.

Senator Troeth would not want that either. She would stand on her own two feet. She believes that if farmers go down in the drought they go out, and some greedy bank or entrepreneur would come in, buy the farms cheap and make a few dollars. But the government does not want that. It recognises that farmers who stay on the land for many years and many generations are a great strength to this community of Australia. The report goes on:
The Committee encourages State Governments to share expertise and information on services and to co-operate in devising strategies to assist farmers to manage for drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the government's response to the report?

—Senator Tambling apparently does not know about the Labor Party's attitudes and how we were able to get consensus on the committee by working together constructively in the interests of the rural community. There were further conclusions, which state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is of the view that individual landholders within rural industries should be responsible for preparing and managing for variable climatic and seasonal conditions.
Again, I agree with Senator Troeth. We say that they should stand on their own two feet. But it goes on:
However, it considers that there are limits to the self-reliance of farmers—
Senator Troeth disagrees with that—
to cope with severe drought.

If they go down in the drought, let them go out the back door. We do not believe that though. We want to save them because we know that they are an important part of the community. The report goes on:

Invariably, as drought worsens, self-reliance will diminish. Therefore, even with sound management and planning, it may be difficult for a primary producer to withstand the effects of the most severe drought.

We believe that the whole community has to contribute in times of difficulty. We do not look at things in a vacuum or in little compartments; we look at our nation as a whole, and each of us should help the others in times of difficulty. The report then went on to say:

The Committee considers that the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility to provide additional assistance in severe drought, as it is in the national interest for the Commonwealth Government to protect and maintain Australia's agricultural base and productive capacity, particularly Australia's breeding herd and flock.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rural industries will be in perpetual drought under your policies.
—Senator Brownhill agreed with all this. Those were the days when he was feeling sensible, not like today.
—I'm feeling very sensible and very worried for the rural community under your government.
—Shame on you. You ought to hang your head in shame.

—I hold my head up high. I am proud to be part of a Labor government which sincerely cares about the whole of this nation, not a few grubby people over there who care about their own special interests. Let us look at the rural adjustment scheme report. What did it do?
—Senator Calvert is on the committee and he has not had a mention and Senator Crane is, too.
—Yes, but Senator Calvert has not attacked me yet, and I know Senator Crane well, of course. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The present Scheme came into effect on 1 January 1989 following a review in 1988 as a result of which major changes were incorporated into new legislation—
They were changes for the good brought about by a Labor government—
with the objectives of operating the Scheme in a more flexible and innovative way and to more closely match the requirements for assistance of individual farmers.

Those opposite should note that—to match the requirements of individual farmers. Senators Brownhill, Crane and Calvert know that we listened very carefully to all those farmers. That is what we have done.

PARA.TAB: We looked at the question of improving the farm. Part A of the scheme provides assistance for structural adjustment purposes. It goes to these questions: capital restructuring, increasing farm size, increasing capital intensity, changing farm programs and adopting technological developments. Assistance takes the form of a 50 per cent interest subsidy on commercial loans. Honourable senators opposite asked me what we were doing; this is what we are doing. Grants and loans are also available to eligible farmers to improve their farm management skills or to obtain professional advice to improve their farm performance. Surely the opposition is not objecting to that. It seems to me to be a fairly rational and reasonable approach. We do care, otherwise we would not be pursuing such a program.

Part C of the rural adjustment scheme provides assistance to those people who leave the farm. Honourable senators opposite would say, `That is their problem. They made a commercial decision. Let them go down the drain'. We do not say that. We say that they are human beings and that they should be looked after. The community should assist them. Part C provides assistance to the farmers who have been assessed as being without prospects of a return to profitable operation. This provision enables them to leave the industry and it takes the form of household support payments and re-establishment assistance. Household support payments are equivalent to jobsearch or newstart allowances. We have done that.

Senator Brownhill asked whether that should be so. Senator Crane asked whether that should be. Senator Calvert asked whether that should be so. We did that. Now we get attacked for trying to help rural people. The rural adjustment scheme's annual report says that once the farmer has left the land or made firm contractual arrangements to do so, a means tested re-establishment grant of up to $34,000 as of 30 June 1992 may be payable. The grant is indexed according to the quarterly consumer price index. One cannot do much more, when people are really down and out and finished, than assist them to leave in a way which enables them to start a life somewhere else.

Then we get to the Commonwealth rural counselling program. It was interesting to hear the comment Senator Troeth made about standing on her own two feet—you make the wrong decision and out the door you go. As a very young person I first began to understand people on the land. I found that in those days, which was quite a while ago, people on the land were not highly educated. They really did not understand accountancy. If you talked about cash flow, they did not know what it was. So some farming families do have a problem.

I think the family farmers are a very important unit in our community; I agree with Senator Troeth about that. So we decided that we should assist in that area. In 1986 we established the Commonwealth rural counselling program, with Commonwealth assistance provided under the authority of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It provides grants that help rural communities to operate local counselling services which support and advise farm families in times of financial difficulty.

Our committee heard from people in that community who had been really happy to get that sort of assistance. In some cases it had saved them. That was not done at the initiative of people. It would not have happened if the government had not assisted. What it did was help farm families identify their options and successfully adapt to change. Opposition senators may say that if people make the wrong commercial decision or they are not smart enough to run their farm then they will go down the drain. We reject that sort of proposition. We say that these people need assistance. Let us give it to them. The community will assist in that regard. We made sure that the rural counsellors were required to have experience in a wide range of issues affecting the rural community and were well able to handle the task they were given.

In October 1991, Commonwealth RAS funding was increased by $30.64 million under parts A and B of the scheme and a new modified provision for farmers was introduced in December because of continuing difficult financial conditions, largely the result of a prolonged dry spell.

TALK.START.PARA: —And created by Labor's recession.

New South Wales

drought conditions—

to be reviewed in 2 years; part B carry-on $7,000 for 2 years only; and a training grant of $1,000 per annum for 3 years.

In addition, the Authority was able to further reduce the farmers' debt servicing commitments by negotiating with their bankers—

a 1 per cent reduction in the interest rate charged on their core debt.

PARA.TAB: We have a clear indication of the attitude of the rural and regional affairs committee—one of absolute cooperation between both sides of the chamber. We should look at what the committee suggested, what has happened in terms of the government's response and how the government has dealt with RAS.

On the spurious and emotional point about leaded petrol, I do not think anyone in this chamber would suggest that we should not try to eliminate the use of leaded petrol in this country. We should try to influence everyone around the world to get rid of leaded petrol. There is not any doubt—it is scientifically proven—that most of the lead in the air that goes into the bloodstreams of young children in this country and elsewhere in the world comes from leaded petrol fumes. It is a question of how we go about dealing with this problem.

Up to one-third of the motorists now using leaded fuel can actually avoid increases altogether by simply using unleaded or minimise the impact by using leaded only occasionally. The amount of leaded fuel that is being used is far beyond what is necessary. Another one-third could use unleaded with only minor modifications to their vehicle. That is absolutely clear and simple. What about the price of petrol around the world? I am sure that many people in this chamber have been overseas and they know that, for instance, in Italy people can pay up to $1.50 for a litre of petrol.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they pay in Switzerland?

PARA.TAB: When Senator Brownhill says that there is not a problem with lead in the air in the country areas, is he saying to this chamber that he really does not care about young people in the country areas or those living next to main roads where the fumes are very heavy? TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. PARA.TAB: Rural telecommunications services will be upgraded through funding of $4 million over the next four years for the standard telephone service network. There will be no additional opportunities for disabled people to participate and the government's response therefore will be that the consequential flows to those parts of the budget are going to be very hard.

Senator Burns has to answer to all of those people throughout rural and remote Australia who he thinks are uneducated. Those people have been on the land for all of this century. They have contributed to the—
