SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to introduce amendments to the Pig Industry Act 1986, the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977, the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984.

The Pig Industry amendments are designed to improve the effectiveness of the pig industry's statutory policy body in providing advice to Government and industry on issues affecting all sectors of the industry.

The amendments to the Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation Acts enable levy motions put to annual general meetings of industry stakeholders to be passed on a simple majority on each of the appropriate registers, and no confidence motions passed by two-thirds of total votes cast with a minimum of 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register. The amendments will also allow the lodgment of proxy forms by facsimile.

Other amendments to the Meat Research Corporation Act will bring the Meat Research Corporation's functions and operational powers into line with those presently available to the majority of other Primary Industry research and development corporations which have been established under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. The opportunity will also be taken to remove the 65 year age limit on Board membership from the Meat Research Corporation Act.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act will replace one of the three members of the Committee appointed on the nomination of the Australian Meat Exporters' Federal Council with one appointed on the nomination of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia.

This Bill will establish the Australian Pig Industry Council under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 to replace the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council, which was established in 1987 under the Pig Industry Act 1986. This change gives the new Council enhanced powers and operational functions so that it can more effectively perform its role of coordinating and formulating industry policy. Also it will allow for funding of the Council by the Commonwealth Government.

Under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 industry councils are required to review and report on the strategic direction of the industry; to inquire into and report to the Minister on matters affecting the pig industry that the Council or the Minister consider warrant investigation or action; to convene industry review conferences; and to convene regular meetings of chairpersons of the other relevant statutory bodies in the industry.

The passage of the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 provided the catalyst for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to review the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council with the object of improving its effectiveness.

The review found that there was a need to clarify the Council's role and functions. It found a need to improve communication of the Council's work. It suggested that the Council needed to be financially independent, and that it should be staffed full time and located in Canberra. It recommended that there should be a minor adjustment to membership to better represent those with a direct investment in the industry, with associated interest groups being accommodated through working groups.

The review also concluded that the industry needed to take a more strategic approach to securing its future. At the moment only about one per cent of domestic production is exported. Clearly, the future for the pig industry lies in developing an export orientation. The level of investment in technology in the industry needs to be increased, and greater efficiency and rationalisation in the processing sector achieved.
The review concluded that the Council would be in a better position to address these matters if it was brought under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991.

Under this Act, provision is made for the establishment of a Council and the specification of its membership by amending the Schedule to the Act. This Bill adds the Australian Pig Industry Council to the Schedule and it is proposed that the new Council will begin its operations on Royal Assent.

Besides the Chairperson, membership will include three persons nominated by the Pork Council of Australia, one person nominated from each of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia and the National Processors Association, and the Chairpersons of each of the Australian Pork Corporation and the Pig Research and Development Corporation.

The anticipated operating costs of the Australian Pig Industry Council, which will be met by the Government, will be about $205,000 in a full year. The present Council is funded by industry levies paid to the Australian Pork Corporation. This arrangement is inconsistent with the principle of separating industry policy development from statutory marketing authority arrangements. Government funding will remove this dependency and will bring it into line with other industry council funding arrangements.

The Bill also provides for the termination of the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and establishes transition arrangements for the orderly transfer to the Australian Pig Industry Council. These arrangements ensure that all outstanding liabilities at the date of commencement will be met by the Australian Pork Corporation. There is also a provision for the old Council to continue beyond the date of commencement for the sole purpose of preparing and submitting a final annual report to Parliament.

The Bill also amends the Pig Industry Act 1986 to recognise the Pork Council of Australia as the eligible representative producer body for the purposes of Australian Pork Corporation accountability and membership of the Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee. The industry formed the Pork Council of Australia in March 1992 to supersede the Australian Pork Producers' Federation as the sole nationally representative body of pig producers.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 will change the requirements for passing motions at annual general meetings. Levy motions will now be passed on a simple majority on each of the appropriate registers. Currently it requires 75 per cent vote against a levy motion put by a Corporation for it to be overturned. No confidence motions will be passed by two-thirds of total votes cast. Additionally, at least 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register must be in favour of the motion.

The amendments will give effect to the Government's decision that levy motions at Annual general meetings should be passed on a simple majority. This also has the support of the meat and livestock industry organisations.
The new arrangements will ensure that any successful no confidence motion, which represents a very serious step for the industry to take, is based on strong industry support.

The amendments will also enable the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation to accept by facsimile forms appointing other people as proxies for people entitled to vote at Annual general meetings. This issue was raised on the floor of the Annual general meetings held in November last year. Both Corporations have subsequently requested the Government to make these amendments, and the Government has been pleased to do so, believing it will allow greater producer participation in Annual general meetings, particularly for those producers in isolated areas.

The Bill further amends the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 to give the Corporation a clear commercialisation function and to allow the Corporation to carry out routine operations and activities with the same level of confidence and efficiency as is available to research and development corporations which come under the umbrella of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act.

The additional function of facilitation of the dissemination, adoption and commercialisation of meat and livestock industry research and development results will now be included in the Meat Research Corporation Act. This function has been provided for by the Meat Research Corporation Regulations as an interim measure. The clear statement of this function in the Act will enable the Corporation to confidently develop and pursue initiatives in the increasingly important area of technology transfer, particularly commercialisation activities.

The provision in the Act requiring the Minister to approve agreements and contracts made by the Corporation where these exceed a set limiting amount will be removed. The amounts involved, particularly in the case of contracts with research organisations, require Ministerial and legislative processes which are not imposed upon other Primary Industry research and development corporations. The Meat Research Corporation will be able to operate more efficiently by removing the demand on corporate and Ministerial time created by those processes.

The Board will be able to conduct meetings and pass resolutions without it being necessary for members to meet physically, allowing meetings to be conducted by telephone or other means of communication. It will also provide a more cost effective method of meeting, as members of the Board are frequently widely dispersed geographically at times when Board meetings are scheduled.

At present the authority of the Executive Director is dependent on delegations by the Corporation. These are detailed and require reasonably frequent amendment. The Bill will give the Executive Director the direct authority to conduct the affairs of the Corporation and the power to delegate that authority to his or her staff. This will have the effect of greatly simplifying the conduct of the Corporation's operations.

In addition to these amendments, the Bill will give effect to the Government's decision of 17 September 1991 to abolish statutory age limits for part-time officeholders by taking the opportunity to remove the 65 year age limit on the appointment of Board members from the Act.

The amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984 will include a person nominated by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee. Honourable Senators will be aware that the Selection Committee is a statutory body which nominates persons to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for appointment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation. The Committee is required to nominate persons against selection criteria set out in the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act.

The Selection Committee currently consists of an independent Chairperson appointed by the Minister, and six other members appointed on the nomination of the Cattle Council of Australia, Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Australian Meat Exporters' Federal Council. The person nominated by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia will be in place of one of the three nominated by the Australian Meat Exporters' Federal Council. The inclusion of a Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia nominee on the Selection Committee will ensure that meat processors, retailers and smallgoods manufacturers are represented in the selection process for Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation Board members.

In conclusion, this Bill will create an Australian Pig Industry Council that is responsive to the policy needs of the pig industry and is effective in coordinating policy input from all industry sectors to deliver an overall strategic policy direction for the benefit of the whole industry. In the case of the meat and livestock industry, annual general meeting requirements give effect to both the Government and industry's desire to make voting requirements more democratic. The Bill will give the Meat Research Corporation the necessary basis on which to develop its evolving commercialisation role and for improved efficiency in carrying out its day to day operations and activities. The Bill will also include a nominee of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Message from the House of Representatives

TALK.START.PARA: —A message has been received from the House of Representatives responding to the Senate's resolution of 18 August concerning legislation. Copies of the message have been circulated in the chamber.
—Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that I would have liked to have asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) during question time this week but did not have the opportunity to do so. I do so now in the confident belief that Senator Sherry, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is present in the chamber, will convey this matter to Senator Faulkner. I shall be brief.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the review being undertaken in Senator Faulkner's department of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I want to ask him why he is not allowing the Vietnam veterans family support link to be consulted in relation to the review that is being undertaken. I remind Senator Faulkner that when speaking to the New South Wales RSL congress not long ago he said, `I am committed to consultation with ex-service organisations'.

The people that I am talking about are those women who are the carers of veterans suffering as a consequence of their involvement in the Vietnam war. Those women are the mothers and wives of returned veterans and have the responsibility of caring for those on Department of Veterans' Affairs pensions who need, in many instances, 24-hour a day, seven-day a week care. These people really need their families to look after them. They are not permanently in hospital but are at home sick and are being cared for by their families. It is very much a full-time job for the carers.

I believe that Senator Faulkner is consulting quite widely and his intentions are probably quite honourable when he says that he wants to consult quite widely. But I fail to understand why he does not appreciate that the carers ought to be consulted and their needs and experiences recognised.

The group that I have referred to has 1,500 members Australia-wide, but this really represents only a small proportion of the total number of people involved. Many of them do not have the time, in addition to the role that they play of looking after their family member, to take part in an organisation such as this. Luckily, there are some who have the time and energy to be spokespersons for the Vietnam veterans family support link line. Without them, many would have nobody to talk to and nobody that they can share their experiences with. For some reason they are not included in the review of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I cannot understand why that should be the case because the Department of Veterans' Affairs should be very conscious of the unpaid role that is played by the carers of veterans who need pretty intensive care from their family members.

War widows are involved—and so they should be—and are being consulted by the department in the review of the act. It is my view that this group of women ought to be consulted. I fail to understand why, presumably, somebody is advising the minister that they not be included. I ask the Minister why he will not consult with the Vietnam veterans family support link line. Why is the minister not prepared to listen to the stories that they have to tell about the role that they play in caring for Vietnam veterans?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with the previous speaker, Senator Reid, I want to use this opportunity to seek some information from Senator Schacht, the Minister for Science and Small Business. On 4 August the Trade Practices Commission put out a press release stating the new regulatory arrangements for newsagents in Victoria, and abandoning the territorial zoning system. To some degree, this was supported by the Victorian newsagents, who wanted to change the system. I cannot quite understand why; nevertheless, it was an agreement between the Victorian newsagents and the Trade Practices Commission.

PARA.TAB: If those findings and new regulatory arrangements for the newsagents of Victoria are transferred to Queensland, to the ACT and to New South Wales, a great deal of loss will be incurred by newsagents who have paid huge amounts of money for their businesses. In many cases, they have invested their life savings to acquire newsagencies, spending $400,000 or $500,000—which would be the average price of a newsagency in Queensland. They have spent that money to acquire a business which has a territorial zoning system, and if that system is deregulated it immediately reduces the value of that business.

People have been prepared to buy into newsagencies because they are the type of business which will guarantee a certain income, provided the newsagent is prepared to work seven days a week for 80, 90 or maybe even 100 hours a week, 363 days a year. The only days newsagents get off are Christmas Day and, of course, Good Friday. On every other day papers are produced and, therefore, have to be delivered.

I point out to the minister that in Queensland it is very important that this territorial zoning be maintained. Many newsagencies in the smaller towns in the rural areas of Queensland rely on what they call a cross-subsidising arrangement. They would not be able to afford to throw out a couple of hundred—or even 100—papers a day. They cross-subsidise the profits they make on the news runs—it may be only $5 or $6 a day—with the profits they make on the shops. If they cross-subsidise between the retail shops and the news runs, the businesses are quite successful.

An exemption was signed early in 1980 when the Trade Practices Commission found that the newsagents' territorial zoning system was anti-competitive but did provide a service for the community. I believe that service is still important and is still required today. If those newsagents did not have this particular zoning system, many businesses in some of the smaller communities would not be able to stay viable. This would result in papers being sold maybe in the Coles or Woolworths stores and the town's newsagency being removed, which would have an effect on the rest of the town.

Tonight I am seeking an assurance from Senator Schacht—having lobbied him on a number of occasions—that the Victorian decision will not be transferred to Queensland, New South Wales, the ACT or even Tasmania, which I think would have the same problems. It would result in a loss of business and a loss to the community, which would not be able to get specialised newspapers through grocery stores or even Coles and Woolworths.

Specialised newsagencies being removed would result in specialised magazines not being delivered. These newsagencies provide a service to the community. They have been in the community for 80 or 90 years. There is no doubt that most people are happy with the service they get. If Senator Schacht could give an assurance to the Senate and the newsagents of those particular states, I am sure he would put their minds at ease, as they are particularly worried about the investment they have made in their businesses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in the adjournment debate in response to Senator Boswell's remarks. He spoke to me today after he missed asking me a question on this matter. As the parliament is about to rise for a week or more, he wanted to get this issue raised in the Senate. I agreed that I would respond on this issue in the adjournment debate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell has raised this issue with me and made representations on a number of occasions. In my short time as minister for the small business area, Senator Boswell has been more than active in dialogue with me about issues concerning small business. This goes back to discussions we had when I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and we dealt with changing the Trade Practices Act. Senator Boswell was a very assiduous lobbyist, not only of his own colleague on the committee, Senator O'Chee, but also of me and other senators, irrespective of parliamentary affiliation, to get certain amendments to the Trade Practices Act that would, in his view, assist small business.

I agreed with him on all those issues. I also agreed with Senator Spindler, and he agreed with me. As a majority, we convinced the committee to adopt a couple of recommendations. Even when we were in the minority, we still put forward some views that we believed would assist small business in Australia.

Senator Boswell, like some others of us on that committee, made it very clear that, if he had to choose between supporting the top end of town interests, or big business, and those of small business, his heart and mind were with the interests of small business. I respect his genuine interest in this area. When he raised this issue about the situation of newsagents in Australia, I was more than happy to take up his representations.

I want to give to Senator Boswell some information from the Trade Practices Commission. I do not know whether it will be absolutely 100 per cent what he wants to hear, but I think there is enough of it to give some encouragement.

Senator Boswell and other honourable senators may be aware that recently the Trade Practices Commission made a determination with respect to a system for newspaper and magazine distribution in Victoria. To date, the Trade Practices Commission has not formally considered the positions in Queensland and New South Wales. I am advised by the Trade Practices Commission that once the revisions to the Victorian system are finalised, the Trade Practices Commission will wish to discuss with the industry participants the implications and possible application of the changes in Victoria to other states—namely, New South Wales and Queensland.

The Trade Practices Commission advised me that the period during which appeals may be lodged in Victoria expires tomorrow. If no appeals are lodged, it is expected that the new arrangement will be in place in Victoria within about three months. The TPC said it is significant to note that the changes in Victoria were supported by the Victorian Authorised Newsagents Association.

In summary, the changes reduce the anti-competitiveness of the system, allow for greater innovation and freedom in retailing and improve the efficiency of the home delivery system to the benefit of competent newsagents and their customers—so I was advised by the TPC. The changes proposed in Victoria preserve the delivery zone monopoly for home deliveries and deliveries to retail outlets which cannot obtain direct supplies from publishers. It should be noted that in South Australia and Western Australia agency distribution arrangements provide for delivery territories only as retailing is not a regulated market. The Victorian changes also provide for compensation to be paid by certain subagents to newsagents where those subagents change from obtaining supplies from a newsagent to obtaining supplies direct from the publishers.

The compensation payments to newsagents for loss of income formerly received under commission sharing arrangements applies for a transitional period. I must emphasise that in relation to Queensland and New South Wales the TPC has agreed to consult the industry before taking any steps which would or might involve issuing a notice to revoke the existing authorisations. I emphasise to Senator Boswell that the TPC has made the commitment to have consultation with the industry in New South Wales and Queensland if it is going to revoke the present authorisations.

The TPC's view is that if those authorisations are now operating in a way which is excessively anticompetitive, or if they contain restrictions now unnecessary to deliver the public benefits claim, they should be reviewed. The marketing of leading title magazines in supermarket chains has become a shopping reality and appears to be supported by customers without obvious extensive damage to newsagencies. I am advised of this by the Trade Practices Commission.

The commission is very mindful of the quality of service to readers, small businesses and retail businesses generally. It is also very mindful of the comments by and interest of Senator Boswell in this issue. It is noticeable that complaints about the newsagency system come from small businesses which object to the disadvantages they face because of these arrangements—so I am advised by the TPC.

As in the Victorian situation, if changes were considered which affect the value of existing newsagencies, the issue of compensation would be addressed. I suspect that that information is not totally what Senator Boswell wanted to hear because it indicates that after the Victorian review is completed it is quite possible that the arrangements will be reviewed in New South Wales and Victoria. The review will be done in consultation with the industry. I hope that the industry is able, with the support of such people as Senator Boswell, to explain the particular and peculiar—I do not say that in a pejorative sense—features, particularly in Queensland with its decentralised nature, that have to be considered as far as arrangements for newsagencies are concerned.

I assure Senator Boswell that I will provide him with more information if the TPC starts a process of review, so he has plenty of time to make his views known and so the people he supports have plenty of time to put their views to the TPC. At the appropriate time I will ask people within the small business area of my portfolio to consider the implications for small business—and newsagencies are small business—of any such changes if there is disagreement between the industry and the TPC because I note that in Victoria, according to the TPC, these changes were supported by the Victorian Authorised Newsagents Association.

Now that I have given that information to Senator Boswell, I want to conclude by making a few brief remarks about the opposition's contribution to the debate earlier this evening on the budget. I did not enter into the debate at that time because of the agreements about the time available for the discharge of Senate business. I was the duty minister in the chamber and on a number of occasions I felt that I had to interject about a number of points that Senator Hill was making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your experience as a minister to date has been most distinguished.

—What struck me about the remarks of Senator Hill was that he has now adopted the mentality of someone permanently in opposition. From my cursory examination of the history of the Senate, it is interesting to note that this Senate is the first since federation in which no member of the major non-Labor parties represented has had ministerial experience. That is a unique feature because in the previous 90 years, even when there were Labor governments, there were always Conservative senators—whether from the Liberal Party, the National Party or the UAP—who had some ministerial experience.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that Senator Hill's remarks reflect the fact that his experience is only in opposition. I think the opposition is now only concerned about how to be in opposition; it does not see itself in government in the forseeable future. I accept the fact that in a democracy, you are only as good as the next election.

Senator Hill's was being very plaintive tonight in his claim that we misled the people. I must say that after the 1990 election the same complaint was made; after the 1987 election the same complaint was made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, there was no recession, is that right, and no child will live in poverty?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Senator Kemp, you are on the list in front of me. You might leave your comments until then.

TALK.START.PARA: —But I am being provoked, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—The irony is that despite all those accusations from the opposition that we misled the people in those election campaigns, at subsequent elections the people still elected us to government. In the end the people will judge the various political parties.

PARA.TAB: During the remarks made by opposition speakers tonight in the budget debate, I took note of the fact that, although Senator Boswell gave the government a fair amount of stick, he did say that the issue will be resolved at the election and he will do his best to remove this government at the next election. I notice that Senator Boswell accepts the democratic process quite openly and is going to campaign to defeat us at the next election. He made his point in a way that was different to the carping and whingeing of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) who still has not overcome the fact that he was part of the team that led the Liberal Party to the election it thought it could never lose back in March this year. The psychological position is very much—

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to speak to your back bench. You think we have problems. You speak to your back bench, Christopher.

—Senator Kemp is the closest thing I have seen to the Bill Hartley of the Liberal Party of the 1990s. He was a persistent oppositionist—only interested in being good in opposition and not worrying about winning elections. Because the opposition cannot win elections, it is trying to work out how to be a permanent opposition.
—Get that tie off. You were better when you were natural.

—I remember sitting here through 1991 and 1992 and Senator Kemp sitting with a cheeky smile on his face and saying, `Just wait until the election; we'll clean you up. We're 15 per cent ahead in the opinion polls'.
—You did say that.
—Did I say that?
—Yes, Senator Kemp used to say all of that. I also remember that on election night Senator Kemp was on ABC radio making comments. Even an hour after the polls had closed—
—Two hours in Tasmania.

—Two hours after we started winning seats all down the east coast of Australia, Senator Kemp was giving predictions based on the fact that there must have been a seventh state past Western Australia that was going to deliver another 10 seats to the opposition. He went down slowly, but in the end he went down to the inevitable defeat, despite all his cockiness of the previous period.

PARA.TAB: I have always believed that, in this game of politics certainly, one day you are a rooster and another day you are a feather duster. He should never forget that. I have had enough experience in politics to know that one never takes any election for granted. We will be only as good as the next election campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that by now most members of the Senate would be well aware of my continuing campaign to bring to this place the examples of the misuse of chemicals within our society. I continue that tonight. I bring to this chamber tonight the case study story of Pat Snowden.

PARA.TAB: After helping her husband in the cleaning industry in the early years of her marriage, Pat Snowden was bewildered by the various debilitating symptoms that suddenly affected her. Like most people who take pride in their work, she fought to stay on, but in the end she had to resign because of continuing ill-health.

She had never previously considered chemicals as an explanation of that ill-health until directly after x-rays her doctor asked her, `Have you ever been exposed to chemicals other than in cleaning?' At first, through her naivety at the time, she began to inquire about the ammonia content of the heavy-duty cleaning products that she used. But then later, through further diligent searching, she found what she believes to be the responsible chemical, known as 2-butoxyethanol or ethylene glycol mono butyl ether.

Pat says that she attempted to bring the subject to the attention of people whom she thought would immediately understand the problem, but her efforts fell on deaf medical and bureaucratic ears and many of these people were openly scornful of her. She felt that she had been denigrated, ridiculed and left without the medical attention that should have been given to lung damage and industrial asthma, a diagnosis which had never been passed on to her.

She believed that governments never permitted people to use chemicals without labelling and providing suitable warnings of danger. She says, `All those years I struggled against an unknown poisonous substance and there are others who are suffering as well'. In her opinion, the people who were at that time considered experts were in fact not sufficiently qualified to understand the pattern of poisoning caused by this particular chemical. Consequently, she learnt the same lesson that many other pesticide victims have learnt, and that is that very few people, if any—including medical specialists, local GPs and government health authorities—can recognise the symptoms of chemical poisoning.

In November 1989, Pat Snowden said that she left a written report at the Victorian Department of Labour in Nauru House. It was directed to the attention of Mr Pope, showing him the scientific adverse effects of this chemical and her fears about its use. She received no reply. In April 1991, a full report was placed with a senior ACC member asking for an investigation into her allegations, and still no reply—still no action taken on her behalf.

Despite the ongoing debilitating effects from the excessive chemical exposure, Pat Snowden continued to search and supply the so-called experts with the scientific evidence of the toxic effects of this chemical and its related compounds. She feels entitled to know from each and every person who ignored her symptoms or belittled her in their professional capacity why she was treated so badly in view of the fact that the information she fought so hard to find was so readily available to them.

Pat Snowden had the normal childhood illnesses. Nevertheless, she did not need any other medical attention between the ages of eight to 21 years, at which time she had an appendectomy. During her working life she held managerial positions from 16 years of age, including one as a cash controller, until 1985. She married at 20 years of age and had four children.

Her husband's main occupation was a carpenter and he supplemented his income by working part-time as a cleaner. Sometimes Pat helped him and the children went with them. Gradually, both began to suffer illnesses they had not experienced before, while the children and Pat showed symptoms that her local doctor could not identify. He was perplexed and was unable to diagnose the white lumps with black tops which presented in Pat and her baby son. These broke out on almost every part of the body, including legs and genitalia. Her doctor even suggested that the case should be presented to the Australian Medical Journal.

Finally, Pat and her husband were so upset by continuing illnesses, which they blamed on their home for want of any other reason, that they moved away and purchased a milk bar. During the 11 months in the business, she was still ill and suffered constant bleeding thought to be period related, loss of hair, weight loss down to five stone and spasmodic shaking. The business was sold and the health problems gradually diminished. Her next working experience was at the Sandringham police station as a part-time cleaner.

During this period she suffered from migraines, pumped up feelings in her head, dreadful pain in the legs, loss of circulation, anaemia, narcolepsy, memory loss, deafness, very loud speech, red eyes, tears for no reason, dreadful cold and the inability to write. She could not follow recipes, lacked concentration and had shocking nightmares. There was a cobwebby feeling over her eyes, urine and faeces incontinence, appalling body and faeces odour and sudden drowsiness and slurred speech. She recognised a sudden irrational dislike of people, salivation then dry mouth, excruciating pain in the right chest; a cold icy feeling in the right side—very complicated symptoms, as anyone would recognise. She could not even hold light weights and at times she could not walk straight. Among other problems, she learnt in the early part of her illness that medication made her worse and she refused it from then onwards.

The symptoms changed and she began to feel afraid. Reluctantly, she took a month off work and was tested for cancer because of the debilitating illnesses. The results were negative. The doctor suggested it was depression, which she knew could not be correct. She said that she was so ill, she felt she was dying. She spent three weeks out of a month's leave in bed and the symptoms lessened a little.

She went back to work but the promised help did not eventuate. All of the symptoms returned plus others. There were pains in the right side of her chest and right arm; she was unable to breathe easily and bruising began. Then, Pat had to take two days a week off from work because she could not stand the dreadful head pains. In the end she began to hear voiced thoughts. She struggled to continue but she was having six-hour narcolepsy attacks which began about three-quarters of an hour after leaving work. It was then she decided she could no longer drive safely.

She revisited her doctor and again he wanted her to take anti-depressants. Once again she refused because it was not her habit to take medication. She struggled back to work but, through her failing health, she was forced to leave on 2 December, 1988. Today, Pat says:

SPEECH.PARA: I still suffer burning and soreness in my lungs and I find it hard to breathe. There is numbness in my left leg, a lump in my right side under my ribs, my chest feels like lead. Sometimes, I suffer short-term memory loss and the inability to walk up a few steps without feeling leg pain. However, there is no narcolepsy nor anaemia. Without medical help, I found ways to ease some of the symptoms and I believe by doing so, I have managed to stay alive.

That terrible story that I bring to the Senate tonight is one for which there has been no explanation other than this person's exposure to chemicals through her work. She is just one of the thousands of Australians who have not been properly diagnosed or catered for with regard to the health problems that they have suffered as a result of exposure to chemicals during their work or their normal daily occupation. It is because of the inability of any other standard system to cater for the needs of these people that I will continue to bring their case studies to this place. I will continue to argue that there needs to be action taken—which may need to be legislative action—to properly regulate the way we use chemicals in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped to be able to speak on the motion of my colleague Senator Brownhill today regarding the effects of the budget on the rural sector, but primarily due to Senator Burns's mind numbing 30-minute speech, I must address my comments to a certain aspect of the budget in the adjournment debate. Senator Burns's speech will be forgotten as quickly as he sat down, except for one particular comment he made—that in his 40 years of knowing them, he has found that farmers are an uneducated lot. That will be a comment repeated to Senator Burns time and time again, and not just in this chamber. As I travel around this great country, in every rural town I go to I will distribute the Hansard containing Senator Burns's comment. What a comment, Madam Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Would you address the chair and stop responding to the rabble that is around you—the noise that is around you, I should say.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order.
—I am sorry. I withdraw the comment.
—Unequivocally!
—I have withdrawn the comment. I apologise.
—You are not in your place. Perhaps you would like to vacate the chair.
—I call Senator McGauran.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. It may comfort you to know that I will also be occupying that position in the coming weeks and will have to take on the trials and tribulations that befall the chair from time to time. On this particular occasion I do sympathise with you.

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns's mind numbing 30-minute speech, I should add, was in contravention of an unspoken agreement between the two sides of the house that we would only take some 10 minutes each in addressing Senator Brownhill's notice of motion, but it took him 30 minutes to say nothing. We did not have to have that. If we are going to get through these sorts of motions, we have to stick to these agreements. Senator Burns chose to break that agreement, to take people like me out of the debate. He may think that is a clever tactic in the Senate, but we also have some clever tactics on the agenda. One is that, as the coalition announced this evening, it will not be supporting the government's tax measures which, of course, affect the rural sector and have been so well outlined this evening by other speakers.

I confine my comments to one particular point. The honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Ros Kelly, made boastful comments on the radio today about how this budget has benefited the city of Canberra, saying in fact that there will be a net increase of 400 jobs in the Public Service in Canberra.

The rural community, which has been shocked by this budget—it cannot understand why its needs have been so blindly ignored—has a right to be bitter or more bitter than it already is against this government. This budget is directed towards the pampering of its own bureaucratic corps, as boasted by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the honourable member for Canberra.

The government's running costs are up almost six per cent, but the rural community has to absorb cut after cut when it is suffering one of longest crises ever endured. I know there has been a bit of a fanfare of late in Canberra that there has been a reduction in the Public Service numbers, but this means nothing. One has only to listen to the honourable member for Canberra, Ros Kelly. She has confirmed that the staff have not been affected; they have been redeployed. She has confirmed that they are taking up other so-called special projects. So there has not been a cut at all. As confirmed by the honourable member for Canberra, there is actually a net increase of 400 jobs in the Public Service.

Here we have a minister of state celebrating the size of the Canberra based Public Service while the rural sector sinks. She is celebrating the government's making sure that some other city or some other town suffers, not its precious and protected public sector. It is no wonder the rural agenda has been lost; it has been lost in the Canberra bureaucracy. What can the second largest growing city in Australia know about the bush and the real depth of its suffering? How can a city which is annually propped up by millions and millions of dollars of public works ever understand about the infrastructure collapse in rural and regional towns in Australia? There is absolutely no doubt that every time the budget rolls around Labor always looks after its city of Canberra, its mandarins, those that work for them—those who deliver the lines and deliver the lies.

The Public Service in Canberra is the most politically appointed and biased Public Service since Federation. This year's budget has fuelled the Canberra building market still further. Despite all the austerity, we still have a $150 million construction project going ahead for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We have about the same amount of money being spent on the new complex for the Australian Geological Survey Organisation. Is it any wonder that the Canberra property market has jumped by almost 100 per cent? While Canberra continues to be recession proof, the rural community sinks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the adjournment debate. I am extremely concerned about the vindictive attack by Senator Burns on country people in general and me in particular. The implication was that country people are uneducated. On the contrary, Australian farmers are among the most efficient farmers in the world. How can a senator who belongs to a party which instituted the statistical fact of one million unemployed Australians claim to possess compassion and to care for country people? The rural adjustment scheme certainly helps people. It helps people off farms and into unemployment queues.

PARA.TAB: I also refer to the earlier remarks of Senators Sherry and Carr. Senator Sherry kindly outlined 31 initiatives which have been set out in the budget which certainly do not care for country people. Apart from the rural adjustment scheme, he detailed things such as clean food, rural counselling, community based approaches, when soon there will not be any communities to make these approaches, energy and greenhouse commitments and landcare commitments. At the moment very few farmers in Australia can afford to plant trees. I ask the government to revert its attention to the true people in the country who are really hurting: pensioners, low income earners and the unemployed, who will all be affected by what Senator Carr terms as the `fixation' of this side of the house on the petrol initiatives instituted in the budget.

It may not be apparent to the government but the reason why country people need petrol at a reasonable price is that they travel longer distances. There is no public transport, or very little which is accessible on a daily basis in the country. The area in which I live is bounded by three provincial towns, Hamilton, Portland and Warrnambool. Those towns are 100 kilometres from each other.

With the demise of small rural communities—a fact which has been hastened by the policies of the federal government—people now need to travel to one of those provincial centres on a weekly if not twice-weekly or thrice-weekly basis, simply to buy the basics of daily living, let alone visits to medical practitioners and optometrists. This means that they will need to spend more on their petrol to go and buy groceries. Trips to take their children to sporting activities on the weekend will become a luxury rather than a necessity.

Pensioners, low income earners and the unemployed contribute a great deal to their local community, mainly because they cannot afford to travel further for their entertainment or leisure activities. The fact is that they will simply not be able to indulge in any leisure or spare time activities because they will not be able to afford to drive their cars.

Although the government would like to think that its initiatives will discourage the use of leaded petrol, the fact is that, because these people will need to hang on to their cars for much longer periods, it will encourage the use of leaded petrol.

At a business level the hike in petrol prices will add to the cost of groceries, farm costs and small businesses in towns. The town in which I live, Heywood, at one stage in January 1991 had a fuel price of 88c per litre. The standard price is 72c per litre. At present, this is 12c or 15c a litre higher than it is in Melbourne. I suggest that, under the initiatives mentioned in the budget, this price discrepancy will become even greater.

In respect of the remarks made by Senator Sherry and Senator Carr, it is all very well to set up these bureaucracies and task forces, but how will they help the individual? They will not. Senator Carr mentioned the sterling endeavours of Premier Jeff Kennett who is slowly getting Victoria back on track instead of pandering to groups like teacher unions. He has had to adopt those initiatives because the party to which Senator Carr belongs progressively sent Victoria broke. If the economic upheaval, chaos and devastation had not been so severe, the strong measures undertaken by Premier Kennett would not be necessary. Most Victorians now agree that that sort of strong action is necessary.
In short, I simply wish to register my extreme concern over the lack of care, consideration and understanding of the rural sector demonstrated in the budget. I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate for delaying our departure from this place tonight. I think in six years I have made three adjournment speeches. I was not going to do so tonight until I, like Senator McGauran, became incensed by the delaying tactics of Senator Burns. Senator Burns is the chairman of the committee that Senator Brownhill, myself and you, Madam Acting Deputy President, are members of. I have always respected his chairmanship, but I thought that his display in here tonight was rather disgraceful. I was quite astounded by the way that he carried on.

PARA.TAB: I must admit that I am one of those people he was talking about. I left school when I was 15, so I suppose that I am one of those uneducated rural people that he was having a shot at tonight. I feel just as slighted as anybody else in the rural community about the unwarranted attack that he made upon the rural people of Australia. If I had had the opportunity, like my colleagues were hoping to have the opportunity today, to support Senator Brownhill, I was intending to pass comment on the fact that this being the budget week, we were very lucky yesterday to able to hear four maiden speeches, or should I now say, now that we have this new non-sexist language, four first speeches? We used in the old days to call them maiden speeches.

It was interesting to note that three of those four first speeches made comments about the effect that this government's policies have had on people in rural areas. I looked with interest at Senator Troeth's speech, and she has confirmed again tonight her ties and concerns with the people in rural areas. She said:
There is a great deal of concern in rural Australia about the future of the family farm.

SPEECH.PARA: That is absolutely correct, and that is why earlier today my colleague Senator Brownhill put forward his motion. Madam Acting Deputy President, I have the feeling that you were just as embarrassed as I was about certain comments that were made by our committee's chairman tonight about rural people.

PARA.TAB: I was also very interested to hear my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Gibson, in his first speech mention something that I had forgotten about but which was absolutely true. When talking about the prosperity that Australia has had over the years, he said:
The exceptions to this trend have been our miners and farmers who are world leaders and have remained world leaders in efficiency and productivity for the past 100 years or so.

SPEECH.PARA: It was rather comical to hear Senator Burns here tonight talking about making our farmers more efficient. We have been the most efficient farmers in the world for a long time. All we got from this government and this budget that came out this week was to screw the farmers harder and harder. All the winners in this country have been taxed out of existence over the years and this budget is no exception.

PARA.TAB: Then I was very interested to hear our new Democrat colleague Senator Woodley. He had a bit of a jibe at our side of politics, but he did say that he had spent a lot of time in the bush travelling through Queensland. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Those 30 years have enabled me to observe the steady decline in population, the impoverishment of many rural families and the awful neglect of the bush by successive governments of every complexion.

We have not been in government for 10 years. I have been farming since I was 15 years of age; I have been through the credit squeeze in the 1960s and a few other bad times; but my colleagues and myself in the bush have never experienced anything like the things this government has subjected the people in the bush to. It does not matter where one goes.

PARA.TAB: I was quite surprised to hear Senator Burns because our committee went to Barcaldine where the Labor Party supposedly had its roots. We went out and stayed there. Senator Burns took the hospitality of a magnificent woman who on the night we were there said, `Look, you've nowhere to stay because the pub is full up'. So we travelled the 50 miles to her place at 2 o'clock in the morning. She made her home available to us and extended her hospitality. She was there on her own and had been battling along. I just wonder how she feels now when she will have to pay another 10c a litre on her fuel as well as all the other nasties, such as the wholesale sales tax and the compounding effects of freight charges as they affect those who live and work in the bush. The effect of the fuel increases on goods and services in remote areas will be catastrophic.

Senator Burns has been with us on the drought inquiry to the back of Bourke where farmers were letting their sheep die and were forced to shoot kangaroos to make a living. We experienced the absolute desperation of country people. Now we see what is going to happen with this budget.

I was surprised to see that some of my Labor colleagues from Tasmania have been quite outspoken. I noted on Tuesday of this week that the new Labor member for Franklin, Harry Quick, got a headline on the front page of the Mercury. It was absolutely good stuff; the sort of stuff that Bruce Goodluck, whom Harry Quick replaced, used to get. It said, `Quick opposes petrol tax hike'. He said he was going to oppose it because it was going to have a big impact on his rural area and his battlers in Bridgewater. What happens?

TALK.START.PARA: —Has he stood up in Canberra to be counted?
—No. The budget came down the next day, and then we saw another headline: `Revolt looms from state backbenchers'. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Two of Tasmania's new Federal Labor backbenchers have vowed a party room rebellion to try to overturn some of yesterday's Budget decisions. Franklin Labor Member Harry Quick said he would oppose the petrol price increase.

What a load of rubbish. Michael Lester, who wrote this stuff, must be a member of the Labor party. He knows how things work. It is a bit of a joke for him to say all that. How can Harry Quick turn around and look at his constituents in Franklin and say, `Look, I am opposing this'. When the budget bills come up I will be interested to see what Harry Quick does. Will he do what Michael Tate quite often did—absent himself from the chamber when the vote is taken so that he can say, `Well, I did not vote in favour of it. I was going to oppose it, but unfortunately it was a budget decision and I had to go along with the party'.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of politics from Tasmania have been there. It would not have made any difference if we had crossed the floor. But if Harry Quick has got the courage of his convictions, after having all this media coverage, he should lobby Senator Devereux. Then Senator Devereux should join us over here and vote against some of these taxes that are going to affect the rural people.

I have had dozens of phone calls from sawmillers and battlers in Franklin who were quite surprised and disappointed about what has happened. With all the promises that were made at the last election, they did not believe that these sorts of things were going to happen. Dick Adams, the new member for Lyons, had the audacity to come out and say that the budget provided funds to help rural industries to set up for production of high quality clean food exports. Senator Sherry and I both know that Julian Alcorso, who produces Murilla wines in Tasmania—and who has been a very good supporter of the Labor party—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Greens.

—Well, his father has been in recent times. Julian has been a very good supporter. He had these big dinners when Bob Hawke was being re-elected and put all the money in. What thanks has he got? The government is going to decimate the fledgling wine industry in Tasmania—one of the few industries that is starting to show a bit of promise. The government has increased the excise. As my colleague Senator Tierney said here earlier tonight, the government is cutting the wine industry off at the knees.

PARA.TAB: I will not go over all the other particular matters that have been canvassed by my colleagues. It goes without saying that, as a farmer from Tasmania representing all Tasmanians who have been savagely affected—and we have been particularly affected in Tasmania because we rely on freight—it will really hurt us. I make the point once again: I just hope the people of Franklin, Lyons and Bass realise that the cavalier attitude of Harry Quick, Silvia Smith and Dick Adams is nothing but a sham—just like this budget—on the people of Australia but, in particular, on those of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly—because the hour is late and I do not wish to detain my colleagues for long—on a major paper which was presented at a recent conference which I attended. The paper was by the distinguished Victorian silk, S.E.K. Hulme, and dealt with the High Court's Mabo decision.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very difficult for members of the public to come to grips with the High Court decision and its ramifications. Since this has been a news item almost every day for the last three or four months, naturally, like all members and senators, I have had a wide range of discussions with constituents who, perhaps like us, are trying to come to grips with this particular decision.

I suppose a few themes have come through. The first theme, which I think a lot of Australians express, is that people do recognise there are serious health and unemployment problems in the Aboriginal community. I think there is a desire amongst the vast majority of Australians to make sure that those problems are properly addressed.

Equally, I think that there is concern amongst Australians who have the desire to remain—perhaps to use the words of the federation fathers—`one people with one destiny'. I think certain aspects of the debate have emerged which may perhaps suggest that the founding vision of this nation possibly may be compromised, unless the government ensures that the decisions which are taken reinforce the desire of Australians to be one people and one nation. Certainly, I believe that anything which smacks of creating special rights and privileges for particular groups will be strongly resisted by most Australians.

Equally, I think there is very little acceptance in the community of the so-called black armband view of Australian history. Professor Blainey has drawn attention to this theme that has emerged in the public debate of a view of Australian history—one which I think is held by many people on the other side of the chamber—which I think is basically out of touch with mainstream Australian views and the great sense of pride that most Australians feel about their nation and its history.

In coming to grips with this Mabo decision, I had the opportunity, as I said, to listen to a paper presented by Mr S.E.K. Hulme at the Samuel Griffiths Society. I think it is probably indisputable that S.E.K. Hulme is one of the finest legal minds in Australia and therefore what he says is worth addressing by senators and members of parliament.

I found the paper profoundly disturbing in what it said about the processes of the High Court in the Mabo decision and the process of legal reasoning adopted by some of the judges. As I have said, I felt it of value that this paper should be brought to the attention of the Senate with the expectation that perhaps others may wish to read it. Senator Sherry has given his permission for the tabling of the paper so that it may be available to the senators. Therefore, I am seeking leave to table the paper.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am someone who, under normal circumstances, would find it distasteful to criticise the actions of individuals who belong to perhaps one of the central institutions of our society—the High Court. Along with other people in this chamber, I am aware that in recent years the High Court has become very controversial indeed. Not too long ago in this chamber, Senator Schacht and former Senator Tate expressed extreme displeasure with certain actions of the High Court in relation to the political advertising decision. However, probably nothing matches the concern that has arisen over the Mabo decision.

PARA.TAB: In his paper, S.E.K. Hulme has argued that the High Court has ignored significant facts in relation to the case, indulged in specious reasoning, used language which is inappropriate to a court, and has wrongly used normal court processes, such as judicial notice, as the basis for findings in an area of controversy.

He is critical of the actions of the Chief Justice, Justice Mason, whom he criticises for not providing an `ordered and considered analysis and treatment of the matter in words which are his'. He concludes the paper by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Deane and Gaudron JJ have said in terms that the content of the law of property in Australia should be altered forever because of their view, arrived at by their joint research among unspecified material referred to by unspecified writers, of the rights and wrongs of what they call the dispossession of the aborigines in the nineteenth century. It would not be a surprise if the Australian people, if asked, said that it shouldn't.
In relation to questions about the High Court's handling of the case, he said:

. . . (they) have not arisen because the Court is handling delicate and controversial matters. The Court has always done that. What is perceived to have changed is the manner of the Court's handling of such matters.

This is an important paper. It raises vital issues about the High Court. It is a paper which requires a response. I hope that in due course it may be appropriate for the Chief Justice or others to respond to what I regard as the very serious criticisms that S.E.K. Hulme has put forward in this paper entitled Aspects of the High Court's Handling of Mabo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on the adjournment because I have been provoked by a speech that I heard in this chamber tonight. I have to say that it is one of the most disgraceful and distasteful performances that I have ever witnessed in this place.

PARA.TAB: The attack on Senator Troeth here tonight, and the misrepresentation of what she said in her speech, can only be described as pitiful. It is tragic. Until tonight, no-one on either side of the chamber in my three years in this place has chosen to come in, misquote from a maiden speech and then try to build an irrelevant case based on that misquotation.

I want to put on public record that what Senator Burns did tonight is not worthy of him. It is not worthy of the man with whom I have done a number of tours around Australia—on the drought inquiry, which I will come to in a moment, and the shearers inquiry, which is currently in progress.
When Senator Burns wakes up in the morning and thinks about what he did tonight, I hope he has the courage and decency to come back into this place and apologise for the denigration that occurred.

I can understand from some of the contributions of the other side that there would be a deal of posturing, that there would be an attempt to `defend the indefensible'. They are not my words but the words of Martin Ferguson. Those words have also been used in private by a number of people who sit on the other side of the chamber. One can understand Senator Sherry's posturing, particularly when he says that rural regions should be grateful for the government not removing the freight assistance subsidy from Tasmania—something that has been in place and kept in place by successive governments for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I use those words?
—That is what you inferred.
—Let us get that on the record.

—I am not quoting Senator Sherry exactly; I am reporting the essence of what he said. That is what he said or at least that is how I understood it. I suppose we should also be grateful that the government did not nationalise our properties, mines and a whole host of other things. That is how irrelevant that comment is. It shows the government's lack of understanding of what has happened in this budget.

PARA.TAB: The national drought policy was put together by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. Senator Burns is the chairman and you, Madam Acting Deputy President, are a member of that committee. In my view, to use that report as a defence for what has been done to rural Australia and to tie us into a comment that was taken out of context from a first speech, as I have said before, is disgraceful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgusting.
—As Senator Panizza said, it is disgusting. Senator Burns failed to say that Senator Troeth also said:

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when some areas of rural production are sadly in need of leadership, a long-term rural policy perspective shows the importance of government incentives directed towards the improvement of skills in farm management and production technologies.

How can Senator Burns come in here and misrepresent the position of what I think was a brilliant and magnificent speech? The speech quite clearly set down the principles for which Senator Troeth stands. At no time did Senator Burns try to defend the government's position, for example, on transport. Transport is very important to the cost structure, competitiveness and the productivity of this country. Transport is one area that needs reform. What has the government done for the rigs which travel backwards and forwards on our roads carting our goods and services for farmers, miners and workers? Senator Carr kept asking, `What about the workers?'. What would happen if there were no trucks to carry the goods and services or if there were no mines or farms? If they were all bankrupt and out of business, there would be no jobs for workers. We know that one million people are unemployed in this nation today, but what would happen?

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian Road Transport Association has faxed some figures to me today. This hike in fuel prices means that the cost of fuel to the transport industry will increase by $200 million to $225 million a year. Who does the government think will pay for that? The consumers will. Who are the consumers? We are all consumers. This is just another example of the hidden goods and services tax that this government has foisted on this country. As I said earlier, the cost of fuel excise and the cost of wholesale sales tax prior to this decision was about $80,000 per annum for each rig travelling 250,000 kilometres. The industry tells me that is about the number of kilometres a rig has to travel each year to break even. This means an additional cost of $15,000 to $25,000 per annum on each one of those rigs.

I want Senator Sherry to answer to me, I want the government, Senator Carr and Senator Burns to answer to me as to how the people at the end of the road—the unemployed, those who are lucky enough to have a job, those businesses that are trying to survive—are going to avoid having the government come through and create enormous cost increases at a time when we should be addressing the biggest social issue in this country, and that is unemployment. This budget does not do one thing for the unemployed people. People on the other side of the chamber, who allowed this budget to come through, should hang their heads in shame.
One could go on talking about this for a long time, but I just want to wind up my

SPEECH.PARA: comments by saying that I hope—in fact, I pray—that when we bring down the report on the shearers inquiry Senator Burns can take a much more balanced point of view. I hope he will not misuse that report as he did with another report tonight—a report that was more about social justice than economic justice. We on this side of the chamber do care about social justice. We recognise that those people who genuinely need assistance should be given assistance. We do not care if those people who genuinely need assistance are farmers, miners, live in the city, in Tasmania or on Cocos Island—that does not concern us. But it is unacceptable to me to mix up economic justice and social justice.

PARA.TAB: I conclude my comments by saying this: I have only referred to one aspect of the budget tonight and that was fuel. One could talk about the wine industry and other things. Dr Hewson tonight declared our position on behalf of the opposition in his response to the budget. Senator Hill did likewise in this chamber. Tonight I hope that the Democrats and the Greens have clearly heard what we said. I hope that both groups, who often talk

SPEECH.PARA: about fairness and social justice—in fact, we heard talk about those issues tonight from Senator Kernot—have the same conviction and commitment to the people that the Labor Party have deserted; those people that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on the night of the election, called the true believers. They have been left out in the cold and the Labor Party deserves to pay for that for a long, long time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities—

PARA.TAB: The Council was established under the Formal Agreement dated 22 December 1978 between the Commonwealth and the States (and later the Northern Territory) which established a Commonwealth-State Scheme for Co-operative Companies and Securities Regulation. This Agreement still exists but for all practical purposes it has been superseded by the Heads of Agreement on Future Corporate Regulation in Australia between the Commonwealth and the States/Northern Territory which was reached on 28 June 1990. The Heads of Agreement, which underpins the national companies and securities scheme, commenced operation on 1 January 1991 and established a new Ministerial Council for Corporations which has the same membership but a different role. In view of the negligible role left for the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities under the national scheme, the following answers relate to the Ministerial Council for Corporations:

(a) The Ministerial Council for Corporations was established by the Heads of Agreement of June 1990 between Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Ministers on future corporate legislation in Australia. Its principal function is the consideration of legislative proposals relating to the national companies and securities scheme. It also has a consultative function in relation to the appointment of members of the Australian Securities Commission, the Corporations and Securities Panel, and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee and its Legal Sub-Committee.

(b) Secretariat services for the Council are provided by the Business Law Division of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department. Meetings are held at the same time and place as meetings of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. It is the policy of that Committee to meet in the capital city of each member in turn, in accordance with an established schedule.

(c-d) The members of the Ministerial Council represent the parties to the Heads of Agreement, that is the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. Each party is represented by one member who is the minister responsible for administering companies and securities legislation in that jurisdiction. The Attorney-General of the Australian Capital Territory attends meetings of the Council as an observer and the Commonwealth Minister is the Chairperson of the Council.

(e) The Ministerial Council for Corporations has, during the past 12 months, met in Perth (2 July 1992) and in Adelaide (4 February 1993). Members of the Council met informally at Taupo in New Zealand on 14 October 1992. Meetings are usually held three times per year.

At these meetings the Council considered papers and issues which officers representing each jurisdiction had proposed following officers' meetings held shortly before each meeting. Voting and consultation also occurs between meetings by facsimile messages and letters.

The subjects considered by the Ministerial Council for Corporations have been wide-ranging. They have included rationalisation of the interface between the corporations law and the financial institutions legislation, legal professional liability in relation to corporations law matters, limited liability partnerships and proposed amendments to the national scheme laws.

(f) The Ministerial Council for Corporations does not directly receive any Commonwealth funds. However, the Secretary of the Council is an officer of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department and officers of that Department frequently prepare papers for consideration by the Council. The Commonwealth pays for its own officers to attend officers' meetings and Ministerial Council meetings.

(a) DACA provides advice to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services on the effect of Commonwealth policies, programs and activities on people with a disability, with particular reference to:

(e) DACA has been involved in a wide range of activities in the last 12 months. In summary these can be categorised in the following way:
DACA Taskforces
DACA has established a number of Taskforces to focus on specific areas of concern and to bring the skills and experience of DACA members to bear in a focused way on an issue of concern.
Work undertaken during the last 12 months has included:
a project on the safeguarding of advocacy for people with a disability in Australia;
a project on the participation of people with a disability in quality assurance issues;
the monitoring of Commonwealth employment and education programs for people with a disability administered by DEET;
participating with the Department of Transport and Communications on a national accessible transport committee focusing on transport issues for people with a disability; and
monitoring the implementation of the Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement, and the associated disability legislation of the different States and Territories.
As well as work undertaken in these specific subject areas by members in specific Taskforces, DACA has also been involved in the following key activities:
the development of the Commonwealth's Disability Discrimination legislation and the consultation processes associated with this key legislation for people with a disability;
participation in the Review of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS);
the provision of advice to the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the development of the future Survey of Aged and Disabled Persons; and
participation in the Telecom Working Group on the introduction of charging for directory assistance and the impact on people with a disability.

During the last 12 months DACA continued to produce two key publications in the disability area, ADR and Breakthrough. ADR is a quarterly journal which addresses and analyses important disability issues. Until the end of 1992, DACA also published Breakthrough, a magazine dealing with events and information in the disability field from the perspective of people with a disability. With the launch of Link magazine by Disabled Persons' International, Breakthrough is now published as a regular column in this newsletter.
